Would you please advise me what action has been taken for the building of a new school at Cape Mudge Village.

This school is over 60 years old and in bad condition and may collapse any time. It is being held together by truss rods at present, and as the Department have promised this school for several years, every effort should be made to have it built this year.

Anything you can do to bring about the erection of a new school in this village will be greatly appreciated by the Indians and myself.

Re: Cape Mudge Indian Day School
Your File 805-5 (E)

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of July 19th, I am enclosing for your information a memorandum from District School Inspector Davey wherein he suggests that, of the various plans referred to, No. 865, with minor changes, would be most suitable. Please note that these minor changes are proposed only if they will not involve any delay in advertising for tenders. I would recommend that immediate steps be taken to advertise for tenders for the erection of this school, as it is essential (reference Mr. Todd's letter of July 26th attached) that replacement of the existing building be made this year.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

July 26, 1949.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Cape Mudge School

I have examined plans 890, 862 and 865 and consider that the last of these, plan 865 is most suitable for Cape Mudge.

The living quarters could be left unfinished as we already have a teachersage which will serve for five years or more at this point.

I suggest that the partitions forming the boys' cloakroom could be omitted, giving additional length to the class room. The doors forming the entrance to the class room would then be placed to open into the boys and girls entrance halls. The store-room and bathroom on the base floor level could serve as cloakrooms. I suggest these modifications only if they will not involve any delay in the advertising for tenders. I feel that this plan with the modifications suggested would provide excellent facilities for the primary grades which are to be enrolled.

R.F. Davey,
Dist. School Inspector.
Ottawa, July 12, 1949.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Campbell River Indian Day School.
Cape Mudge Indian Day School.

In accordance with the recommendation of the Joint Parliamentary Committee that Indian children, wherever possible, be educated in association with other children, our field officials have been carrying on negotiations with various provincial departments of education.

These talks have been particularly successful in British Columbia where we have our own School Inspector, Mr. Davey, a former provincial department of education official, has been able to make considerable progress in having Indian children admitted to provincial schools. The total of such children now enrolled in these schools has risen to 435.

For some time Inspector Davey has been in discussion with the Campbell River School District concerning the two new provincial schools being erected at Campbell River and on Quadra Island (near the Cape Mudge Reserve). Please find attached a complete memorandum from him, clearly outlining the situation at each of these schools insofar as it concerns the Indian children who might be educated in them. As these are children of the United Church faith, there will be no objection from local missionaries to the proposals outlined by Inspector Davey. A summary of his suggestions is as follows:

(a) Campbell River - size of school 21 rooms including library, home economics and industrial arts.

Cost of school - $485,999 plus 6% architect's fees and $61,961 equipment.
White enrolment - 439  
Indian enrolment - 17  

Estimated contribution from Indian Affairs  
Branch on basis of enrolment - $18,700.

(b) Quadra Island Provincial School -

Size of school & rooms (superior)

Cost of school, anticipated $96,310  
and equipment at 11,634.

Transportation - one mile walk to bus and  
5 mile trip by bus.

White enrolment - 72  
Indian enrolment - 23  

Estimated contribution from Indian Affairs  
Branch on basis of enrolment - $30,000.

You will note Inspector Davy recommends that we  
continue both our small one-room schools as primary and kindergarten  
rooms. I concur in his recommendation as too often the first two  
years of school are taken up with teaching these Indian children  
to speak English. Mr. Indian Commissioner Arnell has recommended  
that the Department make a contribution towards the capital costs  
of provincial schools at both Campbell River and Quadra Island.  
I concur in his recommendation and would request that he be  
authorized to prepare an agreement to be entered into with the  
Campbell River School District, along similar lines to the draft  
agreement attached hereto.

Acting Director.

Cape Mudge Indian Day School.

Reference your 6-11-3 (156) of July 11

The matter of co-operation with the Campbell River School District has been referred to the Minister's office and we will write you when a decision has been reached. We are pleased to note that you are prepared to advertise for the construction of this building. Under separate cover, we are sending you the following plans:

(a) Plan 865 - including basement, plumbing and lighting.

(b) Plan 890 - one-room school with no teacherage.

(c) Plan 888.

Plan 865 is designed for erection where hydro is available. However, it could be adapted for use with a D.C. lighting set. Would you please advise which of these plans will be the most suitable for your requirements.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Re: Cape Mudge Indian Day School

Our requirements at the above mentioned point will be adequately filled by the construction of a one room school without teacherage, to accommodate Grades 1, 2 and 3. The remaining Grades can attend the Provincial School on Quadra Island. It is therefore in order to advertise for the construction of this building if suitable plans are available. It is understood that such plans are now in the course of preparation.

Inspector Devey considered the possibility of adapting Plan No. 888 as suggested by Mr. Neary in his letter of June 22nd in connection with our requirements at the Chehalis Indian Day School, file No. 806-5 (E). Mr. Devey noted that these plans made no provision for plumbing and feels that in view of the fact that the Cape Mudge Village is one of our most progressive that the school should be in keeping with the housing on the Reserve. He would prefer to wait for the completion of Plan 890 if this makes provision for plumbing and lighting and would not prevent the completion of the school before the end of the fiscal year.

In Mr. Neary's letter referred to above he stated that a set of the preliminary drawings were being forwarded to this office. Unfortunately these apparently have not been received and although they are no longer required for the Chehalis school, the building of which has been deferred, I shall appreciate receiving a set of the sketch plans to be used in considering construction at Cape Mudge.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Pupils Attending Quadra Island Superior School

Attached is a letter from the Secretary of the Campbell River School District requesting payment of an account in the amount of $35.00 for the removal of desks from the Provincial School at Cape Mudge to the Quadra Island Superior School. This expenditure was incurred in order to provide seating accommodation for eight pupils from the Cape Mudge Reserve who were admitted to Grade 7 and 8 of the Provincial School.

The Cape Mudge school referred to on the attached receipt is the Provincial School which bears the same name as our Indian school.

In view of the fact that this expenditure was incurred through the admission of our pupils it is recommended that the Board of School Trustees, District No. 72, be reimbursed for the $35.00. Will the Department kindly forward the cheque for this amount through this office. Also enclosed is voucher No. 48 covering the account.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

SEAL ED TENDERS addressed to the Director, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Canada, and endorsed "Tenders for Cape Mudge Indian Day School(s)" will be received until noon on September 9, 1949, for the construction by contract of:

1. One-room Indian Day School and attached teacher's residence,
   Cape Mudge Indian Reserve, Cape Mudge, B.C.

Contractors shall tender in complete accordance with the relevant drawings, specifications, and tendering documents supplied by the Department of Mines and Resources. Contractors may tender on one or more of these projects.

The drawings, specifications and other documents will be exhibited at the following points from August 8, 1949, until September 9, 1949, inclusive:

1. Indian Commissioner for B.C., Post Office Building, Vancouver, B.C.
2. Superintendent, Indian Agency, Alert Bay, B.C.

General instructions to Tenderers. Drawings and specifications are obtainable at the above offices upon deposit of Five Dollars ($5.00) in the form of a certified cheque made payable to the Receiver General of Canada. This deposit will be refunded upon return of the drawings and specifications in good condition to either:

1. Indian Commissioner for B.C., Post Office Building, Vancouver, B.C.
2. Superintendent, Indian Agency, Alert Bay, B.C.

within one month from the date on which tenders closed.

To receive consideration, tenders must be submitted on the tender forms provided and must be accompanied by a certified cheque on a chartered Bank in Canada, payable to the order of The Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources, equal to ten per cent (10%) of the amount of the tender, or Bearer Bonds of the Dominion of Canada or of the Canadian National Railway Company and its constituent companies, unconditionally guaranteed as to principal and interest by the Dominion of Canada, or of the afore-mentioned bonds and a certified cheque if required to make up an odd amount.

The Department reserves the right to reject any or all tenders, and the lowest tender will not necessarily be accepted.

H. L. Keenleyside,
Deputy Minister.

TENDERS, to be entitled to consideration, shall,

(1) Be made upon the form provided therefor, and shall be forwarded, duly sealed, and in the envelope attached thereto, on or before the time above limited.

(2) Be signed by the tenderer or tenderers as the case may be, in their respective handwritings, with the designated occupation and post office address. In the case of a company, the President, or other official having authority to bind the company, shall sign, and the corporate seal shall be affixed.

In the case of a partnership, each and every partner in the organization shall sign the tender, and in the event that such partnership shall be awarded a contract for the work, the partners will be jointly and severally bound in the contract agreement.

(3) Be accompanied by the required security deposit in amount stated in Tender Form. The amount of such security deposit will be returned to the unsuccessful tenderers as soon as the contract is awarded, or in case no tenders are accepted.

In the case of a Contractor's tender being accepted, the amount of the security deposit will be retained until such time as he has completed the contract work to the satisfaction of the Department.

(4) Have all blank spaces completely filled in, and shall give all information requested.

Tenderors shall submit with their tenders a statement of such works as they have previously undertaken similar to that on which they are tendering, giving details of the type of building and construction, location and present ownership.

Tenderors shall state whether or not all materials are of Canadian manufacture.

Tenderors shall include in their tender price all sales or special taxes in force at the time the tender is submitted.

Tenderors shall investigate and examine the site(s), everything and every condition affecting the work, and shall base their tenders on their own examination, knowledge, information and judgment, and not upon any statement, representation or information made or given by any officer or representative of the Department.

Tenderors should communicate with

1. Indian Commissioner for B.C., Post Office Building, Vancouver, B.C.
2. Superintendent, Indian Agency, Alert Bay, B.C.

and arrange to inspect the site(s) concerned.

Should a tenderor fail, within fifteen days of the date of notification of acceptance of his tender, to execute the contract form, the tenderor's security deposit shall be forthwith forfeited absolutely to His Majesty.

The Minister reserves the right to reject any or all tenders and the lowest tender will not necessarily be accepted.

This will acknowledge receipt of Plan #865 received direct from Ottawa, and I have been advised by the Commissioner's Office this is the plan they have recommended for the new Cape Mudge Indian Day School and that tenders are now being called for.

Upon perusing the plan recommended I note it includes one classroom and a modern teacher's residence as part of the structure. This will give us two modern teacherages for a one-roomed school, as we now have a fully modern, partially furnished teacherage at Cape Mudge Village. The present teacherage is a modern five-room cottage, present value about $7,000.00. The present teacherage has a good cement foundation, well-built and in a good state of repair with the exception of needing some inside decorating, a new chimney and minor repairs to plumbing. Most of the materials for these repairs have been purchased by the Department and are on the ground ready to proceed with the work. The cost of these repairs would be roughly $400.00. Two years ago the Department put a new roof on this building and painted the exterior as well as part of the interior. We own an excellent lot, fully improved on which the teacherage is located; and I am wondering if the Department has forgotten this teacherage exists when providing a second teacherage for a one-room school.

Had I been consulted and asked for a recommendation, it would have been as follows, keeping in mind the future requirements of this fast growing village:

1. Present teacherage - repairs to same to the extent of approximately $400.00, as indicated above. The present building will accommodate two teachers.

2. School - modern two classroom structure with full basement and oil-burning furnace to heat building, electric lights and full plumbing.

These recommendations based on the following facts:

1. Attached hereto list of school-age children.

2. Attached hereto list of preschool-age children.

| Term   | Children enrolled, grades 1-8 | Village children to attend school, grades 1-8 |
|--------|-------------------------------|---------------------------------------------|
| 1949-50 | 43                            | 43                                          |
| 1950-51 | 47                            | 47                                          |
| 1951-52 | 48                            | 48                                          |
| 1952-53 | 56                            | 56                                          |
| 1953-54 | 62                            | 62                                          |

I am informed Inspector Davy intends to have all children from Grade 4 up attend Quadra Island White School. To reach this school from Cape Mudge Village the children have to walk a very difficult, steep trail through the forest for approximately two miles. In good weather this would be excellent exercise but for most of the term the weather is very miserable with heavy rains and snow. There are no roads through

p.t.o.
the Reserve where transportation could be made available. In this respect I am thinking of the children's health, particularly the younger ones.

I understand Inspector Davey's desire to have the Cape Mudge children attend Quadra Island White School is for the beneficial effect it will have through mixing with White children. I am thoroughly in accord with this general policy wherever possible but we must not be misled by such splendid ideals or motives no matter how good they may be if they are not economically sound. I also understand the School Board are considering building a new Quadra Island School. Experience has proven to us that the tuition grant being charged by local School Boards has increased, in some cases to the point where it would more than pay the Department to operate their own schools. There is no set tuition fee. Each School Board bases the tuition fee charged the Department on their actual costs of operation; and if the Quadra Island Board provided with the construction of a new school, we can anticipate that our tuition fees are going to be just as high if not higher than Courtenay, which is $163.00 per pupil per year. According to our census, based on Inspector Davey's policy of sending all children from Grade 4 up to Quadra Island School, we would have to pay grants to this school as follows:

Term 1952 - 53 Grades 4 - 8, 33 children @ $163.00 each = $5,379.00
Term 1953 - 54 = 34 = $5,422.00
Term 1954 - 55 = 34 = $5,422.00

This village is growing and will continue to do so. As I analyze the known facts I am thoroughly convinced the Department should erect a two-room school, and even with two classrooms, Grade 8 could be sent to Quadra Island if the Department felt it was wise, and still save money by operating two classroom school in Cape Mudge. I have always recommended to Inspector Davey that there should be a two-room school at Cape Mudge for the reasons indicated above.

This report is being made to furnish the Department with present as well as future requirements, and is based on local facts and knowledge after years of experience as Superintendent of the Kwawkwehtl Agency. I felt this information should be given you when I was not consulted as to requirements, but whatever the Department decides to do will be appreciated. My only desire is that we have a proper school at the earliest possible date.

(W. S. Todd)
Indian Superintendent.

MEMORANDUM

September 24, 1949.

Re: Cape Mudge Indian Day School

I refer to Mr. Todd's letter of September 1st to the Department concerning the new school at the Cape Mudge Village and Mr. Neary's letter of September 19th.

As Mr. Todd knows, arrangements have been made to admit grade 4 and above to the Quadra Island School, and this will provide accommodation for the primary grades a number of years. It is quite practical for the senior group to attend the Provincial school as outlined in my memorandum dealing with the suggested agreement with the Campbell River School Board. I have walked over the trail referred to in Mr. Todd's letter, which is only one mile instead of two, and I consider that it would be too difficult for the primary children only.

With regard to the cost of educating our children in Provincial schools, it is assumed that it is the Department's policy to provide in our schools the same educational standards as prevail among the white schools. If this is to be the case undoubtedly our costs will equal those of the Provincial Department.

My reason for recommending plan 865 with the attached teacherage was that this plan is apparently the most suitable available. I understand that Mr. Arneil has visited the teacherage at Cape Mudge and is of the opinion that it will have to be replaced in five or six years, and consequently, the added expense of the attached teacherage is justified on these grounds.

The proposed use of a quonset building at a saving of approximately $7,000 is something which I feel should be considered with caution. One of these buildings of different design is being erected at Ucluelet and several Provincial School Boards are experimenting with them. However, I have not had an opportunity to see one in service and I am not in a position to comment on the suitability and appearance of this type of construction. I shall have an opportunity to see one of these buildings in use in a Provincial School District during
my trip to Williams Lake and Stuart Lake next week. This will give me an opportunity to see the building in use and to secure information regarding its suitability. As you are aware, the Cape Mudge Village is the finest from the standpoint of the quality of the housing that we have in British Columbia. It would be a mistake to construct a corrugated iron building among such a group of houses unless the general appearance has been improved considerably by the use of windows and the one front flat wall surface.

I believe that the Department would be well advised to defer proceeding with the construction of a building until I have had an opportunity to see how successful the school board experiment has been.

A.F. Davey,
Inspector of Indian Schools in B.C.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Cape Mudge Indian Day School
Your file 805-5 (E.1)

Further to my letter of September 26th, District School Inspector Davey has returned from the Williams Lake district and in his memorandum of October 6th attached, reports with regard to Quonset school buildings and recommends against the erection of a Quonset building on the Cape Mudge Reserve for the reason stated, with which recommendation I fully concur.

Mr. Neary's comments with regard to the tenders received on a standard building at Cape Mudge as compared with the cost of such a building in Eastern Canada, are noted, and while I cannot see why there should be such a great difference in the cost here and in Eastern Canada, as the tenders received were submitted on a competitive basis, it would appear to indicate that material and labour costs must be higher here.

Since writing the above Mr. Neary's letter of October 11th, in which it is suggested that both tenders on Plan 865 be rejected, has been received. This no doubt would be the proper thing to do if it were not for the fact that construction at Cape Mudge has already been postponed for a number of years, or if we had some other proposal which would provide suitable classroom accommodation at a more reasonable cost, but otherwise it is felt that in spite of the exorbitant cost the lowest tender on Plan 865 should be accepted.

We are opposed to the use of a Quonset building at this point, as stated above, having in mind the type and standard of home construction in the village and also the
fact that on Quadra Island and at Campbell River the Province is proceeding with the construction of modern buildings costing at the rate of over $20,000 per classroom.

Elimination of the proposed use of Quonset building and the rejection of the tenders on plan 865 leaves us with only one alternative if construction is not to be postponed for another year and that is the erection of a prefabricated "Multi-Flex" building of the same construction as the new schools at Pemberton, Metlakatla and elsewhere. We are confident that Prefabricated Structures can supply us with a single classroom, complete, erection of which we can arrange on a firm price basis for amounts in each case sufficiently low as to obviate the necessity for an Order-in-Council, but having in mind the absence of any reaction from the Department to our recent submission covering the proposed erection of prefab. schools in the Skeena Agency we hesitate to spend our own time, Contractors' time and the Company's time on such a proposal without some indication from the Department that it will be given consideration.

To summarize the situation briefly, this office would not recommend:

(1) Postponement of construction for another year.

(2) The erection of a Quonset building.

We would recommend:

(1) That consideration be given to the erection of a single prefabricated classroom designed in such a way that it can be easily added to if necessary, or:

(2) If this is not approved, acceptance of the lowest tender on plan 865.

W. S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
October 6, 1949.

Memorandum to: Indian Commissioner

Re: Cape Mudge Indian Day School

On my recent visit to the north, I had an opportunity of examining the one room quonset school recently constructed for the Quesnel School District at Alexandria, B.C. A number of pictures were taken of this building, prints of which are attached herewith.

I feel that this is an excellent building for our isolated reserves where the cost of standard construction is almost prohibitive. However, in the case of Cape Mudge, where there should be no difficulty with normal construction, I feel that the Department would be well advised to use their standard plans. The Cape Mudge reserve is the finest that we have in B.C. with regard to housing and general appearance. Indeed, I am sure that it compares with white communities of a similar size. It will be apparent from the pictures that the quonset type school will not add to the attractiveness of the village. I am sure that no house-holder would welcome the establishment of such a school in close proximity to his home. I might add that I had the opportunity of visiting the School Inspector, Mr. W.H. Grant of Prince George, in whose district this school is located. He informs me that he is very pleased with this building and that the school district plans on using more of them in the isolated communities. The Inspector mentioned that provision has been made for an addition and, consequently, the northern wall has been temporarily installed so that the addition of a second classroom might be effected with a minimum of difficulty. This will explain the facing of the children so that the light comes over their right shoulders,

rather than the left, as is standard practice. I assume also that when the addition is erected, the chimney will be faced, rather than left exposed, as it is at present.

The classroom arrangement is very convenient, there is ample cupboard room and excellent lighting.

The Department will recall that we are building in the West Coast Agency at Ucluelet, a school with this type of construction, and in spite of the favour which the quonset buildings have met with the Provincial School Board and Inspector, I still feel that the Cape Mudge School should be one of standard construction. Next year we will have had an opportunity to discover what faults there are, if any, with this type of building. In the case of Cape Mudge reserve, the factor of appearance should also be considered.

Dear Sir:

I have been wondering if the Dept. would consider buying the house they are renting for the teachers' use; and fixing it up comfortable for a permanent home. They do this on other reserves where I have taught and it is always much easier to secure teachers for schools where there is a comfortable home for the teacher's use. As you know we are right in the open with no fence, and cattle tramp around at all hours, rubbing on the house and drinking our rainwater. During the recent storms the rain beat in and the wind blew a lot of paper loose and the house swayed dreadfully owing to being all open underneath. There would not be very much expense attached to renovating; a lean-to kitchen at the back would be all the extra room necessary; a front porch, fence and outside finishing is all that is necessary. If the Department will consider this proposition I will go ahead and cultivate a flower and vegetable garden and try to get the people interested in doing the same. I never lived anywhere before without being able to have flowers and vegetables of my own growing. I like to have flowers especially in cases of sickness among the people. It is no use for me to preach garden cultivation and improvement of homes to the people unless I practice it myself first. I am here to help the people and here to stay as long as my services are satisfactory. I do not see any reason why we should not have an excellent attendance here and a good school for there are lots of children growing up. I find the people here a class well worth helping. Will you kindly put this matter before the Dept. I have never yet known them to turn a proposition down that would be helpful to the work.

Hoping for an early reply.

Yours sincerely

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I have been expecting to hear the result of your interview with the Superintendent of Education, hope we are to have a more comfortable home before next winter.

I knew that Mr. Cairns was pleased with my school, I hope for much greater success this year. I have worked hard to build up the work & the people are greatly interested. I have devoted all my time to the work here as I feel that is the only way to be really...
successful. Out of school hours I visit the homes where care for the sick, beside having my sewing class for girls, night-schools, social evenings for the people, I am planning a domestic science class for the women this fall which should be a great help to them & when our people return home from their summer's work there will be Sunday school to organize & always take the services when our missionary is away. I have been kept so busy that I have had no time to try to earn anything out of school hours & find at the close of the year that I am in debt & have had to borrow $50 to meet my payments. Our first year of course was the hardest, having to start housekeeping & also having so many Dr bills to meet; still living is very high here & I find my salary insufficient for our needs. I thought there was no harm in writing to you stating the facts & if you feel you can recommend

Ottawa, April 27th, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, enclosing copies of tenders which you received for the supplying of the material - cement, brick, lumber, hardware, etc. - for the erection of a teacher's residence at the Cape Mudge Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the price submitted by the Farmers Mutual Lumber Co. Ltd., Vancouver, is accepted, and you may arrange with them to forward the building material as mentioned in their tender, a copy of which you state you have retained. It is noted that the price quoted by them for this material is $969.43, F.O.B. Wharf, Vancouver. You should request this firm to forward the material freight charges prepaid, and to also forward to you their account in duplicate covering the cost of the material, together with a receipt for the freight charges paid. When the material has been received at Cape Mudge you will be good enough to certify these accounts and send them to the Department in order that payment can be made.

You should arrange for the labour required in erecting the building in accordance with the plan that was sent you in official letter of March 13th, last. The labour of the Indians in erecting the building should be given gratis. If it is necessary, however, to secure a carpenter to supervise the work, you may engage the services of a competent man to oversee the work. Proper time sheets should be kept showing the days he is employed, and the rate of payment he receives. Only the regular rates for the locality should be paid the foreman and labourers. The work is to be carried on under your supervision, and you will see that the building is properly erected and that a good and serviceable job is done.

The building should be erected on the site which has been selected on the half acre of ground which the Indians have agreed to surrender. You should obtain a surrender from the band for this half acre, which is to be used as a site for the residence. A description of the land by metes and bounds should be included in the surrender, which should be signed by a majority of the male (adult) members of the band.

I shall be pleased to hear from you as to the date the building material arrives, and the arrangements you have made with the Indians for the labour, and whether you have engaged a competent carpenter to oversee the work or not. Again, when the building is completed, you should furnish a full report descriptive of the work.

W. M. Halliday, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay,

MEMORANDUM

Purchasing Commission of Canada.

It is the intention of the Department to erect a residence for the teacher at the Cape Mudge Indian Day School (British Columbia) this coming summer. This Department will supply the material and the Indians will do the work of putting up the building gratis.

Our Agent sent an estimate of the material required to 10 dealers and invited them to tender for the supply of same. The only firm who quoted on all the material required was the Farmers Mutual Lumber Co., Ltd., Vancouver, and our Agent, who checked up the various quotations received, states that the price submitted by this firm is cheaper than dividing the order up among the other firms who only quoted on part of the material required. Owing to the difficulty in arranging for delivery at Cape Mudge, which is an out of the way point, it is considered advisable to make the purchase of the entire quantity of material from the one firm, in order that arrangements can be made for shipment.

The correspondence and quotations received are attached hereto, and I shall be pleased if you will authorize purchase from the Farmers Mutual Lumber Co., Ltd., at the price quoted by them, vizt $969.43, F.O.B. Vancouver, and forward your Minute accordingly.

MEMORANDUM.

Hon. Charles Stewart.

It is intended to erect a residence for the teacher at the Cape Mudge Indian Day School, Kwawkewlth Agency, British Columbia, during this coming summer. If we provide the materials, the Indians have agreed to do all the work in putting up the building gratis, and have also agreed to provide a site of a half acre of land.

Our Agent called for prices from a number of dealers for the lumber, sash and doors, cement, bricks, etc., required, and that of the Farmers Mutual Lumber Company, Ltd., Vancouver, is the lowest received. The tenders were submitted to the Purchasing Commission of Canada, and that of the above firm has been accepted. Their price for supplying the material required F.O.B. Vancouver is $969.43.

Funds are provided in the current year's estimates, and in view of the urgent necessity for this building, as there is no accommodation for the teacher at this point, I shall be pleased to receive your approval for the expenditure required in the purchase of the materials.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I am sending a snap of our cozy little home we have at last at Cape Mudge; we moved in before Xmas & now that it is all finished we are very comfortable.

The place was left in a very unfinished condition which meant a lot of extra work for us two. My wife and I had to make steps lay some flooring, do all the outside painting (roof included) & all the inside staining & varnishing.

We started early in the year to clear the lot & it looked pretty hopeless.
The time covered with brush or small trees, stumps & stones but by staying with it working very spare minute out of school hours & most of vacation we now have it laid out in lawn, gravel walks, flower beds, small park & good sized kitchen garden.

The Dept provided wire for fencing & lumber for a woodshed but it was just lying out in the weather & would have been yet if I had not bought posts & hired a man to put up the fence & framework of the shed. I only let him do the work we could manage, we put on the siding, did all the finishing & painted the shed to match the house.

The place is greatly admired & I am hoping our people will soon live up their places to look more homelike.

Mr Halliday says the Indians promised to provide fence posts & do the work but it came at a time when they were all logging & water fishing & if I had not gone ahead as I did the house would still be unfinished with no improvements around.

Will you kindly take the
I am glad all the hard work is done for I do not feel as tho I could stand much more of it. I am looking forward to a helpful time at the meetings I have planned for mothers, boys, & girls this winter. I shall give instruction in sewing & cooking to the women & girls.

Best wishes to you & Mrs Ferrier. Sincerely Florence Howat
Mr. Russell T. Ferrier, M.A.,
Superintendent of Indian Education,

Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

During my last visit to Cape Mudge I examined the damage done to the waste pipe-line leading from the teacher's residence to the beach, and I am requested to ask for authority to not only have this repaired, but to have the line extended.

I have on file a letter from a former teacher, Mrs. Florence Howard, dated February 20, 1925 in which she refers to the advisability of having this drain pipe extended. However, I find that in February, 1925, 225 feet of vitrified tile pipe at a cost of twenty-three cents per foot was laid. Time has shown that this is at least one hundred feet too short to affect its purpose properly. At the same time, I am convinced that the damage done to this pipe has been caused by Indians depositing their logs for fuel purposes on the beach and not taking reasonable care to avoid damaging this pipe. Unless some extensive alteration is made involving the pipe-line being buried deeper, it is quite possible that this damage will occur again in a very short time if this matter is not given the necessary attention and the repair work carried out.

In my opinion it would not be necessary to replace the whole of the pipe, but only that portion which extends over the actual beach and which hitherto has been exposed. For this purpose I would suggest that a box pipe would be more suitable as although this portion of the pipe could be sunk a little deeper, it would probably only be a matter of a year or so until it was washed clear. I would therefore recommend that an outside sum of one hundred dollars be applied for to cover the cost of having this work done.

Your obedient servant,

E.G./T
C.C. Perry, Esq.,
Asst. Commissioner for B.C.,
Department of Indian Affairs,

The Chief and members of the Chehalis Band of Indians have expressed a very strong desire to have a day school established on their reserve. At the present time there are some thirty children of school age residing there; and owing to the fact that the boarding schools in the vicinity are full to their capacity these children cannot obtain admission thereto. The Department will no doubt note that in my estimate for the coming year provision was made for the continuance of the school at Tsawassen Reserve, where there is a considerable amount of school material stored, but owing to the fact that a number of the parents and children on this reserve are absent therefrom it is very difficult, if not impossible, to secure a sufficient number of pupils to justify the reopening of the school. I would, therefore, respectfully recommend to the Department that the grant included in my estimate for Tsawassen School be transferred to Chehalis, where I believe I can secure a building from the Indians free of charge, suitable for the purpose of conducting school at present.

Trusting that the Department will favourably consider this recommendation.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir-

Having come to my knowledge that the Indian Department intends opening up a day school at the Chehalis Indian Reserve in this Province, I beg herewith to tender my application for the position of teacher to the above school.

I have had an English College education, and for a good many years past have been following the profession of architecture in this country, having had the honor of being elected a Fellow of the Royal Institute of Architects of Canada soon after the inauguration of that body.

Though not a school teacher by profession, I have had a good deal of experience in directing pupils in their studies of the above work in its various branches. I may also state I am qualified to take over the physical directorship of the children, in such exercises as drill, dumb-bells and Indian clubs etc., as well as, horticultural studies, in practical fruit growing with the Indians of more mature years.

My wife, who has had several years experience in teaching in England, and who held the position of matron on the Gordon Indian Reserve in Saskatchewan some years ago, would assist me in the school with the girls and the children. In fact it is our intention, should this application meet with your approval, to both take an active interest in the village outside the actual school hours, with a view of bettering the existing

Dear Sir:

I should esteem it a great favor if you would bring before the Indian Department the great hardship inflicted upon me and my family by the small salary allowed. The price of food and coal for transportation both by rail and gasoline boat to our nearest market town was not nearly nothing at the end of the year but cut into the little reserve of funds which so careful husband we have saved in last years.

I discussed the matter of salary with the Inspector on his last visit and he quite agreed with me that the wages are altogether inadequate. If the department will only follow me in the particular herein given I feel quite sure that something in the way of a substantial increase will be given.

The Chehalis Reserve is located eight miles by gasoline boat from the Harrison Mills Station. I have to purchase all my stores from Vancouver. A sack of flour (90lbs) costs me seven dollars (the freight on same by P.R. adds another 40 cents about). I must then hire a gasoline boat which cost me sometimes $2 and sometimes $2.50. So that by the time I get my supplies to the Reserve I have paid between forty-five or five-and-a-half cents per pound. I have to buy everything at market rates in the old house in which we live, has no provision suitable for cultivation. I am, consequently unable to raise any green vegetables or potatoes which I should certainly be able to do if the war had allowed us to have the new buildings which I understand were to be erected when I was charged from Chehalis House to Chehalis.

At this stage there are four children who are of school age. The average attendance during the March-April-June term was 27 and these children are taught in a building too small...
to admit the full attendance of those entitled to come to school. When it is considered that a good day school properly taught and further when the department are aware that the teacher, his wife and two children have to spend eleven months practically isolated I think that my application for a substantial increase of salary will meet with success. I have two children, one of school age but until the small salary of fifty dollars a month I fear that my daughter will have to do without whatever education she can obtain at home.

In conclusion, I would suggest that the department pay me the same as the teachers of Indian schools in the north viz. #50 per month. This I think would be a fair increase. I have taught in the Indian Schools now over thirty years; I was teaching for twenty years in Australia in the secondary schools and for several years in Ottawa's Business College in Vancouver. If the Department want any further information as to my ability to handle the duties I would refer them to the present Principal Mr. Craig as to my success as a teacher of white students as to my success as a teacher of white students in Canada. If a reference to the Principal of Ottawa's Business College is all that is necessary.

I trust that you will bring the matter of an increase to the attention of the Department.

Yours, dear Sir,

Very truly yours,

J.J. Moroney

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the application of Mr. Moroney, teacher of the Indian school on the Chehalis Reserve, for an addition to his salary, I beg to say that he is now paid at the rate of $700.00 per annum, and his wife is in receipt of a salary of $300.00 as field matron. There is no doubt that, owing to the high cost of living and the isolated locality in which this school is situated, his present salary is not more than sufficient to allow him a bare living.

Mr. Moroney has been in charge of this school ever since it was opened, in October, 1916, and Mr. Inspector Cains, in his last report, which was made on the 16th ultimo, says, "Mr. Moroney is an excellent teacher. He is very practical and it is marvellous what progress these pupils have made since the school was opened. He is gentle and kind in his treatment of the pupils, thus winning their confidence. Mrs. Moroney is the field matron. She nurses the sick, teaches the mothers sanitary laws, and instructs the girls in sewing, etc. If all our day schools were doing as efficient work as this one, the Indian educational problem would appear less formidable. The teacher is the greatest factor in the problem".

Mr. Moroney has maintained a high average attendance since he has had charge of this school and for the last year it was 65% of the enrolment, in spite of the influenza which visited this locality.

We are paying much higher salaries at some of the other schools in British Columbia, which are not giving as good a return either in attendance or progress.

At the Skwah School, for instance, there is an enrolment of only 19, with an average of 12, and the salary of the teacher, Mr. Grimshaw, was increased from $600.00 to $750.00 in the June quarter, 1918 and again increased from $750.00
There is no comparison between the efficiency of these two teachers, Mr. Moroney being by all odds the best. Mr. Cairns, in his last report on Mr. Grimsby's school, which was dated the 9th of April, last, states as follows:

"The senior pupils are very shy. It is difficult to get them to answer questions. The teacher's manner and his methods do not tend to bring out the best from the pupils. The senior pupils read and spell fairly well, but they cannot do much in arithmetic. They can do the simple rules but fail in the application of them. A class of juniors were learning to read, spell, write and to count. The teacher seemed to take particular pride in these juniors. He wanted me to note how well they did. I failed to see anything remarkable in their work — just ordinary work. I am convinced that the school will not reach a high standard under Mr. Grimsby. He knows nothing of methods. Then one must in sizing up the situation remember that the people are not at all progressive. The teacher is neat and orderly. He keeps everything tidy. He has many admirable characteristics."

I think it would be well to give Mr. Moroney every encouragement possible in the way of salary, as I am doubtful if a teacher who would give as good satisfaction as he is giving could be obtained.

Dear Sir,

It is with great reluctance I address you but necessity forces me thereto. I am after receiving my salary for the Jan.-March term as teacher of the Indian Day School at Chehalis. The Inspector Mr. Roth claims was here ten days ago, and we discussed the matter of salary and he seemed rather surprised to find that the increase given me had been so paltry.

I have been almost five years with Indian Schools. On July 21st, 1914, I went with my family to the Homalosin Reserve, Church House. We paid all our expenses to that place upwards of twenty-five dollars. We received payment that year for only the month of September. At the end of the year, I mentioned the fact of some adjustment but was just too understand that no such adjustment could be made.

Owing to the extreme loneliness & isolation of the place & the distance from a doctor, the Department transferred us to Chehalis, where I opened a new school, a most promising one under most discouraging circumstances. For almost three years we have labored here. Last year my wife and I with no assistance from any doctor had to handle fifty-five cases of influenza, living in a two-roomed shack in the midst of the village. I am grateful to Providence that we were able to do some good among this people both from a health & educational point of view. We have two children and the only thing that buryed us up to remain on the elusive promise, economically held out was the elusive promise, economically held out that we should have proper conditions in the near future. I am pleased to say...
that we seem to be about to realize the hope of improvement & this I am sure is due entirely to yourself, in response to an appeal made by Mrs. Moroney last November.

To come to the point, I think it only just that an adequate salary should be paid, should a man's record warrant it. I think I may refer you with confidence to the records of this school and the one at Komaiko. For four years the department paid me the salary of fifty dollars per month. Last year after several appeals an increase of fifty dollars was given; then in response to a recommendation of the Inspector another fifty dollars was added.

The increase of the cost of living is so great that and the fact that I have to keep two freighters on all groceries, one from Vancouver to Harrison Mills and then the hire of a gasoline boat from Harrison to the Reserve, makes it impossible to obtain the things which every worker is fairly entitled. The freight on my last order of fifty dollars worth of groceries amounted to four dollars.

I should consider it a very great favor indeed if you would do something to help us to tide over these hard times by recommending some increase purely due to people who are interested in what is really a great work viz - the uplift of the poor Indians of the West.

Trusting I have not trespassed too much on your patience,

I am, Sir,

very respectfully yours,

J.J. Moroney

Our expenses here, merely to obtain food, are very great. In addition to the high price of food we have to pay two and a half dollars for boat hire every day. Last Christmas, we went for our provisions, and owing to the violence of the wind and the force of the rapids we could not get back and our expenses on that occasion to obtain forty dollars worth of supplies amounted to over dollars more had to return and stay at Starvation Creek. Dear Mr. Cairns:

As you are aware, we have been most anxious to get a change from Chehalis to another school where it would be possible to give our children a chance to attend school. During the last year or more, we have written to head-quarters and while the replies have been sympathetic, nothing has come of our representations.

It is not for me to enlarge upon our services, as our reports to the Department can be consulted, and as you can bear witness to my work now going on for the term of years. However, our children are of school age, and this year we shall probably lose one of them at a boarding school, as any further delay would be disastrous to her chances of obtaining any education worth while. As this will be a heavy drain upon our resources, I must ask your help in securing from the Department an increase of salary which will bring mine on a par with other teachers. I cannot see why I am not receiving $75.00 per month the same as teachers who are within easy reach of towns. Here we have to obtain our ordinary groceries costs us one third dollar a year. Last year, a visit to a dentist to have a tooth drawn cost me twenty-two dollars. Further the price of food in these country stores is nearly fifty per cent higher than in the city of Vancouver.

I mention the facts stated above to give the Department some idea of what a great drain it will be upon us to send our daughter to a boarding school. The increased asked will be some aid towards solving the problem. At present I am receiving $800.00 per annum. The additional $100.00 is I think justly due after nine full years of service.

I feel sure that I can rely on your support and I trust that the Department will see its way to help Mrs. Moroney and myself to provide for this absolute necessity. It will be a fearful wrench to us to have to separate ourselves from our child, but it must be done at any cost.

With kind regards from all,

Yours very sincerely,

(sgd) J.J. Moroney.

Dear Sir:

For nearly ten years, I have been engaged as teacher in Indian Day Schools. On joining the Department in July, 1914 I was paid for the actual days the school was open during the September term. The understanding was that at the end of the school year I should be paid the balance to bring up the year's salary to $600.00. Several times I asked the Indian Agent, Mr. Peter Lyne, now deceased, to have this matter adjusted and he usually promised that he would take it up with the Department; he never did so. The change which has been introduced in the payment of teachers has brought this omission again to my mind and I should feel really obliged if you would give it consideration and have it settled.

When taking up this work, I had the impression that by devoting myself to work among the Indians, by learning their languages, and by studying their ways, I should equip myself for a better position. I worked devotedly for seven years before asking for an Agency. Though not successful in attaining this object, I was not discouraged until lately; now it seems that my chances of promotion are very meager. I have two children who must receive education and I have had to part with one. She is now at the Nanaimo Convent. The other, almost ten, will also have to go. This is a great deprivation to myself and to Mrs. Moroney, and the expense involved is exceedingly great. I trust then, dear Mr. Ferrier, that you will not be unsympathetic to my request.

At all times Mrs. Moroney and I have done our best to improve the Indians, both children and adults. The education of the Indian children has been a very serious matter with me, and the reports of the Inspector will show that I have not been an unfaithful servant of the Department.

Should you be able to help us in any way we shall be very grateful, indeed.

With kind regards,

I am, dear Sir,

Very truly yours,

With reference to the appointment of a teacher to succeed the late Mr. W.H. Grimshaw, at the Skwah Indian Day School, and concerning which, I understand, you have already been communicated with by Mr. W.E. Bitchburn, Indian Commissioner.

I should be glad to know at an early date what action has been taken in this direction. To transfer the Moroneys to Chilliwack would really be a financial loss, unless it were possible to open a matroncy there.

I may say that this move would be a very good one. The Chilliwack Indians and more particularly those whose children attend the Skwah Day School, are a very polite lot indeed in every sense of the word, and a Field Matron of Mrs. Moroney's calibre would do more than anything else to straighten them up in their home life.

I knew the Chehalis Reserve in 1912 and 1913, before the Moroneys went there, and a more drunken, debauched camp it would be hard to find; now all that is changed, and it is mainly attributable to the influence exerted by the teacher and matron over them. The Moroneys also have two children of school age, one of whom is attending High School, and it would mean a great deal to have the educational facilities offered by the City of Chilliwack at their door.

Would it be possible, therefore, to transfer Mrs. Moroney's matroncy with her to Chilliwack, and to create a temporary matroncy at Chehalis until the end of the fiscal year, when the position might be made permanent? I beg leave to acknowledge receipt of your communication of the 10th inst., having reference to a report made to the Department by Inspector Barry in connection with his visit to this school on June 22nd, last.

For your information I beg leave to point out that when Mr. Barry visited the Chehalis School in February 1931, he was very well satisfied with the progress of the Indian children. Indeed, he went so far as to say that they were good. They were "good" as far as the word can be employed in connection with the progress and development of Indian pupils. And this must have been so for verbal compliments are seldom bestowed by Inspectors on teachers. His report, no doubt, is still on file and we may have occasion to examine it and previous reports within the next three or four months.

It will be recalled that for two years previous to Mr. Barry's appointment there was no Inspector of Indian schools. Still Mr. Barry admitted that the children were efficient and doing well in their studies. Does it not then seem strange that as soon as the Inspector came on the job that I would have neglected my work. If such should be the insinuation behind the Inspector's report, I deny it and brand it as a colossal untruth. Teachers are just as honorable and truthful as are Inspectors, and many of them have much greater ability, a whole lot more practical experience and understand the mentality of the Indian child.

Complaint is made according to your letter that I failed to carry out certain "valuable suggestions" and did not put into practice "demonstration lessons" which the Inspector explained in "considerable detail." It is surely news to me that the Inspector made any suggestions at all, valuable or otherwise. It seemed to me to have been the other way about and that our method of imparting simple lessons to the children was looked upon by him with favor. I only wish he had made some good suggestions for we
can use them here to advantage. I just wonder what was the nature of the suggestions he had in mind?

It is quite true the Inspector gave three or four demonstration lessons, which I shall take the liberty to briefly explain: Stepping to the blackboard, Mr. Barry drew pictures of three chairs and asked the children what the pictures represented. Next he gave three or four examples in the combination of addition and subtraction—very good lessons, too, but nothing that we had not learned in our infancy thirty years ago. This ended the demonstration lessons upon which so much stress has been laid. Both lessons did not take more than ten minutes. If this is what Mr. Barry calls "considerable detail", both words must have taken on a new sense of meaning in recent years.

The Inspector, I suppose, did not go to any pains in particular when making his report to explain how he tested out and came to the positive conclusion that the suggestions he claims to have made were not carried out by me. It is a tendency with people not to make explanations if they have some definite purpose in mind which they do not wish to convey. It might, therefore, be as well to clear up this point now. When Mr. Barry visited the school in June, there were three children present. The rest of them were out digging roots in the woods and picking berries in order to get something to eat. Two of the children are in the Infant Class and the other pupil in the Third Class. It is certain that the two Siwash urchins in the Infant Class were too young to understand anything except the very simplest and plainest language. The boy in the Third Reader was examined in two subjects—he read six lines from a page of the Third Reader and made a few figures on a sheet of paper. This completed his examination. There were no questions of any kind asked him. Mr. Barry said, the boy was ready for the Fourth Reader. Now where do the valuable suggestions come in? They don't, for the very sound reason none were made.

In regard to the reading charts, the Inspector reports there are none on hand. This is serious, indeed, so serious that I am inclined to think that Mr. Barry has made a mistake in this connection and has got this school mixed up with some other school. There are eighteen charts in use here, supplied by Messrs. MacMillan Co., Toronto, several years ago. These charts or tablets measure 24 X 18 inches each, and are made of heavy cardboard. If you have any doubt about this I shall be glad to bundle them and send them by Express for your inspection.
It may be that these are not just the sort of charts Mr. Barry has reference to and that I misunderstood him. If such should be the case I am sorry and the sort of chart he has in mind ordered. True enough the charts we have on hand are old. In this school we take good care that the property of the Department is looked after with care, and nothing is ordered unless it is absolutely essential and can be used to advantage. But to say that there are not any charts in the school is a mistake.

There are no children in the world who are taught with so much care and given such consideration as are Indian children, and there are no other children in the world who respond so poorly. Every lesson is explained so thoroughly that a visitor to an Indian school might surmise the teacher was giving an exhibition of his or her skill. And this care, patience and thoroughness goes on every day, but alas, it goes for naught. Teachers may explain and expound and give the very best that is in them, but they can't be expected to bridge the void left by Nature in the Indian child's receptive brain. Memory they have not, and the germ of impulse of intelligence insofar as educational matters are concerned has not been born in them. There are a few exceptions, but the exceptions are so rare as to arouse and excite curiosity. But even in an Ape jungle exceptions will be found. The Indian child as well as the Indian adult admit they are not bright and that it is difficult for them to learn. And here we are dealing, as perhaps you know, with one of the lowest type of Indian, the very fungus of the Indian race. Lazy, shiftless, indolent, liar, all stomach and cunning. I wish Mr. Barry went among them with his suggestions. According to some of their own spokesman they intend to remain as they are. Civilization to them they state would mean taxation, and while the country supports their children at the Boarding Schools there is no valid reason for them to embrace civilization or go to any trouble to improve their condition.

School does not worry either the young or the old—it is the least of their worry. Of course if they did not have a school they would kick. With this attitude in mind and these notions held by most of the adults and imparted to the youngsters, don't you think in all fairness that it is quite a struggle for teachers to handle them. Very few people other than Indian Agents, realize the many things a teacher on an Indian reserve has to contend with, and if he does not understand them he may just as well get out. It is dubious if Mr. Barry has been long enough in the service of the Department to understand their weakness and mentality.
Nevertheless, the teacher is blamed for their imperfections, looked upon as a sort of rag, and put on the "spot" if an Indian child in his twilight stage of civilization does not answer some question he has either forgotten or never before heard.

Here the average Indian child attends school for about five months in the school-year. It is not reasonable for Inspectors or for anyone else to expect that a child, even a white child can accomplish as much or absorb as much in five months as in ten months. We have on our Roll Book children who have only been to school four days in the Quarter, others ten days, twenty-five days and thirty-six days during the same period. When the Inspector comes along he does not take this important phase or relation into consideration when making his report to the Department, but it counts against the teacher when it should not.

There are several other things which dove-tail into our work and retards progress in the schools. Two instances among many will serve as examples at this time:

Sixty per cent of the poor devils here have T. R. in one complex form or another and many of them have other chronic ailments. About October they begin to spit and hawk, sneeze and splutter and this condition lasts throughout the winter and spring months. Then, too, their houses are just dreadful. Not alone are the houses dilapidated but they are also germ infested. This is not mentioned to arouse the sympathy of the Department to build them new houses, no, indeed, for they are well able to build their own houses and there is plenty of material on the reserve. But they will not build— for the reason that while this miserable appearance is kept up, they believe visitors and tourists to the reserve will have pity on them, and that the condition of their houses is proof to all and sundry how unjustly they are treated by the Department of Indian Affairs. It is a song with them. The worse feature about it is that visitors often believe it— until they are otherwise informed. You will appreciate that children living under such abnormal conditions, with health impaired and low, sluggish vitality, are not apt to be bright or very anxious to learn.

I wish to thank you for your letter and appreciate the help you offer. I shall be always glad to carry out any instructions of my superiors. Though you may be very certain Mr. Barry will recommend my dismissal on his next visit. His last report is quite obvious.
I am

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J. W. Burns.

SIR:—

I have received a long letter from Mr. J.W. Burns, teacher upon the Chehalis Reserve, complaining of an inspection made by Mr. Barry, School Inspector, on the 22nd instant.

I know nothing of the circumstances of the case, but I gather that Mr. Barry was most indignant that only three children were present at the School, and consider it only fair to point out to the Department that the Indians have to earn their living, and that the entire Band are away picking berries and taking part in the other seasonable work in the Fraser Valley. In this they compete with Indians from the surrounding Agencies, and our hands are full with these visitors until after hop-picking. If the Department wish to support Mr. Barry and have us keep the children off the Reserve to attend school, they must be prepared to issue steady relief to the parents in lieu of the wages they are prevented from earning. This view of the case is, of course, well known to anybody with any knowledge of Indians, but it is apparently beyond the experience of our School Inspector.

The Inspector further enquired what duties the Teacher performed upon the Reserve in addition to teaching, and upon being told that he watched the Relief and kept a general eye upon the conditions and happenings, Mr. Barry is said to have told him that these matters were not merely my duty and not for him to perform. Now I wish to point out that I have only one man besides myself to cover all the Reserve comprising the Agency, that the Agency is for the most part in a thickly settled area, and that there is no two week period in the year when we have not rentals or dues of some sort to collect, and if I cannot make use of officials resident on Reserves, I must ask the Department to furnish me with more staff. It in no way detracts from the efficiency of a teacher to attend to these local matters, in fact a teacher who controls the Indians of a Band is much more likely to successfully hold down the job than one whom the Indians discover has no standing or powers in the Agency.

Mr. Burns has always handled the Chehalis Indians well. If he goes, and the class of men who would appeal to Mr. Barry succeeds him,

More attention was given here last year (1933) to the cultivation of the soil than in previous years, and a fair crop of potatoes and vegetables was raised. Fish and game was plentiful during the winter months and there was no scarcity of food. Despite this, however, the usual urgent requests for relief were sent to the Indian Agent that the Band or the "boys" were in great distress. When moan wails and groans of this kind go through, they take every precaution I will not hear about them, knowing that I am much opposed to recommending relief when employment can be found, or when they quit their jobs or spend their earnings foolishly. I trust you'll be able to gather from the two following paragraphs whether this Band was entitled to more relief during the past winter than was given them. A few cases taken at random will serve as an example of what I mean:

A member of the Band who had been away from the Reserve for the past seven years, last August quit his job at $4.00 a day and drew back wages to the amount of $300.00, and went picking hops with his wife and family for a dollar a day. He then returned to the Reserve and got one of the last three new houses just finished. He has now left the Reserve for his old job and won't again return for years, except on occasions when there are relief distributions. He has two children at St. Mary's Mission Residential School.
Several members of the Band left here for the salmon fishing last June. One of them showed me a statement of his earnings for three weeks. It amounted to $529.00. The other five fishermen also made quite a sum, and all of them were back from the north in time to pick hops. The man who made the $529, bought guns and a mighty gramaphone, expensive clothing, while his wife bakes for the household in a stovepipe. Two of the other men - father and son drank the most of their's at Vancouver. The son had come out of the North Vancouver Indian Residential School where he had spent eight years.

Before the Indians had returned from the hopfields, I was asked by a logging contractor in the neighbourhood to send him five Indians to cut shinglebolts- the job he said would last all winter. I went round from one to another, but none of them wanted to work- not they. It was not worth while. Very soon the Government would no doubt issue Special Relief- $20. a head as it xxx had done the year before. Special Relief is the thing- very fashionable, indeed. It is no longer asked for, but demanded. In a short time it will develop into a racket and as the idea spreads and takes hold it will become a menace. The huge order given last year to this Band of cadgers has already complicated matters to some extent. Depending on a similar order this winter only a few of them cured any fish last fall for winter use as had been the custom in the past.
They have been in a sulky mood for sometime, chiefly about relief. They have pointed out time and again for the past two or three months that in the Lytton Agency the Indians get anything they require for the asking of it, such as clothes, shoes, twine for nets and even potatoes, besides monthly rations. True or otherwise this information has stirred up the passion of our Siwash warriors, and the fame and generosity of the Lytton Agency resounds heavenward from every lip, while our Agency has neither pull nor power with the Tyees at Ottawa. To show that they were in earnest in this matter Isaac Mack explained that his brother Enice Mack who lives on the Seabird Island Reserve, wrote not long since to the Lytton Agency for net twine and that he was supplied with six balls. Along with this he was given on request clothing, shoes and other things to the value of $26.00, and that he is also getting monthly rations. Numerous stories of this description have excited and raised the temper of our Band, and, you know it is quite interesting to deal with a horde of jealous Siwashe whose minds are regulated by the rise and fall of their stomachs.

It is noticed that the Indian Residential Schools in this section of British Columbia are turning out an exceptional class of young Indians, that is to say if indolence, laziness and uselessness can be said to be "exceptional", we have
a number of them here who have spent years at Residential Schools. When they return to the Reserves they are soft, fat and flabby. "A fat boy" as the Principal of an Indian School told me a few years ago, "is a good advertisement for an Indian Boarding School," and so it is. But when they return to the Reserve they are lost. Day after day they stroll up and down in twos and threes with their hands thrust deep into their trousers pockets. When this exercise gets dull they take to football and visit other Reserves and relief camps to show their skill and how accomplished they are in this great pastime. Work or thoughts of work brings on giddiness, but that rarely happens for they seldom take any chances on going to work. Anything different can't be expected after spending eight, nine or ten years in comparative idleness with everything provided for them. Consequently when they come out they are like goldfish taken from a pond and exposed to the mercy of the sun. I am not referring to the "boys" here in particular, other Reserves have their "walking boys" too. Some of these fellows have learned shoemaking and carpentry, but nobody has ever seen them repair a shoe or drive a nail, and the art is soon forgotten like everything else they had been taught.

The girls are not a whit different. Their houses are dirty and untidy. Still they have qualifications worthy of mention, which is costing the Department substantial sums annually. I am
referring in this instance to the numerous letters they write to M. D. for all sorts of medicine: wintergreen, camphor, eucalyptus and anything else they can swallow or rub into themselves, not because they want it, but because its free and obtained for the asking. Of course this is not the sort of report the School Inspector would likely send you in regard to the braves the Residential Schools are turning out year after year, but some inspectors are very, very ignorant and are nothing more than floating ornaments and knew next to nothing about Indians. But here on the different Reserves we see them as they actually live, they are just clowns. There should be only one Residential School in the whole of British Columbia, one where Indian orphans would be taken care of.

In regard to relief: when there is a Special Relief issue they sit down and eat and eat and held high festival until its gone and not a tap of work is done. In order to remedy this abuse they should be put to work on the Reserve and earn the amount they are to receive in relief. In this way a certain amount of improvements can be made, and I feel sure if the Department desire that something like this might be done, it will be done.

Dear Sir;

I have the honour to forward herewith a letter which I have received this morning from Mr. J.W. Burns, teacher at Chehalis Indian Day School, together with my reply.

I do not understand from Mr. Burns' letter just what action, if any, he has taken to inform the Department of Indian Affairs of his intention to resign his position of teacher at Chehalis. In the ordinary way this teacher should have sent forward his resignation to the Department through Mr. Indian Agent Daunt at New Westminster. The matter is further complicated through the fact that Mrs. Burns is acting as Field Matron at Chehalis, and no mention is made of her intention to resign.

I have therefore to request that you will take any steps you consider necessary in this case.

You will recall that I reported unfavourably on this school twice, and that since then there has been at least one letter of complaint from the local Indians.

Mr. Indian Agent Daunt informed me some time ago when we met in Chilliwack that there had been complaints from the Indians with regard to Mr. Burns' teaching. At that time I asked him to inform the Department of Indian Affairs of these complaints, and I need hardly say that I am very glad indeed to hear that Mr. Burns is being moved from this school, as nothing could possibly be done to advance the education of the local Indians till a properly qualified teacher was placed at Chehalis.

As I am leaving for the Ross early in May, and till then my time is very fully occupied with inspection itineraries to Alert Bay, and the West Coast, an inspection could be made of the Day School at Chehalis still near the end of June, and it would seem to me to be far better to allow this teacher to relinquish his appointment without further inspection. I shall however make a note of the necessity of carrying out an inspection at Chehalis early in the next school year, when a new teacher has taken up the work there.

The teacher has made and in fact is making an attempt to follow out all suggestions made at my inspections. The number of children attending the school is small, but the teacher and Mrs. Burns, the Field Matron, are I feel certain doing very good work here.

The Indians have tried in the past to borrow money from Mr. Burns he tells me, and on being refused have attempted to get rid of this teacher.

While I was carrying out my inspection a letter was placed in my boat which I found on my return to the launch to start for Harrison Hot Springs. The Indian concerned asked the launchman to give the letter to me, but did not have the courage to wait to speak to me. Possibly the best thing I could do with this particular letter would be to destroy it, as it appears to have been sent to me by the man who was refused a loan of money some time ago. I am copying it into this report and attaching the original for the information of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Chehalis, Harrison Mills, B.C., March 28/36.

On March 5th last a general meeting of our Chehalis Band with their Reserve Council was held. It was unanimously agreed to apply to the Indian Department for a change of teacher for our Indian Day School for the following reasons:

The children attending school will do so only under compulsion as the claim that their teacher is not giving them proper attention during school hours.

The parents are sure that these children should make more progress in their school than they have been making.

The parents are also certain that their children are not taught as they should be covering the subject of each grade thoroughly, before promotion to a higher grade.

As this teacher has been here for over ten years we do think he can change his method to suit us.

The Indians of our band are quite willing and anxious to do their part in educating their children, but we are asking the Department to give us a capable Instructor who will take a deeper interest in the progress of our children and our own welfare.

(over)
Several times we wrote to the Department but we have not received any reply to our letters. We spoke about the matter when Dr. Stone was here. We would be very glad if a reply is forwarded to our Chief in acknowledgment. Chief Michael Peter

Per Wm. A. Harris.

In conclusion I may say that Mr. Burns exercises good control in his school, and that I am pleased with the progress of the school during the past year. The general standing of the school may be classified as "Satisfactory".
