SIR:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated the 9th instant, File No.155-12-1, enclosing a communication from the Chehalis Indians, requesting a change in school teachers.

In this connection, Inspector Barry will be visiting the School some time next month, and I will take the matter up with him.

I may say that on the occasion of the last inspection I accompanied Mr. Barry, who expressed himself pleased with the general conduct of the School, particularly taking into consideration the difficulties under which Mr. Burns labours.

The Chehalis Indians move out when the rhubarb appears at the end of April, and are rarely back before November. This means that most of the children have only the Winter months at School, and if the Winter happens to be inclement, even this brief period is considerably curtailed. Under these circumstances I fail to see how the Indians can expect a teacher to do more than Mr. Burns has been doing with the School.

As a matter of fact I think the real cause of the petition is that I have been frowning on the practice of admitting children from Reserves with a Day School to our Residential Schools, as we are unable to find space in these Institutions for all those children without educational facilities at their homes. The Indians would like to shelve the responsibility of the upkeep of their families onto us, and as long as they have a Day School on the Reserve, they find it difficult to do so.

I am returning the communication you forwarded to me.

Your obedient servant,

On March 5th a general meeting of the Chehalis band with their Reserve Council was held. It was unanimously agreed to apply to the Indian Department for a change of teacher for our Indian Day School for the following reasons:

The children attending school will do so only under compulsion as they claim that their teacher is not giving them proper attention during school hours.

The parents are sure that these children should make more progress in their school than they have been making.

The parents are also certain that their children are not taught as they should be covering the subject of each grade thoroughly before promotion to higher grade.

As this teacher has been here for over ten years we do not think he can change his method to suit us.

The Indians of our band are quite willing and anxious to do their part in educating their children, but we are asking the Department to give us a capable instructor who will take a deeper interest in the progress.
of our children and our own welfare. Several times we wrote to the Department, but we have not received any reply to our letters. We spoke about the matter when Dr. Stone was here. We would very glad if a reply is forwarded to our Chief in acknowledgment.

SIR:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letters of April 5th and 17th, respectively, File No.153-12-1, in connection with Mr. J.W. Burns, teacher at the Chehalis Indian Day School.

Under date of April 9th, I also received from Mr. Perry, Assistant Commissioner, a copy of a letter addressed by Mr. Burns to Mr. Barry, School Inspector, in which he resigned his position as teacher from the 30th of June. Mr. Perry informed me that he had written to Mr. Burns telling him to submit his resignation through this office, and instructed me to report to him when I received it.

As I had no reply from Mr. Burns I wrote again on April 16th, and have today received the attached letter. I am sending you the original, as Mr. Perry appears to have passed the matter on without waiting for it, and I am sending him a copy.

You will note Mr. Burns wishes to cancel his resignation if possible. As this is a matter altogether outside my province, I leave it entirely to the Department.

I would, however, point out that this man has had a very unpleasant position for nine years. The Reserve is isolated in so far as there is no road system out of it and he is entirely dependent upon the Indian boat transportation. There are no Whites for society, so he and his family are completely marooned in the midst of rather unpleasant Indians. He has consistently done his duty towards the Department as he saw it, and it is only fair to him to say that I think he looked after Departmental interests well. It is certain, after the inspection made by Doctor A.L. McQuarrie, Medical Superintendent, and myself, that the Indians did not suffer from want, although they were not allowed to run riot with our charity.

Mr. Burns is also blamed for the tightening up on the drug expenditure at Agassiz and the prohibition of promiscuous calls on the doctor. As an employee of the Department, I hold that any information he thinks of interest it is his duty to pass on.

So far as his qualifications as a teacher are concerned, this is a matter for the School Inspector. I would like to point out, however, that these Indians are away from the Reserve from May to December and no teacher can therefore do very much with them. When Mr. Inspector Pragnell visited the Reserve with me on November 26th,1932, we found only five children there, but these five thoroughly understood their work as far as they went. This would seem to imply

that Mr. Burns is not such a poor teacher, if given a chance.

The attitude of these Indians is no doubt partly influenced by the presence in the District of four Government Relief Camps, the inhabitants of which fish along the river and come in contact with the Indians. These men live splendidly on a higher scale than most taxpayers, have their clothes and tobacco found for them and $7.50 per month in cash. This, with plenty of leisure to play around fishing is a poor example to the local Indians, who would very much like to have the same treatment. There are, of course, a number of exceptions of local Indians who are educated, encouraged on by firebrands such as Mrs. Richard Felix Joe, William Harris and a few more, the whole Band soon becomes rebellious and unappreciative of the services they are receiving. When Indians are in that frame of mind, it is a mistake to cater to them, as they will not be satisfied, but keep pressing for more all the time.

I would, therefore, recommend to the consideration of the Department closing the School for a year or two anyway to bring the Indians to their senses; otherwise, any teacher appointed will be up against the same thing.

The Pemberton Indians with a membership of about 320 have been asking for a school for years. They have 78 children of school age of whom 54 are taken care of in St. Mary's Mission Residential School leaving 44 on the Reserve without educational facilities. The Chehalis School and Cottage need repairing and it is possible that the cost of these would fit up temporary premises at Pemberton if the Department were inclined to transfer the teacher provided such accommodation could be found. We badly need a Field Matron at Pemberton also, as it is over sixty miles from the nearest doctor. It would be much better policy to endeavour to place a teacher and Field Matron at Pemberton than to carry on the Chehalis School either with Mr. Burns or a new teacher.

I am very sorry for the Burns family. They have had a difficult time and will have a more difficult one if he loses his position, as it is not easy for a man getting on in years to obtain work these times. They have four young children, two of whom they have had to send outside to educate, so I do not think they have much money saved to face the world with.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letters of April 9th and 16th in which you inform me that Mr. Perry, the Assistant Commissioner, desires my resignation, originally submitted to Mr. Barry, School Inspector, to be turned in through you, I wish to say that I would like to recall that resignation if possible.

At the time I wrote it, I was feeling very badly at the attitude of the Indians and I was under the impression that another position was available. I find now that this is not the case and as I have a young family, it is a serious matter to be without work.

In connection with all this trouble, I would like to say, that the Indians blame me for the action of the Department in putting a check on their medical expenditures at the Agassiz Drug Store, and in calling the Doctor to the Reserve. I have of course never had anything to do with this, as the whole matter was raised and handled without my knowledge.

They also blame me for not giving them wide open Relief and point out that on the Chilliwack Reserves everyone is getting Relief. I know nothing of what conditions may be like at Chilliwack but I do know that Mrs. Burns as Field Matron will not recommend Relief where it is not needed and I will not recommend Relief where young men quit work to come home and loaf.

I am also suspected of keeping the Agent posted on Reserve affairs, but I think this is part of my duty as an employee of the Department. The Indians do not like having any official who has been long enough with them to know them thoroughly, for then they cannot put anything over.

An Indian on the Reserve has told me that what they would really like is to have the school closed down, as they think that the Department would then be forced to take their children and place them at Mission to be fed, and clothed. They do not realize of course that Mission is up to strength and there is no room there for more pupils.

With the removal of the Field Matron also, there would be no drug supply on the Reserve and they think that they would then be entitled to call the Doctor whenever they wish and get all the drug store medicines they want. As it costs I think $20.00 every time the Doctor comes to the Reserve and there is a great difference in
in the cost between Departmentally purchased drugs and local prices, this would cost the Department a great deal of money.

This Reserve has always been a wild one as it is difficult of access and the Indians are pretty much left alone. My crime with the Indians has not been my teaching, but the suspicion that I am responsible for them not receiving more Relief and other disciplinary measures. Anything I have done has been in the interests of the Department whose employee I am and in accordance with my duty, so I submit that the Department should protect me now.

As I said before the care of my family will be a serious matter if I lose my position, but to be candid, I think the Indians should not get a new teacher. I do think I could do useful work for the Department on some other Reserve, where the children attend school regularly enough to learn something. At Chehalis they are mostly away from May to December, so no matter what a teacher's qualifications may be, he has no proper chance with them. I have always tried to see that they thoroughly understood what they did learn and in this I think Mr. Inspector Pragnell will bear me out.

I would respectfully request that I may be given a chance on some other Reserve, if there is no such opening I am willing to face it out, but I would be very glad to have the opportunity of a transfer.

I would also add that the old custom of the teacher and Field Matron on the Reserves taking an active part in relief issues, because of their intimate knowledge of conditions, which while absolutely correct and economical from the Department's point of view, has been the real cause of all this trouble and I would ask that in future the Reserve officials be relieved of this. It will cost the Department more money and work hardship on many cases who need temporary assistance but it will keep the Teachers and Field Matrons clear of much trouble. This particularly in our area where there are four Government Relief Camps, the inhabitants of which the Indians meet and listen to.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir;

I have the honour to forward herewith a letter which I have received this morning from Mr. J.W.Burns, teacher at Chehalis Indian Day School, together with my reply.

I do not understand from Mr. Burns' letter just what action, if any, he has taken to inform the Department of Indian Affairs of his intention to resign his position of teacher at Chehalis. In the ordinary way this teacher should have sent forward his resignation to the Department through Mr. Indian Agent Daunt at New Westminster. The matter is further complicated through the fact that Mrs. Burns is acting as Field Matron at Chehalis, and no mention is made of her intention to resign.

I have therefore to request that you will take any steps you consider necessary in this case.

You will recall that I reported unfavourably on this school twice, and that since then there has been at least one letter of complaint from the local Indians.

Mr. Indian Agent Daunt informed me some time ago when we met in Chilliwack that there had been complaints from the Indians with regard to Mr. Burns' teaching. At that time I asked him to inform the Department of Indian Affairs of any such complaints. I need hardly say that I am very glad indeed to hear that Mr. Burns is being moved from this school, as nothing could possibly be done to advance the education of the local Indians till a properly qualified teacher was placed at Chehalis.

As I am leaving for the Nass early in May, and till then my time is very fully occupied with inspection itineraries to Alert Bay, and the West Coast, no inspection could be made of the Day School at Chehalis till near the end of June, and it would seem to me to be far better to allow this teacher to relinquish his appointment without further inspection. I shall however make a note of the necessity of carrying out an inspection at Chehalis early in the next school year, when a new teacher has taken up the work there.

Your obedient servant,

Gerald H. Barry
District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

The following is an extract from the Annual Report for the fiscal year ended March 31st, 1941, from Mr. J. W. Burns, Teacher of the Chehalis Indian Day School, Harrison Mills, B.C.:

Original Report on 1941-1P-British Columbia.

Ques. What community work is done by the teacher - apart from regular school work - Give details?

Ans. Fifteen years ago this reserve was one of the toughest and most degraded, down-at-the-heal reserves in British Columbia. Today it is one of the best regulated in the Province. No drinking, morals fairly good, 15 out of 24 houses compare favourably with the houses of whites throughout the Fraser Valley in regard to cleanliness and furniture. The old Indian customs and way of life are finished here. Indian basketry should be discouraged - it has made slaves of their women and children, ruined their health and encouraged laziness in their men-folk. Here the so called "Art" is passing out rapidly. Basketry work of Indian women who have T.B. should be disinfected as the cedar strands are pulled through the mouth of the basket maker.

Ques. Do the parents show interest in the education of their children?

Ans. None. They have no appreciation for anything they do not pay for. Indian schools will always be a sort of joke with the average indian until he pays for their up-keep.

Ques. Is mid-day meal served?

Ans. No. Indian children are better fed here than white children. It will pay the Indian to remain a parasite while he is hand-fed by the Department. We do not want the "midday-meal" racket started here.

Ques. Is there a regularly appointed janitor, and if so, state name?

Ans. No janitor. Here, we dispensed with janitor service at the outbreak of war. The boys do the work.

NOTE: They are not interested one way or another in the war. They refused point blank to contribute as little as one cent toward the war effort, though several of them are earning from $1200 to $2000 a year.

I beg to forward you, in duplicate, applications received from Mr. and Mrs. J.M. Goettler, for transfer from the positions of Teacher and Field Matron at Chehalis Indian Day School, to the vacancies at Skwah Reserve following the resignations of Mr. and Mrs. Burns from the latter point.

To grant this transfer would have the effect of having the Chehalis School again vacant, which is not to be desired, the more especially as both Mr. and Mrs. Goettler seem to have worked in very well with the Indians.

The Skwah School has for years been a source of trouble, and I think an effort should be made to obtain a properly qualified teacher.

I recognize that it is a difficult school to administer. The Reserves from which the pupils are drawn are scattered, and their proximity to the town of Chilliwack does not improve the moral fibre of the Indian parents. It will require a thoroughly trained and competent teacher to make much headway and awaken an interest in the School among the Indians.

In view of past difficulties, my recommendation is that unless a really good teacher can be obtained, that the School be closed until a properly qualified man is available.

Repairs to Buildings - The only Departmentally owned buildings in the Agency are four Day Schools, viz:- Pemberton, Chehalis, Skwah and Katzie. These are all in fair repair, except Katzie. This latter School has been closed for two years, and most of the windows were broken by boys. We boarded them all up, so no further damage is possible. The roof is also in poor condition, and we stopped actual leaks with such material as was on hand. The desks were all shipped to Skeena Agency in January. Both Chehalis and Skwah Schools should be painted and redecorated, but it is impossible to interest people in submitting tenders at the present time. When there is more work available in the cities and towns than can be attended to, no workmen are anxious to go out in the country on jobs. The buildings will really come to no harm until after the war, but they should certainly be attended to them.

A. O'N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

Schools: Three Day Schools have been operated throughout the year, viz: Pemberton, Chehalis and Skwah. The fourth school at Katzie Reserve has remained closed, and the desks have been shipped to the Skeen Agency.

Chehalis Indian Day School: This school is in charge of Mr. J.M. Goettler, who previously taught at the Kamloops Residential School. This school has done very well during the year. Out of twenty-four pupils on the register an average attendance of about eighteen was maintained. The teacher is popular with the Indians. Most of the men of this Reserve are continually away logging at points as far distant as Texada Island, but they are getting away from the Indian habit of taking the whole family with them when they leave home, and as a result their children are receiving an education.

A. O'N. Daunt, Esq., Indian Agent, New Westminster, B.C.

Your File 1-8-D

Replying to your letter of April 13th, 1945 re Chehalis Indian Day School, I would advise that the Inspector of Schools pointed out in his report of the 23rd ultimo that the teacher, Mr. Goettler stresses fundamentals. A great deal of educational water has flowed under the bridge since he first commenced his teaching career and it is felt that he should be encouraged to keep abreast of modern pedagogies. It is unfortunate that the attitude of some persons employed in our schools is that procedures common in rural schools thirty or forty years ago are good enough and they will exert no particular effort to keep themselves in touch with present day trends which tend to make the work far more interesting to the pupils than the old-fashioned methods. In any event the Department is anxious to promote the teaching of Home Economics, Industrial Arts, etc., in our schools.

In respect to medical examination of the pupils I would point out that a recent departmental circular calls attention to the necessity of vaccination and no doubt the usual check up was given the children at that time. It is possible Doctor Barelay would wish to have his T.B. tests applied at the same time and may wish to secure Nurse Gerry's services for the job. She could not, of course, vaccinate without Dr. Craig's instructions, nor could she properly take the place of the Doctor in making an examination of the pupils. As the Reserve is situated about one hundred miles from Vancouver there would be little difference in actual cost of visitation by the doctor or the nurse. Your further advice will be appreciated.

October 5th, 1946.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

Attached is a letter received today from Mr. J.M. Goettler, Teacher of the Chehalis Indian Day School.

I cannot understand Mr. Goettler's attitude in not notifying us before this date of his illness.

I saw him on the 17th of August at Chehalis Reserve, and he definitely stated he would re-open the School on the 4th of September. Not having heard anything to the contrary, I assumed he opened it, hence the reason I reported in my report that Mr. Goettler resumed duties in September.

Mr. Goettler's remarks on sick leave and resignation will be noted. I have written him to give us a definite resignation, and also not to cash his cheque if it is received until further advised.

Mrs. Goettler left Chehalis Indian Reserve on the 30th of August.

Indian Agent.

Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.,

Kyuquot Indian Day School

The Department is prepared to approve the transfer of Mrs. G. Green from the Kyuquot Indian Day School to the primary room at the Chehalis Indian Day School effective 1 September, 1950.

The Department has reviewed the application of Miss E.H. Langdale as a replacement for Mrs. Green and notes that she has had no elementary teaching experience in Canada. We have had considerable difficulty in the past with teachers holding English certificates in that they do not seem able to adapt themselves to teaching Indians. I would hesitate to recommend that Miss Langdale be classified as a Grade 3 teacher but would suggest that she only be classified as a Grade 2 teacher until she has met the following qualifications:

(a) Attended the British Columbia Department of Education Summer School and taken at least two courses there preferably in primary and elementary teaching techniques.

(b) Had one satisfactory inspection report from Major Davey.

Our experience has been that it is very difficult to down-grade a teacher from Grade 3 to Grade 2.

Bernard Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6387, File 806-3, part 1)
Ottawa, September 9, 1925.

SIR,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, enclosing an application of Mr. J. W. Burns for appointment as teacher at the Chehalis Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the appointment of Mr. Burns as teacher at this school is approved and he will be allowed salary at the rate of $90.00 per teaching month. Mr. Agent Daunt was informed by telegram on the 6th instant of the Department's approval of Mr. Burns' appointment.

Your obedient servant,

R. F. MacKenzie,
Act. Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. H. Cairns, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Schools,
602 Holden Building,
Vancouver, B. C.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6387, File 806-3, part 1)
Ottawa, April 12th, 1929.

Sir,

In official letter of the 6th instant, you were informed that the Department would allow an increase of $5 per teaching month in the salary of Mr. J. W. Burns, teacher of the Chenalis Indian Day School, this increase to date from the first instant. Through oversight, when paying his March quarter salary the increase was allowed from January 1st. Mr. Burns has, therefore, been overpaid the sum of $15, and this amount will be deducted when paying his June quarter salary.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Ferrier,
Dept. of Indian Education.

A. O'H. Daunt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
New Westminster, B.C.

Sir,

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure not to exceed $5.00 in the purchase of prizes for each of the above named schools.

Itemized accounts, in duplicate, should be obtained covering the purchases and these should be attached to proper voucher forms, which should be certified and forwarded to the Department for payment. Vouchers should be forwarded for the expenditure incurred for each school, and the expenditure authorized above of $5.00 for each of the schools should not be exceeded.

March 11, 1927.

John W. Burns, Esq.,
Teacher, Chehalis Indian Day School,
Harrison Mills, B.C.

Dear Mr. Burns:

I wish to thank you and your wife for the kindness that I received from you during my visit of March 6th. When I engaged these boys to take me over in their boat I had no idea of providing them with meals. However, they seemed to understand the ways of the country and made themselves very much at home.

In the matter of school supplies, I hope you will leave nothing undone so that the Readers and other books will be immediately ready for use. May I say that it would be well for you to keep a fairly good supply of school material on hand. As soon as your school material arrives kindly let me know. I recommended that twelve single desks in due time be sent to this school.

Yours sincerely,

H.H. Cairns,
Inspector of Indian Schools of British Columbia.
April 19, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, enclosing a requisition for school material and desks for the use of the Chehalis Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that an order has been forwarded to the Government Stationery Office to send to the teacher's address the classroom supplies considered necessary, with the exception of the slates. You may purchase and have delivered 12 slates.

Sir:

SIR:

In reply to your letter No. 153-12-5 of the 30th ultimo, I beg to inform you that I do not consider it feasible to pay for the clearing of a garden at the Chehalis Indian Day School.

There is a garden around the cottage, where the late teacher, Mr. Moroney, grew all that was required for himself and his family.

If the Indians desire a garden in connection with the School, there is nothing to stop them doing the work themselves, and surely if we provide them with a school and a teacher, it is not too much to expect that they will do a little on their own account.

As a matter of fact were such a garden started it would come to nothing; the Indians being away from the Reserve at the time the vegetables would need the most cultivation.

With regard to the school building, I would recommend that the matter of redecorating and repainting be allowed to stand over until next year, when an estimate of the work necessary will be forwarded to you.

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that again this year Field Matron M.H. Burns, of the Chahalis Indian Reserve, New Westminster Agency, reported that there is a great shortage of water in the wells at the school and the teacher's residence and as a result of this I wrote to Mrs. Burns asking whether or not the problem could be solved if the wells were dug some feet deeper and if so, to forward a tender for the work.

Mr. Indian Agent Dunnt, of New Westminster, has now reported that an Indian named Edward Leon will dig the well five feet deeper and box it in for the sum of $30.00. The Agent has recommended that a pump should be installed in this well which will cost approximately a further $20.00. I respectfully ask, therefore, that authority be given to have the well dug and a pump purchased and installed. Mr. Burns, the school teacher, does not consider it necessary to have two wells at present as during the season when water is short, the children can obtain it from the teacher's residence.

Will you kindly give this matter your serious consideration and let me have a reply at as early a date as possible?

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a Requisition for material urgently needed for the School and cottage.

If The Department will be good enough to supply the material requested, I shall undertake to have the work done. The Department is already acquainted with the fact that the cottage is in a bad state of repair. There are several leaks in the roof and unless it is put into condition before the rains of winter set in the plaster will fall off in the affected spots and stained by seeping rain water in other places.

The School roof leaks so badly along the south side of the building and about the chimney that during the heavy rains of a couple of weeks ago, I had to make repairs of a temporary nature so that the walls and floor would not be spoiled or stained.

A new woodshed is needed, but all I require to make one is a couple of thousand feet of third grade boards for the roof. The walls would be constructed of logs and this would be of no expense to The Department.

If The Department would be so good as to supply material to the value of about $45.00, I believe the School, cottage and woodshed could be put into such order of repair that no further expenditure would be necessary for three or four years. At present prices a lot of material can be got for the sum asked for. There is a good deal of work attached to this, but I'm willing to co-operate and do the best I can if The Dept. will only supply the material. I have already done a lot of work about the place that I have not even mentioned: gates and hinges. An underground pipe system to carry water from the house. A few months ago I had a growth of young scrub trees cut down and removed that endangered both the cottage and School.

Yours respectfully,

J. W. Burns

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR PRAGNELL ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE CHEHALIS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL, DATED DECEMBER 9, 1932, AND FORWARDED UNDER COVER OF LETTER FROM C. C. PERRY, ASSISTANT INDIAN COMMISSIONER, DATED DECEMBER 12, 1932.

---

On the 28th of November, we proceeded by motor boat to the Chehalis Reserve, and I inspected the day school there, which is under the charge of Mr. Burns.

The roof of this school leaks, particularly towards the chimney end, and this, despite the fact that everything possible has been done to try to patch it, the Indians having done good work on the roof. However, I believe that the roof is rotten all over, probably not having originally been properly built to withstand the constant downpour of rain. The only satisfactory remedy is to entirely relay the roof. If left much longer, the plaster in the interior will come down.

I also visited the teacher's residence, where Mrs. Burns, the field matron, was confined to the house with Flu. Everything was neat and tidy, but this roof, too, needs renewal.
Ottawa, December 30, 1932.

Sir:

Mr. Perry, Assistant Indian Commissioner, has forwarded the report of Mr. Inspector Pragnell on his recent inspection of the Chehalis Indian Day School. The Inspector draws attention particularly to the condition of the roof of the school and teacher's residence. He states that the roof leaks, especially towards the chimney end, despite the fact that everything possible has been done to try to patch it. He is of the opinion that the roof was probably not properly built to withstand the constant downpour of rain and that the only satisfactory remedy is to entirely relay it, as, if left much longer, the plaster in the interior will come down. He reports, further, that the roof of the teacher's residence needs renewing.

I have to request that you will have a thorough examination made of the roof of the two buildings and report regarding the repairs or work considered necessary to place these buildings in a satisfactory condition. You should state in detail the work required, the approximate cost of any material necessary and the labour in this connection. Our funds are extremely limited, but, if the cost involved is not too high, it is possible that the amount can be provided. Please state at which time of the year you would recommend that the repairs be carried out, if authorized. The Department will expect to hear from you in the near future regarding the above matter.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. O'H. Daunt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
New Westminster, B. C.

SIR:-

Sir:

The Department has received the report of Mr. Inspector Barry on his recent inspection of the Chehalis Indian Day School. The Inspector states that rain makes its way down the brick chimney and then soaks through the bricks into the plaster of the inside of the schoolroom; also that the stove pipes, although new last year, are rusted. He states that it is suggested by the teacher and yourself that, to remedy this condition, a galvanized chimney cap is required.

I would, therefore, request that you arrange to have a galvanized chimney cap installed on the chimney. This should not cost more than approximately $4.

The Inspector also states that the foundation post under one corner of the schoolroom needs renewing. Please have new posts installed.

An order will be placed here to supply three pieces blackboard, each 6' x 3'. The Inspector states that these pieces will fit into the mounts of the present old black oilcloth boards. When the blackboard arrives, you should arrange to have it installed in the classroom.

Please forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the above authorized expenditure.

Dear Sir:

When Captain Barry and yourself visited this school on the 13th instant, among other things discussed was the wretched condition of the roof of the school and the chimney, also, how the foundation of one end of the building slipped slightly during the heavy snow of last December.

Since you were here I had Mr. McRea (the carpenter who is building the new houses for Indians here) go over the building and report upon its condition. Below is quoted what he said in this connection:

"It would be necessary", said Mr. McRea, "to take the chimney down as far as the roof, re-build it and put on proper flashing and a hood (galvanized cap). I would not advise the doing of this work unless the roof is re-shingled as the old shingles are rotten. If the building is not re-shingled before next winter the plaster and kalsomine will be ruined".

At my request he has submitted an estimate of the cost of repairing the building which covers the labor and supplying the material laid down at Chehalis and comes to $188.00 made up as follows:

Repairing foundations of school and cottage ... $10.00
26 M shingles ... $78.00
Nails ... $5.00
Freight (truck and scow) ... $13.00
Scaffling ... $10.00
Labor (which includes re-building chimney) ... $70.00
Hauling material to site of building ... $2.00 $188.00

Mr. McRea said that he would repair foundations of school and cottage and put a cap and flashing on the school chimney for $20.00 in case the Department is not prepared to re-shingle the school.

Yours sincerely,

I am enclosing herewith, a letter from Mr. J.W. Burns, the teacher, giving Mr. McRea's estimate for the work, and which appears to be reasonable. Dear Mr. Daunt:

I wish you would kindly bring to the attention of the Department that every year from the first week in June to the beginning of September we're tormented by mosquitoes—there is no peace from them as the door has to be opened at all hours of the day and sometimes at night to attend to the needs of the Indians.

We could get along fairly well if one-half of the front of the teacher's cottage was screened with mosquito netting. The material, freight to Chehalis and labor would cost about $55.00. I am enclosing an estimate of the material required and the price quoted for same by Mr. A. S. Nichol of Agassiz.

I shall feel obliged if you'll kindly take this matter up with the Department at your early convenience.

SIR:

I am forwarding you herewith a letter received from Mr. J.W. Burns, teacher at the Chehalis Indian Day school, in which he requests that a porch may be placed across a portion of the cottage front, and screened with mosquito wire.

I can vouch from experience as to the Chehalis mosquitoes, and would most strongly recommend that if it is at all possible to do so, that this request be granted.

Life at Chehalis for the teacher and his wife, is at best a dismal affair, as it is totally isolated from white society, and anything to make their lot easier is only their due.

Attached also is an estimate of the cost, from A.S. Nichol, the local Hardware store etc. at Agassiz, and which shows that any amount of approximately $55.00, would cover these improvements.

Your obedient servant,

A.O.N. Daunt,

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

I have been informed by Captain G.H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools, that there is a possibility of a teacher being appointed to the Chehalis Indian Day School in the near future.

Chehalis Indian Day School,
Harrison Mills, B.C.
June 27th, 1942.

New Westminster Agency,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch:

I beg to request that the Department make every possible effort to supply the school equipment applied for in the attached requisitions.

There are at present only twelve suitable school desks in the school-room. The remainder are small, dilapidated double seated, old style desks which are very unsatisfactory.

I have needed, during the past six months, seating capacity for thirty-three pupils at one time. The indications are that the next school term will call for upwards of forty desks. The present school equipment is entirely inadequate for even half this number. It will therefore be necessary, under these conditions, to refuse entry to new pupils or to try to work under difficulties that will be almost impossible.

It is very desirable that provision be made for opportunity to teach different forms of hand-work in the grades. This would necessitate the construction of a work-shop. An addition to the present school building could be made and equipment installed; woodworking tools and supplies. The boys should be taught to handle tools and apply their dexterity in problems related to home life and community activities. Such instruction is needed perhaps more in Indian Schools than anywhere else. The girls should be taught spinning and related activities. All we need is space and equipment. I therefore urge that ways and means to securing these be considered. I will supply drawings for necessary buildings and do all possible towards improving educational facilities for the Indians here.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]
Teacher.
SIR:

I beg to forward you a Requisition for School Material received from Mr. F. S. Morrison, teacher at the Chehalis Indian Day School.

At the present time, and quite probably for the next three or four years, the Chehalis Indians have employment in various Logging operations within reach of the Reserve. This means that the families are living home, and school attendance high. As things are, therefore, Mr. Morrison has more pupils than the school desks adequately accommodate. He also has an opportunity to do good work in the manual training line.

In giving consideration to the matter, it should be remembered that just as soon as local employment slacks off, the Indians will follow their work, and school attendance will again drop to former levels.

I explained this to Mr. Morrison, but he is a new broom, and I think takes entire credit for the increased attendance.

There is no question that for the next two or three years, and possibly a little more, attendance at this school will warrant increased furniture and facilities; but I am quite sure that the Indians, trained loggers as they are, will follow work of this nature wherever it is to be found, rather than settle down upon the Reserve, when local logging operations cease. When they do so, the school attendance will drop sharply.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Encl. The Secretary, Indian Agent,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, July 8, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, enclosing requisition for school supplies for the Chehalis Indian Day School.

I am not exactly aware if you can obtain desks in British Columbia, but recently we had a request for equipment of this nature for a school in Ontario, and, on taking up the matter with the Purchasing Branch, it was found that it was necessary to obtain a priority, due to the fact that in the manufacture of school desks a certain amount of metal is used. Under the circumstances the Department decided not to supply the new desks for the Ontario school. In view of this decision, it is difficult for me to authorize new desks for the Chehalis School.

I have also noted your remarks regarding the possibility of the increased attendance at this school only lasting temporarily. Would it not be possible to make some other arrangements for seating the pupils for whom no desks are now available?

Re: Redecorating Chehalis School & Teacherage.

Attached are requisitions in duplicate covering materials required to redecorate the interior of both the Chehalis Day School, and the Teacherage.

The amount of $380.00 was placed in the 1948-49 estimates for repairs and shingling of Chehalis School, but on recent survey we concluded that this could be postponed for another year, and provided funds are available, we consider redecorating more important. Although we originally proposed to construct at the above mentioned Reserve a one-room school with teacherage, information received from District School Inspector Davey indicates that the present teacherage will accommodate two teachers and therefore construction should be confined to the erection of a classroom only.

Questionnaire completed by Supt. Gillett with regard to the site, method of construction, etc., is enclosed together with quotation from National All-Steel Buildings Limited on the erection of a Quonset building, 24 x 42, with full cement basement in accordance with their plan attached. W. S. Arneil,

In the Estimates for 1895-'96 from this office provision was made for three day schools in the Cowichan Agency, viz:- Songhees, Cowichan and Nanaimo. The Songhees school is under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church as during the past has been the school at Cowichan, or, as might be more particularly designated, Somenos. The school at Nanaimo had sometimes been carried on by the Church of England and sometimes by the Methodist Missionary Society; at present it is being conducted by the latter.

In view of the above His Lordship Bishop Lemmens feels aggrieved that the school at Somenos should have been handed over to the Methodists.

At the time that Mr. Tate's letter of June 28th, 1895 - sent to the Department under cover of official letter of July 5th, 1895, No. 20. O.2. - was received, the Somenos school, which had formerly been carried on by the Roman Catholic Church, was closed.

This appointment is of course subject to the approval of the Department, the moment it comes to a much-needed assistance by granting a subsidy in favor of the Cowichan day school. As my personal means are very limited, the appointment is of necessity but temporary. I may add that as a matter of fact, my firm belief that a Government grant will be forthcoming before the expiration of the present School term has encouraged me in making the appointment.

THE SECRETARY.

I beg to submit herewith a recommendation of Superintendent Vowell that the usual grant of $300 be allowed in the Roman Catholic day school near Quamichan, B.C.

In his report on this matter Indian Agent Lomas states that there is a good school building on the spot, it having been erected in 1883, when the last per capita grant was made. On or about July 1880 the grant was not paid, it not having been asked for, the Rev. Father Donckele and the nuns who were in charge having been removed to assume control of the Kuper Island Industrial School. For the last three years the school has not received any Government grant.

Mr. Lomas states that the average attendance is 25, and that this might be raised to 35 or 40 when all the Indian families are at home, the children attending this school coming from three villages, namely, Quamichan, Comeakin and Clemclemalets.

As the school in question is the only one at this point, and as all the Indians belong to the Roman Catholic Church, it would seem only fair that the grant to this school should be renewed.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo in connection with the Cowichan Indian Day School and the teacher Mr. J. P. Lejeune, and in reply I would say that we have great difficulty from the commencement of this school in getting the children to continually attend, although repeatedly both Dominion Constable O'Connell and myself have got all children in reach of the school to attend, it is found that they gradually drop off. In my experience with Indian Day Schools, the reason for this is that the teacher, possibly through ill health, does not have enough variety in his teaching so that the children want something outside of the ordinary routine of reading and writing which would create an interest. In other day schools in the Agency I find the children keen and anxious to attend, and should one be absent the teacher calls on the parents to see if the child is ill, etc., etc., thus the teacher wins the respect of the parents, but in the case of the school in question, Mr. Lejeune, say the same, although repeatedly I have tried to get Mr. Lejeune to take an interest in the parents as well as the pupils.

This school was built in the Spring of 1923 at the request of R.C. Missionaries and yet we see little interest taken by them. On the Reservation adjacent we have both Catholic and Protestant families which may in some way affect the attendance. It has been found at the Koksilah Indian Day School a few miles distant, a purely non-sectarian, that far better results prevail in spite of the fact that most of the pupils have a much greater distance to travel. I am firmly of the opinion that if the Cowichan Indian Day School was on the same lines better results would be assured.

It might be suggested by the Department that the school should be closed and the children sent to residential schools; against this I would point out that two-thirds of the pupils of the Koksilah and Cowichan Day Schools are unable to pass a Doctor.

Mr. Lejeune is in poor health but manages to attend regularly, but the situation is hopeless as it is.

Your obedient servant,

Miss Olive H. Anderton began duties as teacher of the Cowichan R. C. Indian Day School (Reserve No. 1, federal district of Nanaimo) on September first, last. In a letter dated the first instant, Mr. Agent Graham writes as follows:

"I have watched this school for some time. The discipline is by far the worst feature, and although this has been brought to Miss Anderton the teacher's attention, on more than one occasion, yet she does not seem to be able to rectify it.

"The class work is also in my opinion of a very low standard and the progress not what it should be. As there are a lot of children for this school, it is really too bad that we should have a weak teacher, where so much good work can be accomplished.

"I would like to recommend that a change of teachers be made at the end of this term, as I am sure that there must be lots of good Roman Catholic teachers available."

Mr. G. H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia, also recommends that the Department dispense with the services of Miss Anderton.

In view of the above reports from our officials, I would appreciate your concurrence in notifying Miss Anderton that her services will not be required after June 30th, 1934.

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

Miss Olive Anderton taught the Comeakin Indian day school for the last two years. Has a first class certificate and has attended summer school. Was told she would have to try and pull up the attendance and claims she did so. She was dismissed on notice dated June 15th to take effect on June 30th. She was given no reasons and on asking them was refused. If she did bad work the first year why was she retained, and if her second year's work was bad how was it known seeing that the last inspection of her school was in October last.

While working for the Indian Dept. she was subject to B.C. school laws and regulations, had to have a B.C. teacher's certificate etc. By B.C. School laws, when dismissed the reasons must be clearly stated in the notice. This was not done and on seeking them she was refused. When legally dismissed she has a right of appeal to an independent Board.

Further, notice of dismissal with reasons must be sent her at least 30 days before date of taking effect. This was not done and according to B.C. law the notice is invalid and she can return to the position for next term. You can ascertain the truth of above by phoning Dr. Willis, Supt. of Education from whom I received it.

Some one appears to have blundered and I suggest that the simplest way to clear the matter up is to either reinstate her in the school from which she has not been legally dismissed or provide her with another school as well situated as the Comeakin one.

The lady is entitled to the same treatment as any other B.C. teacher. Failing this I must take it up at once with Ottawa, but I trust that will not be necessary.

Yours faithfully,

"A.W. Neill."

Dear Capt. Barry:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 19th instant (No. 15/3/35193) in which you state that you consider that I have had "every consideration" shown me during the past two years.

In my letter of the 18th instant I asked you to please give me some satisfaction as to why I was dismissed from my school. You did not mention this at all in your reply. May I be so bold as to repeat the request?

As for the Department's consideration for me, do you think it is considerate of them to dismiss me without inspecting my work this year? If they considered dismissing me I think the least they could have done would have been to have you inspect my school this spring. They are apparently unaware of what I have accomplished this year as the only reports that have been made are those which Mr. Indian Agent Graham made after his monthly visits to the school, when he stayed generally less than five minutes. Obviously, he knew nothing of the accomplishments of the pupils. The last report received at Ottawa which bears on my teaching ability is yours of October 11th last. I think you will realize that this tells nothing of what I have done since then, or, for practically the whole of the present academic year. You ought to be able to see, then, that I have not been treated fairly.

I have put my heart and soul into this work, have secured the love and cooperation of the pupils, have gained their interest and the confidence of their parents. There are practically no disciplinary difficulties now and, as you know, discipline was the biggest problem when I undertook the school. The children now are willingly obedient. You gave me the school's most difficult years and now, when I have succeeded in getting the school into a workable condition you pass it on to someone else and give me absolutely no credit.

However, if the Department can show me that I have failed as a teacher or can give me any other valid reason for my dismissal then I shall be quite satisfied to make the best of it. But I do think refusal to give me a reason not only an insult but a suggestion that perhaps there is not a valid reason. I ask no more than fair play.

One reason for my persistence in this matter is the dire necessity for me to get employment. For the past two years I have been practically supporting my parents and a brother. My father has been unable to get work other than Government Relief for the past three years. His usual earnings
are from twenty to thirty dollars per month. Also, my mother has been an invalid for the past four years, bedridden for the past ten months and will probably be an invalid for the remainder of her life. Therefore, she needs good food and care. How we can procure her this on even thirty dollars a month is more than anyone knows.

If you are unable to help me in any other way, perhaps you could give me a recommendation so that I might be able to find another school for, as things stand now it will be almost impossible to do this. All School Boards insist on receiving copies of inspectors' reports with which, of course, I shall be unable to provide them.

I hope that I do not seem to you to be making trouble about nothing. To me this matter is of vital importance and I do want to be shown fair play.

I trust that you will consider my side in this matter and do something for me.

Respectfully yours,

"Olive H. Anderton."

Dear Miss Anderton:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, and may say that I have given it careful consideration.

Your best course, if you consider the actions of either Mr. Indian Agent Graham or myself to be unfair, is to write to the Secretary of the Department of Indian Affairs in Ottawa. As the Department has decided to terminate your services on the 30th of June next, you will understand that it is quite impossible for me to enter into any discussion on the matter.

Should you care to do so you might place the facts of the matter before the B.C. Teachers' Federation, by writing to the General Secretary, Mr. Harry Charlesworth. The address of the Federation is 1300 Robson Street, Vancouver, B.C. They sometimes act for teachers who do not belong to the B.C. Teachers' Federation.

I never give either copies of my reports, or letters of recommendation, to teachers seeking other appointments. In making application to Principals or Boards of School Trustees you may of course refer to me as your last inspector. On request from a Principal or Board of Trustees for confidential information, I am prepared to supply particulars with regard to teachers who have served in the Indian Schools of British Columbia, and I am of course prepared to do this in your case.

I regret that owing to pressure of work it was quite impossible for me to visit your school this Spring.

Your obedient servant,

"Gerald H. Barry."

General Remarks:

A proper Time Table is followed with care. The Junior Red Cross organization is operating in the school. The whole school is perfectly clean. There is no corporal punishment or any need for it. I am satisfied that Mr. Neary is doing his very best for these children. While the conduct of the children is very good, the fact is that Mr. Neary is a good teacher and finds matters of control very easy for this reason.

I understand that Mr. Neary wishes to attend the session of the University of British Columbia from the 1st of October 1936 to April 30th, 1937, that he may receive a degree in Arts. He has done the previous three years work by attendance at Victoria College and by Summer Schools and private reading.

I am also informed that the local Priest considers this a very suitable thing, and that the Catholic Church authorities will be prepared to nominate a SUBSTITUTE teacher for the months during which Mr. B. Neary is away from his school.

For the information of the Department, I may say that I have no objection to Mr. Neary taking his degree this next year provided a qualified substitute be placed in charge of the school. I do not think that the Catholic Church will have much difficulty in nominating a suitable substitute. I would therefore ask the Department to give favourable consideration to Mr. B. Neary's request if and when it is made in a proper manner through his Indian Agent. He certainly has worked hard here, and I think a final year at his University will be good for him in a professional, as well as in a physical way. His general health should certainly improve by a change for a few months from Indian surroundings to the atmosphere of the University, and I think it would do his nerves good.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of 6th inst no. 152-8-1 re unjust dismissal of Miss O. Anderton without explanation and without legal notice.

When it came to dismissing a teacher, surely that was the time if ever when the Inspector should have thoroughly inspected the school and her work.

Re lack of legal notice. No teacher in B.C can be dismissed without 30 days notice and moreover must be given reasons in writing and the teacher has...

Dear Sir:

Being Missionary to the Cowichan Indians, I am in charge of the Komiaken Indian Day School, which is under the auspices of the Catholic Church.

I would like to know, what are the rights and duties of a missionary who attends to a school which is under "the auspices of his Church".

There is one instance specially on which I would like to have informations. It is about the attendance of the children. Here many are not attending, or are attending very irregularly. Now what is the duty of the missionary and the teacher regarding those children. Is it enough for the teacher to show the register to the Agent, at his monthly visit, or is he obliged to call the attention of the Agent to the absence of a pupil after a certain number of days. If you would like more informations about the situation, I could give more details.

Re: Religious instruction at the Koksilah Day School. Answering my letter of the 8 Jan, Mr Phelan on the 13 Jan, 1936, sent me a copy of a letter to Rev. J. Welch, Ottawa, Sept 18, 1922, regulating the matter. Here again I would like to have a few informations. The letter says that "the school should be conducted along the undenominational lines." Is there any positive rules made by the Department regarding such schools, or are rules made for each case.

The actual teacher is having the Lord's prayer said, thus following what is done in the schools of the province. Is that according to the agreement. This matter was referred to the local Agent, who apparently could not reach any decision.

Re; admission of a child to Kuper School. Gaspard Elliot, child of a half-breed father and an indian mother, who were never legally married, was admitted to Kuper Island School, in April or May 1935. The Principal, not knowing the exact status of the child, referred the case to the Agent, who said the child...
would have to be dismissed. Meantime the child's father went to the school to claim the child. The Principal told him that the child was his and that he could take him at once. But the father refused to take him, saying that he would be back soon to get him. He never came for him and so the Principal sent the child to his mother. I was asked to take up the matter, by the mother who since a few years is the sole supporter of the child, being separated from her husband.

I spoke to the Agent about it who told me that the child could not be admitted to any Indian School, being a half-breed, and could not go to Kuper specially as it was against the will of his father. As to be admitted to an Indian School, I know that some of his cousins, Elliots and half-breeds also are attending the Chilliwack School. The Principal at Kuper Island is willing to accept the child, as long as a decision would be given by the Department. As I was told that it was by special request that the Elliots were admitted at Chilliwack, I make the same request for this child, and a sister of his who never attended school.

As to go against the will of his father, may I asked for a decision from the Department. The mother was allowed to have her children baptised as catholic. She is the only one looking after them now.

Assuring you of my good will to act according to any decision given by the Department, I would like to excuse myself for sending this letter to you. As I did not know who would have to study those questions, I thought the best was to send them all to you.

Obediently Yours,

Ottawa, October 7th, 1936.

Reverend Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 28th ultimo, I may inform you that, in official letter of August 31st, last, Mr. Agent Graham was advised that, if Gaspard Elliott is physically fit, the Department was prepared to approve his admission to the Kuper Island Indian Residential School. As yet, the Agent has not forwarded the application form but he is being written today and requested to do so at once.

The Department can see no objection to the teacher saying the Lord's Prayer at the opening of school each day. This can hardly be considered as religious instruction.

From information received from Mr. Graham and, also, Inspector Barry, the Department understands that, since last March, it has been arranged that you should have an hour from 3 to 4 P.M. each Tuesday for the religious instruction of the Catholic children attending this school. The Department understood that this arrangement met with your approval.

Yours truly,

PURPOSE OF SURVEY

The following survey with respect to the Indian Schools in the neighbourhood of Duncan was carried out in accordance with the instructions contained in Departmental Letter 132-8-6, dated April 27, 1937.

The purpose of the Survey was to show the location of all children, whether or not school age or not, in the Duncan area, to indicate which of these children were receiving education, and to determine the best type and location of Indian Day School suitable for children of school age in this area.

PROCEDURE ADOTTED.

During the period June 23rd to June 26th inclusive the field work of the Survey was carried out in and around Duncan.

The Cowichan Indian Day School was visited on June 23rd; the register carefully examined, and a note made of all children attending that school during the past year.

On June 24th a visit was paid to the Koksilah Indian Day School, where a list of all children attending that school, and of those at present under school age in this district was obtained from the teacher.

On June 25th the greater part of the day was spent in going through the Catholic Baptismal Register with Rev. Father Lemieux. The names of all children shown as R.C. in this Survey Report were obtained from the above Baptismal Register.

On Saturday, June 26th, and Monday, June 28th, the Census Books were consulted in the office of Indian Agent Mr. Graham.

The information covered as above is given on pages 3 to 10, and a Statistical Summary, which I hope may be of interest to the Indian Affairs Branch, is given on Page 11.

MAP.

The approximate location of places mentioned in this report is given on the attached map, which has a scale of 1000 ft. to one inch.

RELIGION OF CHILDREN

In many places in the foregoing list of children it will be noted that, while the original religion is given as Roman Catholic, some of the children in the family are shown as members of the United Church of Canada, and in several cases, where children have returned from the Alberni Indian Residential School to a local Indian Day School, it will be noted that they are again being considered as Roman Catholics, and receiving religious instruction from the local Catholic priest as such.

I particularly wish to bring to the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch the following extraordinary situation which has arisen in the Cowichan Agency.

As will be seen from the study of the Statistical Analysis of the Child Population as given in this Report, out of the total of 279 children 244 are Roman Catholics now, 26 United Church now, and 9 doubtful. Of the 26 who are now United Church the overwhelming majority were previously Roman Catholic.

It appears that when Roman Catholic parents wish to send their Roman Catholic children to an Indian Residential School there is no religious accommodation available at Kuper Island. The following practice has then been followed. The children in question were received into the United Church to permit of their being called Protestants, and were then sent to either the Alberni Indian Residential School or to Coqualeetza Indian Residential School as members of the United Church of Canada. It will be seen from the lists given in an earlier part of this report that the other members of the family, including the younger children, have remained Roman Catholic, and with these so-called United Church children have, for one reason or another, returned from the Residential Schools to the Indian Day Schools, they have, in the majority of cases, reverted to their original Roman Catholic church affiliation. They have, of course, always been considered as Roman Catholics by the authorities of that church, and I have satisfied myself that their names appear on the Baptismal Register of the Roman Catholic Church along with those of their brothers and sisters.

It would appear that the practice reported above has been followed in order to circumvent the strict regulations of the Indian Affairs Branch with reference to the admission of Catholic children to a Protestant Indian Residential School, and I would certainly recommend that the necessary steps be taken to put an end to the above practice.

NECESSITY FOR MORE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL ACCOMMODATION.

From a study of the Statistical Analysis of Child Population in the Duncan area it would appear that there are some 166 children of school age and 92 children under school age. Of the above number 30 are at present attending Indian Residential Schools, 13 being at Coqualeetza and 17 at Kuper Island.

Seventy-one children are, or have been, attending day schools, 39 going to the Cowichan Indian Day School, and 32 to the Koksilah Indian Day School. Sixty-five children of school age do not appear to be receiving instruction in any schooling whatsoever. 40% of the school population is not
ESTABLISHMENT OF A CONSOLIDATED IMPROVED INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

When the 39 children at present attending the Cowichan Indian Day School, and the 65 children of school age not at present attending any school, are taken into consideration it would appear that an improved Indian Day School to accommodate some 100 children is required.

It further appears that, as practically all these children belong to the Roman Catholic Church, the proposed Consolidated Day School should be administered under Catholic auspices.

It will be understood, of course, that some form of transportation to and from school daily will be required for the majority of the children. This matter is discussed on another page of this report.

(a) Location of Proposed School.

After an examination of various possible sites for a school it would appear that the best available is at a point on the South Trunk Road, adjoining the block at present owned by the Catholic Church.

The actual site which I considered the most suitable would include some 4 or 5 acres at present part of the Cowichan Indian Reserve and owned by Mrs. Sammy Bob. This site is about 2½ miles from Duncan, and about ½ mile from the Cowichan Catholic Rectory and the Convent Boys' Residential School, administered by the Sisters of St. Anne. The actual land suggested for school purposes is more or less level, and at least 4 or 5 acres would be necessary to provide for a playing field and a large school garden of at least an acre, where the majority of fruit and vegetables used in the school dining room would be grown. It is not suggested that the boys attending this proposed school should engage in farming operations but it is suggested that part of their regular vocational training should consist of instructions in the care of a large garden.

There is a satisfactory well on the Catholic property adjoining the site of the proposed school, and from an examination of the slope of the land, etc., it is considered that it would not be difficult to find a sufficient water supply by sinking a well to bed rock.

(b) Suggested Accommodation.

To provide suitable vocational facilities for the children of this area it would be necessary to have one Primary Division working on an All Day Plan, a Girls' Division, and a Boys' Division.

The girls and boys might well be given academic instructions on the Half Day Plan, in which the girls' classroom would be used for the junior girls in the morning and the senior girls in the afternoon, while in the boys' classroom the senior boys would receive academic instruction in the morning and the junior boys in the afternoon.
Suggested Accommodation (continued)

During the morning session while the junior girls are working in the classroom the senior girls would receive vocational instruction including practical work in Arts and Crafts. Some of these girls in turn would be responsible for the preparation of the mid-day meal provided for all children attending the school. In the afternoon when the senior girls are in the classroom, the junior girls might well receive suitable vocational instruction.

During the morning session while the senior boys are in the classroom the junior boys should be instructed in manual training, work in the garden, etc. Similar work, but of a more advanced nature, should be undertaken by the senior boys in the afternoon while the junior boys are in the classroom.

(c) Necessary Accommodation

To carry out a plan such as suggested in this report four classrooms would be necessary, one to accommodate the Primary Division, one for the girls, one for the boys, and one for girls' work in Arts and Crafts, including sewing, wool work, basket making, etc. A boys' manual training shop might well be established in the basement which would, no doubt, also accommodate the necessary kitchen. A large room which might be used for the dual purpose of an Assembly Hall and dining room would also be required, together with store room, boys' and girls' wash rooms, and toilet accommodation. No dormitory accommodation would be necessary.

This is only intended to be a rough outline of the accommodation which would be required, as it is not considered necessary to go into detail at the present time. Bathrooms would also be required.

(d) Staff.

Three regular teachers would be required for classroom work, a male teacher being employed in the Boys' Division. A qualified manual training instructor who could also supervise gardening operations, a kitchen supervisor, and an instructress in Arts and Crafts for the girls would also be required. With a school of this size a part-time principal would be necessary.

The suggested location of the school is unique in that the local Catholic missionary priest could no doubt act as part-time principal, and, with the exception of the two male members of the staff, all the other positions might well be filled by Sisters of St. Anne, living accommodation for whom is, I understand, available at the nearby Convent.

TRANSPORTATION

From the information given on pages 1 to 9 inclusive, and the study of the attached map, it will be clear that the odd pupils available for this school are distributed roughly in a circle nearly 10 miles in circumference, which includes Duncan, Koksilah, Clem-Clem-Alits, the Stone Church, Knipsen, and the Trunk Road between Duncan and the present Cowichan Indian Day School.
TRANSPORTATION (continued)

To gather these children daily for school a large covered bus would leave Duncan and travel around the circle via Koksilah, Clem-Clem-Alita, the Stone Church, and Knipsen, to the proposed school. The return journey after school would, of course, be made in the opposite direction. The cost of this transportation in an approved and insured bus, such as that used by the Duncan Consolidated School Board for the transportation of Provincial school children, would be in the neighbourhood, though not exceeding, $150.00 per month, or $1500.00 per school year.

Such a service would be absolutely necessary for a Consolidated Improved Day School to be established in this area.

FUTURE OF THE PRESENT DAY SCHOOLS IN THE DUNCAN AREA.

There are at present in the Duncan School area two Indian Day Schools, the Cowichan Indian Day School and the Koksilah Indian Day School.

These schools provide for approximately 40% of the 166 children of school age in this area.

The Cowichan Indian Day School, administered under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church would be absorbed by the proposed Consolidated School. This school at present costs in the neighbourhood of $1000.00 per year.

The Koksilah Indian Day School, unlike any other Indian Day School in the Province, can hardly be said to be operated under the auspices of any one church. It is located in a United Church mission field, but the majority of the pupils attending the school are members of the Roman Catholic Church. The school building is of considerable age, and is not of very great value. The approach to the Koksilah Indian Day School is through United Church property, which, I understand, may possibly be sold in the near future.

A survey has, I understand, recently been made on instructions from the Surveyor General's Branch, and with the co-operation of Mr. Indian Agent Graham. I am informed by Mr. Graham that it will be necessary to construct a new approach to the Koksilah Indian Day School, and that this will involve road making, bridge building, and the possible purchase of road allowance from the local Indians. I further understand that the total cost of the above will be in the neighbourhood of $2000.00.

Should the Indian Affairs Branch decide to undertake the installing of an Improved Indian Day School on the location suggested in this Survey, very few children, and those of course belonging to the United Church of Canada, would remain as pupils of the present Koksilah Indian Day School.
DUNCAN SCHOOL SURVEY

FUTURE OF PRESENT DAY SCHOOLS IN THE DUNCAN AREA. (continued)

In my opinion it would not be worth while to continue this Day School in its present location, and I would most strongly advise that no money whatever be spent on road making, bridge building, or on the construction of a new approach to this school.

If it is considered that a small Indian Day School, working under the auspices of the United Church of Canada, is necessary to care for the children in the Cowichan area attending to that church, I would suggest that such a school be located on the Cowichan No. 1 Indian Reserve in Duncan where the majority of these children live. It must be remembered that a number of these United Church children could be accommodated at Coqualeetza Indian Residential School were it decided to discontinue the present Koksilah Indian Day School.

Right Reverend Sir:

This Branch has received your letter of January 31 also your letter of February 18 in which you point out the necessity for providing increased school accommodation for the Catholic Indian children of the Cowichan Indian Agency.

I am enclosing a very carefully compiled report of the number of Catholic children of school age and under now living in the Cowichan District. The official report of the Inspector will bear out the facts as here set forth in detail. The state of affairs is now so alarming in regard to school accommodation that it is imperative that some action be taken at the earliest possible date. Wuper Residential School is filled and there is accommodation for only 30 of the 124 Catholic children of this district. The inevitable result is that the balance are either not attending school at all or else contrary to the provisions of the Indian Act and also contrary to the admitted policy of the department are attending Protestant schools. The Koksilah Day School is not a Catholic school yet at present there are only 8 United Church pupils there the other 19 being Catholics! Since the department allowed some grant for transportation purposes there has been a very marked improvement in regard to attendance but absolute lack of accommodation has only one remedy and that is a new day school. I therefore respectfully request that the whole situation be studied with a view to immediate action before the Indian children get completely estranged from the very idea of school.
