Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to the last paragraph of Departmental letter 152-33-1 dated March 17 last, and your reply #15/3/2777 dated April 2, I may say that I have given considerable thought to the provision of proper educational facilities for the Catholic children in the Duncan area of the Cowichan Agency. In this connection I may say that I have spent several days in Duncan recently. I had several long conferences with the Reverend Father Louzon, and with him and Mr. Conroy, teacher of the Cowichan Indian Day School, made a very thorough inspection of the ground adjacent to the present Cowichan Day School, and of the area suggested in my Duncan School Survey, Page 14, Paragraph A, suggested as the location for a Consolidated School.

I would ask you to consider the matters referred to in this letter in connection with my Survey of the schools of the Duncan area forwarded to you on July 8th, 1937. The following paragraphs are therefore arranged in the order of the former Survey.

The various lists of children as given in my Survey, Pages two to ten inclusive, with summaries on Pages eleven, twelve and thirteen is still to be considered as correct though the children are, of course, one year older.

As practically all the children belong to the Roman Catholic Church, I still consider that the proposed Consolidated Day School should be administered under definite Catholic auspices.

LOCATION OF PROPOSED SCHOOL

Should the proposed Consolidated School be erected on ground adjoining the site of the present Cowichan Indian Day School, I would suggest that extra land be acquired from James Connel (Indian). The extra land required should have a frontage of some 110 yards S.E. along the road from the Cowichan Indian School ground and some 50 yards N.W. of the school grounds. The depth of the completed block would have to be at least 100 yards to give anything like adequate room for the erection of a large Consolidated School with playground and garden facilities.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6387, File 807-1, part 2)
This site was visited by Mr. Hoey and yourself in company with Rev. Father Lauzon last June, but I do not think you made any careful examination of the ground.

I find that only about one acre would have sufficient depth of soil for growing purposes, most of the land being extremely rocky. The basement of the school, if such were constructed here, would of necessity be above ground level to avoid rock excavation. There would be some difficulty with regard to the construction of a septic tank. I would point out however, that the worst feature in regard to this site is the almost total lack of a water supply. It is true that there is a good surface well near the present Cowichan Day School but this well dries up in the Fall, and would be entirely inadequate to supply the domestic water needs of a large school. Though I examined the ground with some care, I could not discover any place where we might expect to find water.

I am therefore of opinion that the Consolidated school should be placed on the block of four or five acres, part of the Cowichan Indian reserve now owned by Mrs. Benny Bob. This site was described on Page fourteen of my Survey. The land would appear to be very suitable for playground and garden requirements. Most of it has been cleared and under crop at some time. I am glad to say that there is little doubt that water could be obtained in good quantity by sinking a well some twenty-five feet to thirty feet. Local residents consider that there would be little difficulty whatever in obtaining a good supply of water both for domestic use and garden requirements.

**NOMINARY SCHOOL ACCOMMODATION**

With regard to accommodation necessary in the Proposed Consolidated School, I may say that after considerable discussion with Father Lauzon, I would recommend that provision be made for the following:

- A stone school building with basement (above ground) of some 90 ft. by 60 ft., and with an extension of about 24 ft. by 20 ft. to the rear of the school. The basement might well include a large hall at least 65 ft. by 40 ft. and 17 ft. high with folding doors so that it could be used either for basketball and gymnasium or as separate boys and girls play rooms.
- A kitchen of about 24 ft. by 30 ft., a room for the storage of food materials and vegetables and fruit canned at the school.
- A manual training shop 30 ft. by 24 ft. Main stairs and a road of about 20 ft. by 13 ft. for resident manual training and gardening.
- Provision would of course be made for a furnace connected with the hot water heating of the school and baths on boys and girls sides.

On the first floor there might well be a class room for girls on one side, and for boys on the other, each about 24 ft. by 30 ft., a room for the Sisters who would act as teachers, a vocational room, an office for the part time principal of the school, a dormitory that is a class room of some 24 ft. by 30 ft. There should also be provision for a bathroom and toilet adjoining the Sister's room, and a similar bathroom and toilet on the boys side adjoining the vocational class room.
I would modify the suggestions made on Page 15 of my School Survey and suggest that the staff of the school should be composed of a part time principal who would no doubt be the Catholic Missionary Priest, three Sisters of St. Anne from the nearby convent, one of whom would be in charge of an all day primary class, a second in charge of senior and junior girls, who would work on a modified half-day system as explained below, and the third to supervise preparation of noon day meals in the school kitchen, the preservation of fruit and vegetables from the school garden, and instruction in sewing and other Arts and Crafts on the girls' side. Two male teachers would be necessary, one to take charge of the senior and junior boys working on the modified half-day system explained below, and one to act as caretaker, manual training instructor and gardening instructor. This man might also drive the school bus recommended later in this report.

MODIFIED HALF-DAY SYSTEM

The primary class will be in school all day. The other remaining children will receive academic and vocational training as tabulated below:

| Time       | Girls          | Boys          |
|------------|----------------|---------------|
| 9 A.M. to 10 A.M. | Senior & Junior academic | Senior & Junior academic |
| 10 A.M. to 11 A.M. | Senior, A.     | V.            |
| 11 A.M. to 12 A.M. | V.             | A.            |
| 1 P.M. to 2 P.M.   | A.             | V.            |
| 2 P.M. to 3 P.M.   | V.             | A.            |
| 3 P.M. to 4 P.M.   | V.             | A.            |

HEATING

I believe that the best form of heating for the proposed Consolidated school would be by hot water radiators. The furnace in connection with this system of heating either be arranged to burn wood or oil, though I am of opinion that oil is preferable. I do not consider the system of heating would be satisfactory, and would say that it is almost essential that no large hot air ducts be erected in the basement halls as such pipes would interfere with basketball.

SEPTIC TANK

A septic tank will of course be required in connection with the proposed school, and I recommend the Survey Report recommendation. There should be no difficulty whatever in the excavation of a suitable septic tank site, but it may be most difficult to arrange for one on the Cowichan Capel near the present Cowichan Indian Reserve.
LIGHT

The light lines of the Namaimo and Duncan Utilities Company are located along the road frontage past the suggested site of the new school on the property at present owned by Mrs. Sammy Bob, but stop about 400 yards short of James Capael's property.

TRANSPORTATION

As explained in my School Survey Report, pages fifteen and sixteen, the hundred odd pupils available for this school are distributed roughly in a circle some ten miles in circumference as shown on the map previously forwarded to the Department.

It will of course, be necessary to have a large covered bus to collect these children daily for school and to return them to their homes in the late afternoon. As pointed out by Mr. Hoey, the success of such a Consolidated Indian Day School as I have suggested would depend entirely on the successful operation of the school bus.

In my Report, I suggested that the cost of an approved insured bus such as that owned by the Duncan Consolidated School Board for the transportation of provincial school children would be in the neighborhood of $1500.00 per school year.

I understand that owing to the increase in the cost of materials, it might now be possible to arrange for transportation at $1500.00 per academic year, that the cost would be more likely to be in the neighborhood of $1750.00.

I am inclined to think that it might be wiser to purchase a suitable bus and permit the school authorities to operate the same. Such a plan would probably mean that one of the male members of the staff for preference the manual training instructor mentioned below, would operate the bus each morning before school and afternoon at the close of the day's work.

Even when capital expenditure, operating expenses, insurance and licence fees are taken into account, it is probable that such a private school bus might be for some $1500.00 per annum or less than the cost to the Department of one from a Transportation Company.

SALARIES

As explained above, it will be necessary to pay a school principal apart from the teaching staff. Such might well be the local missionary Catholic priest. It may be necessary to pay this man a full time salary and that such a sum of $50.00 per month or $600.00 per annum is reasonable. Each of the Sisters of St. Anne would be in the neighborhood of $60.00 per teaching month, four classroom teachers and one supervisor a total of $2400.00 per year. The male teacher of the boys would expect a compensation with that paid to the qualified male providing similar work. This would amount to approximately $800.00 per month or $1000.00 per academic year. The man employed as manual training instructor, caretaker, gardener and driver of the school bus would no doubt expect $1000.00 per annum.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6387, File 807-1, part 2)
FINANCIAL

The probable cost to the Department of a block of six acres of land at present owned by Mrs. Sammy Bob, would be in the neighborhood of $600.00.

Such a school as I have suggested above might be expected to cost in the neighborhood of $30,000.00 but this is of course, only an approximate estimate. The cost of noon meals, sinking of a well, and operation of a water supply, and garden must be taken into consideration. As outlined above, operating costs of the school would be between $6,000.00 and $7,000.00 per year.

It will be seen from the above approximate figures that the erection of an improved Consolidated Indian Day School in the Duncan area of the Cowichan Agency would involve a considerable annual operating expenditure in addition to a considerable capital outlay.

RECOMMENDATION

It would appear to me that the Department might find considerable difficulty in obtaining the necessary funds for the erection of a Consolidated Improved Day School in the Duncan area. It seems to me that the Superintendent of Training and Welfare would be justified in asking for such a large appropriation when the needs of other parts of the Province are taken into consideration. If this is so, and the decision against the erection of a school as I have described in the near future be arrived at, I should be glad to be so informed. If instructed to do so, I shall make my next routine visit to Duncan, again examine the situation, and consider the idea of the erection of a one room Indian Day School itself, and another at Clowhomluts, and another at the Trunk Road. (See page 11 of my Survey Report accompanying map).

The above is submitted with respect and in the hope of assistance to the Department.

Yours very truly,

Gerald N. Barry
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Dear Sir:

Your File 152-22-1

I have received your letter of September 6th regarding the proposed consolidated school for the Duncan area of the Cowichan Agency. In this connection, I am forwarding herewith a copy of a further report from Capt. G.H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C., in which most of the information requested in your letter of the 6th instant is given.

Provision is made in the basement of the proposed school for accommodation for a resident Manual Training Instructor and Gardener, who also could probably act as janitor. It would not be necessary to provide living quarters for the staff composed of three Sisters of St. Ann from the nearby convent, the local Catholic Priest as part-time Principal, and two male teachers who could arrange for board and lodging either at the local mission house or in the nearby village.

Capt. Barry estimates the cost of the proposed school at $30,000, with an annual operating cost of approximately $7000.

The present Cowichan Day School building could be used in connection with the manufacture of Cowichan sweaters, and other woolen articles, under the supervision of the school, or used to advantage as a community hall. If we are to endeavor to centralize the sweater making industry in the Duncan and Koksilah sections of the Cowichan Agency, I consider it should be in a small building apart from the main school, but under the direct supervision of a member of the school staff at least during the experimental stage. A start could be made in a small way, and the operation extended should conditions warrant.

The Protestant children available to attend school in the area, should attend the Koksilah Day School and continue to do so until such time as arrangements, as suggested by Capt. Barry in the penultimate paragraph of the Duncan School survey, could be made.

The advantages of a consolidated school, such as is proposed in this case, would be:

(1) A graded school, as against 2 or 3 ungraded schools.
(2) Better facilities for vocational training, manual training and school gardens.
(3) The children would receive a midday meal.

I would recommend that the Department proceed with arrangements for the construction in the Duncan area of an improved consolidated Day School along the lines suggested by Inspector Barry, when funds are available. Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to the last paragraph of Departmental letter 152-23-1 dated March 17 last, and your reply #15/3/3777 dated April 2, I may say that I have given considerable thought to the provision of proper educational facilities for the Catholic children in the Duncan area of the Cowichan Agency. As you may say that I have spent several days in Duncan recently, I have several long conferences with the Reverend Father Lauzon, and with him and Mr. Conway, teacher of the Cowichan Indian Day School, made a very thorough inspection of the ground adjacent to the present Indian Day School, and of the area suggested in my Duncan School Survey, Page 14, Paragraph A, suggested as the location for a Consolidated School.

I would ask you to consider the matters referred to in this letter in connection with my Survey of the schools of the Duncan area forwarded to you on July 8th, 1937. The following paragraphs are therefore arranged in the order of the former Survey.

The various lists of children as given in my Survey, Pages two to ten inclusive, with summaries on Pages eleven, twelve and thirteen is still to be considered as correct though the children are, of course, one year older.

As practically all the children belong to the Roman Catholic Church, I still consider that the proposed Consolidated Day School should be administered under definite Catholic auspices.

LOCATION OF PROPOSED SCHOOL

Should the proposed Consolidated School be erected on ground adjoining the site of the present Cowichan Indian Day School, I would suggest that extra land be acquired from James Capeel (Indian). The extra land required should have a frontage of some 110 yards S.E. along the road from the Cowichan Indian School ground and some 50 yards N.W. of the school ground. The depth of the completed block would have to be at least 100 yards to give anything like adequate room for the erection of a large Consolidated School with playground and garden facilities.
This site was visited by Mr. Hoey and yourself in company with Rev. Father Lauzon last June, but I do not think you made any careful examination of the ground.

I find that only about one acre would have sufficient depth of soil for growing purposes, most of the land being extremely rocky. The basement of the school, if such were constructed here, would of necessity be above ground level. It would look exceedingly well. There would be some difficulty with regard to the construction of a septic tank. I would point out however, that the worst feature in regard to this site is the almost total lack of a water supply. It is true that there is a small surface well near the present Cowichan Day School but this well dries up in the Fall, and would be entirely inadequate to supply the domestic water needs of a large school. Though I examined the ground with some care, I could not discover any place where we might expect to find water.

I am therefore of opinion that the Consolidated School should be placed on the block of four or five acres, part of the Cowichan Indian Reserve now owed by Mrs. Sammy Bob. This site was described on Page fourteen of my Survey. The land would appear to be very suitable for playground and garden requirements. Most of it has been cleared and under crop at some time. I am glad to say that there is little doubt that water could be obtained in good quantity by sinking a well some twenty-five feet or thirty feet. Local residents consider that there would be little difficulty whatever in obtaining a good supply of water both for domestic use and garden requirements.

NECESSARY SCHOOL ACCOMMODATION

With regard to accommodation necessary in the proposed Consolidated School, I may say that after considerable discussion with Father Lauzon, I would recommend that provision be made for the following:

A one storey school building with basement (above ground) of some 90 ft. by 60 ft., and with an extension of about 24 ft. by 20 ft. to the rear of the school. The basement might well include a large hall at least 85 ft. by 40 ft. and 17 ft. high with folding doors so that it could be used either for basketball and gymnasium or as separate boys and girls play rooms.

A kitchen of about 24 ft. by 20 ft., a room for the storage of food materials and vegetables and fruit canned at the school.

A manual training shop 20 ft. by 24 ft. Main stairs and a room of about 20 ft. by 12 ft. for resident manual training instructor and gardener.

Provision, would of course be made for a furnace in connection with the hot water heating of the school and toilets on boys and girls sides.

On the first floor there might well be a class room for girls on one side, and for boys on the other, each about 24 ft. by 30 ft., a room for the Sisters who would act as teachers, a vocational room, an office for the part time principal of the school, and a large primary class room of some 24 ft. by 20 ft. There should also be provision for a bathroom and toilet adjoining the Sister's room, and a similar bathroom and toilet on the boys side adjoining the vocational class room.
STAFF

I would modify the suggestions made on Page 15 of my School Survey and suggest that the staff of the school should be composed of a part time principal who would no doubt be the Catholic Missionary Priest, three Sisters of St. Anne from the nearby convent, one of whom would be in charge of an all day primary class, a second in charge of senior and junior girls, who would work on a modified half-day system as explained below, and the third to supervise preparation of noon day meals in the school kitchen, the preservation of fruit and vegetables from the school garden, and instruction in sewing and other Arts and Crafts on the girls side. Two male teachers would be necessary, one to take charge of the senior and junior boys working on the modified half-day system explained below, and one to act as caretaker, manual training instructor and gardening instructor. This man might also drive the school bus recommended later in this report.

MODIFIED HALF-DAY SYSTEM

The primary class will be in school all day. The other remaining children will receive academic and vocational training as tabulated below:

HEATING

I believe that the best form of heating for the proposed Consolidated school would be by hot water radiators. The furnace in connection with this system of heating might either be arranged to burn wood or oil, though the latter in my opinion is preferable. I do not consider that a hot air system of heating would be satisfactory, and would point out that it is almost essential that no large hot air pipes be erected in the basement halls as such pipes would interfere with basketball.

SEPTIC TANK

A septic tank will of course be necessary in connection with the proposed school, if the location which I recommended in my Survey Report be chosen for the school. There should be no difficulty whatever with regard to the excavation of a suitable septic tank. Such a tank would be most difficult to arrange for on the property owned by James Capael near the present Cowichan Indian Day School.
LIGHT

The light lines of the Nanaimo and Duncan Utilities Company are located along the road frontage past the suggested site of the new school on the property at present owned by Mrs. Sammy Bob, but stop about 400 yards short of James Capel's property.

TRANSPORTATION

As explained in my School Survey Report, pages fifteen and sixteen, the hundred odd pupils available for this school are distributed roughly in a circle some ten miles in circumference as shown on the map previously forwarded to the Department.

It will of course, be necessary to have a large covered bus to collect these children daily for school and to return them to their homes in the late afternoon. As pointed out by Mr. Hoey, the success of such a Consolidated Indian Day School as I have suggested would depend entirely on the successful operation of the school bus.

In my Report, I suggested that the cost of an approved and insured bus such as that owned by the Duncan Consolidated School Board for the transportation of provincial school children would be in the neighborhood of $1500.00 per school year.

I understand that owing to the increase in the cost of materials, it might now be possible to arrange for transportation at $1500.00 per academic year, that the cost would be more likely to be in the neighborhood of $1750.00.

I am inclined to think that it might be wiser to purchase a suitable bus and permit the school authorities to operate this. Such a plan would probably mean that one of the male members of the staff for preference the manual training instructor mentioned below, would operate the bus each morning before school and each afternoon at the close of the day's work.

Even when capital expenditure, operating expenses, insurance and licence fees are taken into account, it is probable that such a private school bus might be for some $1500.00 operated per annum or less than the cost to the Department of one hired from a Transportation Company.

SALARIES

As explained above, it will be necessary to have a school principal apart from the teaching staff. Such a principal might well be the local missionary Catholic priest. It would not be necessary to pay this man a full time salary and I would suggest that such a sum of $50.00 per month or $600.00 per annum would be reasonable. Each of the Sisters of St. Anne would no doubt expect in the neighborhood of $600.00 per teaching month or for the two class room teachers and one supervisor a total of $1800.00 per year. The male teacher for the boys would expect a salary in accordance with that paid to the qualified male provincial teachers doing similar work. This would amount to approximately $100.00 per month or $1000.00 per academic year. The man selected as manual training instructor, caretaker, gardener and possibly operator of the school bus would no doubt expect $100.00 per calendar month or $1200.00 per annum.

The salaries would therefore amount to a sum of approximately $4600.00 per annum.
FINANCIAL

The probable cost to the Department of a block of six acres of the land at present owned by Mrs. Sammy Bob, would be in the neighborhood of $600.00.

Such a school as I have suggested above might be expected to cost in the neighborhood of $30,000.00 but this is of course, only an approximate estimate. The cost of noon meals, sinking of a well, and operation of a water supply, and garden must be taken into consideration. As outlined above, operating costs of the school would be between $6,000.00 and $7,000.00 per year.

It will be seen from the above approximate figures that the erection of an improved Consolidated Indian Day School in the Duncan area of the Cowichan Agency would involve a considerable annual operating expenditure in addition to a considerable capital outlay.

RECOMMENDATION

It would appear to me that the Department might find considerable difficulty in obtaining the necessary funds for the erection of Consolidated Improved Day School in the Duncan area. It might be that the Superintendent of Training and Welfare would not feel justified in asking for such a large appropriation when the needs of other parts of the Province are taken into consideration. If this is so, and the decision against the erection of any such school as I have described in the near future be arrived at, I should be glad to be so informed. If instructed to do so, I should on my next routine visit to Duncan, again examine the ground with the idea of the erection of a one room Indian Day School at Duncan itself, and another at Clemoelmelts, and possibly one on the Trunk Road, (see page 11 of my Survey Report and accompanying map).

The above is submitted with respect and in the hope that it may be of assistance to the Department.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Gerald H. Barry
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Enc.
Sept. 21, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of September 6th regarding the proposed consolidated school for the Duncan area of the Cowichan Agency. In this connection, I am forwarding herewith a copy of a further report from Capt. G.H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C., in which most of the information requested in your letter of the 6th instant is given.

Provision is made in the basement of the proposed school for accommodation for a resident Manual Training Instructor and Gardener, who also could probably act as janitor. It would not be necessary to provide living quarters for the staff composed of three Sisters of St. Ann from the nearby convent, the local Catholic Priest as part-time Principal, and two male teachers who could arrange for board and lodging either at the local Mission house or in the nearby village.

Capt. Barry estimates the cost of the proposed school at $30,000, with an annual operating cost of approximately $7000.

The present Cowichan Day School building could be used in connection with the manufacture of Cowichan sweaters, and other woolen articles, under the supervision of the school, or used to advantage as a community hall. If we are to endeavor to centralize the sweater making industry in the Duncan and Koksilah sections of the Cowichan Agency, I consider it should be in a small building apart from the main school, but under the direct supervision of a member of the school staff, at least during the experimental stage. A start could be made in a small way, and the operation extended should conditions warrant.

The Protestant children available to attend school in the area, should attend the Koksilah Day School and continue to do so until such time as arrangements, as suggested by Capt. Barry in the penultimate paragraph of the Duncan School survey, could be made.

The advantages of a consolidated school, such as is proposed in this case, would be:

(1) A graded school, as against 2 or 3 ungraded schools.

(2) Better facilities for vocational training, manual training and school gardens.

(3) The children would receive a midday meal.

Re: Cowichan Agency Consolidated School

Dear Major MacKay:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 21st ultimo and also a report relating to the above noted subject, received by you from Inspector Barry, attached thereto.

This report, dated July 16, 1938, together with Inspector Barry's report dated March 17, last, enables us to grasp very easily the existing conditions and the educational needs of the Duncan area.

I naturally hesitate to comment upon the proposals and recommendations submitted to the Department by men who are thoroughly familiar with local conditions and who have made a very thorough inspection of the district. I should state, however, that it is not at all likely that I can secure an appropriation of $30,000 for the construction of a consolidated school in the Duncan area this year. We had a somewhat unfortunate experience in the construction of the Port Simpson school. It would appear that when we depart from the construction of one or two room schools the cost seems out of proportion.

What I really had in mind with respect to the Duncan area was a square four room school with full basement accommodation. This basement, in my judgment, should be approximately two thirds underground, thoroughly lighted and equipped for vocational instruction and the necessary facilities for providing, not a noonday meal, but a noonday lunch. This lunch should consist of biscuits, supplied by the Department; broth or soup and any additional supplies the pupils might care to bring with them from their homes. I dislike the thought of providing living accommodation for any member of the staff in the school. If such living accommodation is really necessary, we might, later, convert a cottage on the school grounds, in which the caretaker or the manual instructor could live. Is a septic tank really necessary? I am sending forward, under separate cover, pamphlet dealing with a comparatively inexpensive set-up that might be suitable at the consolidated school.

I have learned from experience that worthwhile vocational instruction - boat building, auto mechanics, hand loom weaving, etc. - is inseparable from a certain amount of vibration, hence the desirability of making provision for this instruction in the basement of the building. If the land on which the school is to be established is of rock formation, may I suggest that consideration be given to the construction of the school as such and the construction of an additional -

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P. O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B. C.
an additional building for vocational studies.

I am personally in favour of securing the five acres owned by Mrs. Sammy Bob, referred to in Inspector Barry's report. I would have to be assured, however, that there was an adequate supply of water at this site, and I should like to have, also, an expression of opinion from you with respect to the removal of the present day school to the new site. I was very much impressed by the suggestion you made in conversation to me with respect to the desirability of combining educational effort and vocational effort, particularly the production of Cowichan sweaters. I am anxious to know therefore, if it would be practical to move the day school or if it is close enough on the present site to permit its use for vocational work (sweater production).

I have intimated that the new school should have full basement accommodation. Upstairs there should be a main hallway running from the front to the back. On the left there should be two classrooms, separated by folding doors. This would enable these classrooms to be used as an auditorium for meetings of Indian parents, adult education, the display of pictures, etc. On the right hand side we might have two smaller rooms and perhaps a principal's room or principal's office. I have been informed that in eastern cities school boards are providing good size classrooms with full basement accommodation for less than $5,000 per room. In view of this fact, I think we should be able to construct the school at Duncan for a cost not exceeding $20,000.

This school, when completed, should be placed in charge of fully qualified, up to date teachers. Such teachers, I feel confident, can be supplied by the Sisters of St. Anne if they are anxious to assume this responsibility. There is no need whatever, in my judgment, for a Principal other than the Sister Superior, in charge. Our experience at the Qu'Appelle Day School, where we have an enrolment of 334 with the Sisters of St. Anne in charge, has been very satisfactory. To have a clergyman nominally in control, as Inspector Barry suggests, might in my judgment lead to friction and to certain misunderstandings. However, this is a mere detail of administration that can be given consideration later.

Are there any four room public schools with full basement accommodation close to Vancouver or Victoria? If there are, I would certainly appreciate receiving a rough sketch map of one of these schools and also a statement indicating the original cost.

In view of the fact that our estimates are under consideration, anything you can do to send forward this information within the next week or so will be deeply appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, September 2, 1939.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am anxious that you should discuss with Inspector Barry, just as soon as you can conveniently do so, the organization of a staff to take charge of the Cowichan Consolidated School.

I have discussed with Mr. Phelan in a general way the organization of this staff, and we have agreed that the instructional duties should be taken over by the Sisters of St. Anne. Mr. Phelan and I are of the opinion that at least three Sisters will be employed in classroom work at the school. In addition to this, a fully qualified vocational instructor should be employed and a caretaker might be in a position to drive the bus.

Father Lauzon called at my office a few days ago and discussed with me very thoroughly and at considerable length the operation of this particular school. The Priest expressed the opinion that for a number of reasons a clergyman should be appointed principal, and that for this service the clergyman should receive a nominal salary. Mr. Phelan and I have given this suggestion a great deal of serious consideration, and we are not at all satisfied that the appointment of a priest as principal would be likely to prove satisfactory. This priest, as I understand it, would only visit the school intermittently and would not be responsible for giving instruction in the sense that we usually speak of instruction. It is our opinion, therefore, that for the first year at least the Sisters of St. Anne should be placed definitely in charge and made responsible for the progress of the school. If who set-up can, if necessary, be reviewed at the end of the year, with the object of making certain adjustments, if experience convinces us that such adjustments are necessary.

It may be difficult to secure a vocational instructor equally well qualified in auto mechanics, boat building, elementary agriculture, etc. If this difficulty is experienced, consideration might be given to the desirability of employing a vocational instructor at Kuper Island and of having these men exchange places for a couple of months in the year. The school at Cowichan is, as you know, an experiment in Indian educational effort. If the cost can be kept down to a reasonable figure and a worthwhile educational program provided, there is no reason why somewhat similar schools should not be established throughout the Dominion. It is our intention, therefore, to

follow -

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
P. O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B. C.
follow this experiment with the utmost interest from month to month. A good deal, of course, will depend upon how the work of the school is organized at the start. It might be well to have Inspector Barry, if he can do so, spend a week over there in the organization of the classroom work.

I should like to have from you, also, a recommendation with respect to the teacher now in charge of the day school at Cowichan - Mr. Conway. Is it your intention to transfer him to another school? You made a suggestion on one occasion that it was your intention to centralize the Cowichan sweater industry, using perhaps the old school building for this purpose. Is it still your intention to do this?

Dear Sir;

I have received your letter of Oct. 2, last, and am answering at once.

First let me tell you that I regret that my last letter was so badly typed. Lack of practice and time were the causes.

My recommendations, except the one regarding the rest room for the Sisters, were based on an assumption, now dispelled by your letter. According to the plan I submitted to Capt. G. Barry, at the time of the survey, which plan I explained to you and Major D. M. MacKay during your visit in Duncan, this school would have been a semi-residential school in as much as the department would have provided a noon-meal to the children, and the older pupils would have spent a good part of the time in vocational training.

I do not remember if I stressed the necessity of providing a hot meal for the pupils, during our talk in Duncan. But I must have, because I always considered it very important for the success of the school. More than half of our children are underfed, not always from lack of food, but from the lack of well prepared food. That is why I figured that a hot meal at noon would have been very useful, and a dining-room required. Also as I said in my letter, Sept 26, last, Mr. Phelan had told me that there were enough rooms, to use one for that purpose. After looking at the building, I noticed that he was quite right. We have accommodation for 150 children all attending school or class at the same time. Yet the actual roll as I pointed out to Capt. Barry will be from 80 to 100. Even if we had 150 pupils, only three rooms would be required, as half of the older pupils would be only part of the time in the class-rooms. So I concluded that one room could be used for a dining-room.

Another reason why I presumed that a lunch would be served, was that 5 acres of land have been reserved for the school grounds, and only 2 would be required for building and play-ground, leaving 3 for garden.

Always having in mind that a meal would be served, I also asked for a hot water tank.

When I suggested that a rest room be provided for the Sisters, I knew that they would be very much dismayed if such accommodations were not given them.

As you will notice, in this letter I am just pointing out the reasons that prompted me to make the recommendations contained in my last letter. I am doing so to dispel the impression that it seems to me, you gathered from my last letter, and which would have been that I went out of my way to submit those suggestions. But as I had no chance to talk the matter over with Capt. Barry, who was absent when I passed in Vancouver, I wrote directly to you.

In the future I will refer everything to him; and he knowing the exact plans of the Department, will decide what should be submitted to your office.

I will also refer your answer to the Rev. Sisters. They can take whatever decision they may think necessary.

I would like to say that what I have done in the past and might do in the future, was not and will not be done in a spirit of criticism, but with the conviction that being in a different position, it may happen that some of my suggestions would be useful.

In conclusion, I want to say that I certainly do appreciate the cooperation your department has given us in organizing this school district, and assure you of my earnest cooperation in all matters, which in the opinion of the Department and in my mind would be within the scope of my duties.

R. A. Hoey

Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Sir:

Had I only suspected that shortly after your visit to the West Coast about a year ago, I would be called upon to continue R.Fr. Lauzon's work, amongst the Cowichan Indians, I would have profited of the occasion to familiarize myself more with your program and plans to carry it out. Nevertheless, Father Lauzon kept me well informed about the work and directives of the Department, and therefore you may be assured of my ever faithful cooperation.

With the energetic help of Mr. R.H. Moore our new Indian Agent, I have done the utmost to assure the school attendance of our fit children and, as shown by the records, with the result of a double pupilage during the past six months. This has required of us in some instances to act as truant officers, as some of our children would play hide and go seek when school time would come but, at times we met with failure due to lack of any official mandate. Therefore in view of the fact that in a very near future, we will have ample accommodations for all the children of school age, I would highly recommend the appointment of a truant officer. As very likely, this attitude of some children and parents towards school attendance, would vanish rapidly when realizing that now the Indian Act, Sec. 10 #3 will be fully enforced, I would not think that this would constitute enough work for a man even if his services would be extended to the whole of the Cowichan Agency. I feel sure that this request meets fully with the approval of the Indian Dept. Officials here, as I have had at different times the occasion of discussing this matter with them.

When Mr. P. Phelan passed through here a week ago, I suggested to him few alterations in the new school building which had previously been discussed with the Agent, Mr. Moore i.e. power running water in the kitchen one inside toilet and one washing basin for the staff one door on the outside from the manual training room and one also from the kitchen.

After a proper study of the suggestions, Mr. Phelan assured me he would immediately refer the matter to you. Now, I beg you to understand that I foster the same ambition as the Department that is, to keep the building and the upkeep costs as low as possible, but at the same time, I feel that these suggested alterations would only assure to the staff essential accommodations and guarantee greater order and cleanliness which advantages would I think amply compensate for the extra expenditure.
Moreover with power, an informative and educational film could occasionally be shown to the children and thus, driving home principles which would otherwise require much time and patience to inculcate. I have a good machine at my disposition and a few excellent films. It would also possibly permit the school influence to be carried beyond the actual years of schooling, through night classes and study clubs, thus keeping up the work long enough to stay.

Mr. Phelan must also have given you the results of our talks about the problem of transportation. As I explained to him the system of the past year has proven efficient as far as school attendance is concerned but, it required too much time and too many trips in the same districts raising the costs of operation beyond necessity. To obviate this I recommended a thirty passenger bus. The best offer came from the Chevrolet people who can supply a B.C. regulation thirty passenger bus for nearly five hundred dollars less than any other I have approached. On a two ton or even a ton and a half truck chassis, an all steel bus body would be built in Vancouver. This fact and also the freight cost from the East to here account mostly for the difference in price. As full particulars will be submitted to you, no use for me of stressing this matter. All I wanted was to justify my recommendations. May I remind you that the distance to cover daily would be approximately thirty to thirty-five miles accommodating around seventy children all outside a mile radius from the new school.

I have one more point I would like to take advice about. I have talked to the agent Mr. Moore about it and as the plan necessitates the cooperation of different divisions of the Indian Affairs Branch, he told me that it should be submitted to you. The plan would be to have the manual training instructor execute whatever construction work would be deemed necessary on the Reserves with his older pupils and ex-pupils who have already received proper training and find no personal use for it. The plan would probably cut down relief costs, provide work and keep the manual training at school within the sphere of practical. The young ex-pupils could not expect a man's salary and the pupils nothing or very little as matter of encouragement. The same plan could probably followed in agriculture and in fish canning, also for young women in indian handicrafts. I would appreciate your opinion about the possibility of the plan, then a deeper study of it in detail could be made.

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to our discussion today in regard to the organization of a staff to take charge of the new Cowichan Consolidated School at Cowichan Agency, and the contents of Mr. Hoey's letter 152-22-1 of the 2nd instant, I wish to report as follows.

In my original Survey Report on this area it was suggested that a male teacher might take charge of the senior boys, and that in such a case it would be best to have one of the local Priests as nominal Principal of the school. In later letters on the same subject I pointed out that neither the male academic teacher or the Priest as Principal was in fact necessary, and that the Sisters of St Ann might well take complete charge of the whole school. May I say that I am in complete agreement with Mr. Hoey and Mr. Phelan in this matter.

At the nearby St. Ann's Boys' Residential School the Sisters do all the academic teaching and in addition look after the administration of the school. While one of the local Priests visits daily, he is not Principal of the school. A similar arrangement would in my opinion be quite satisfactory at our new Consolidated School.

Mr. Hoey suggests that the whole set up might if necessary come under review at the end of the first year, but that for that time at least the Sisters of St. Ann should be in charge and held responsible for the progress of the school. With such a view I am in complete accord and I am of course prepared to give the Sisters all necessary assistance in the organization of the classroom work, even to spending a week in Duncan for this purpose, as suggested by Mr. Hoey. It would be well to have the Sister Superior in Victoria supply the Department with the names of the Sisters it was proposed to send first to take charge of the new school, so that if necessary their past records in the classrooms of Indian schools might be looked up here.

The above in some degree modifies the suggestions made in my letter to you on this subject dated July 16th 1938 and in particular Page 3 the paragraph headed Staff.

The minimum number of Sisters needed to operate this school will be four including a Sister Superior. One will take charge of the senior boys, one the senior girls. The junior boys and girls will be taught by the above teachers as senior and junior boys and girls will work on the half day system. A third teacher will be required for the primary class of boys and girls combined. This class would work on the whole day system, though possibly not the whole of every day would be spent in the academic work of the classroom. The fourth Sister would need to be qualified to teach Arts and Crafts to the girls and take charge of the Vocational Work, preparation of lunch etc. This Modified Half Day System is explained below.
Under the Modified Half Day System the primary class is either in its own classroom all day or at least is working under its own teacher in some part of the school.

The remaining children senior and junior, girls and boys, would receive academic (A) and vocational (V) instruction as tabulated below.

Here vocational training may be said to include Indian Arts and Crafts, Sewing, Knitting, Preparation of Native Wool, Weaving, Dressmaking, Preparation of meals etc., and in the case of boys Manual Training, School Gardening, etc.

Academic instruction includes all the usual classroom subjects, Singing, Health, Religion, etc. Physical Training and Games would probably be taken during periods marked V.

Three classrooms would be devoted to the academic work, one of these being for the primary classes, one for the boys and one for the girls. The fourth classroom would be fitted up for Arts and Crafts (Girls') while the Manual Training shop in the basement would be for the corresponding boys' classes.

Such an instructor should be employed for work at the new Cowichan School quite apart from any instructor at Kuper Island Indian Residential School, where one of the Brothers as a manual training instructor and has other duties as well. Boat building would not be possible at the start of the new school for many skills have first to be learned in the shop.

Mr. Conway now in charge of the Cowichan Indian Day School is much better as a manual training instructor than in the position of a classroom instructor. His work was last reported on by me December 14th 1938. His school will be inspected again next month, October. He is a married man not particularly well liked by the Indian parents, and as a rule in a most embarrassed financial position. His manual training work has been very good at his present school and benches etc., are ready for transportation to the new school. I consider that he might well be employed at the opening of the new school as Manual Training Instructor and to operate the school bus. He would have to pass the B.C. Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Cowichan Indian Day School, Roman Catholic Church, Cowichan Agency, which I inspected on Monday afternoon, November 6th.

It was about 2 p.m. when I arrived at the school with the Rev. Father Le Clair S.M.M., having been delayed by a conference with the local missionaries dealing partly with the conduct of the teacher Mr Donald McConney.

Though not a recognized recess period in B.C. the children had been granted one and were found playing about the schoolroom quite out of any sort of control. Pieces of paper and rubbish were all over the floor, and there were even pieces of bread on the floor near the door and cups on the desks. These conditions were of course also observed by the Priest.

Of the 57 pupils on the roll some 38 only were present and the majority of these were small beginners. It will be noted from my report that there are too many children in Grade 1, some 42 in all.

The teacher, who did not at first observe our presence, was engaged in the preparation of pencil copies for the Beginners writing lesson. He is far too much of a High School teacher to deal with this mob of little beginners, though he has of course been given in the past very detailed instructions as to work and methods for such a class.

In a very few minutes I managed to get good order and to satisfy myself that in the key subjects Grade 1 knew very little indeed, the subject of Language being particularly poor.

The past two reports on this school have been good, and it is with regret that I have now to report in an adverse manner on the work of the school.

The older pupils are anxious to learn but the teacher is too much occupied with the Primary Grades to give them the instruction they so much desire.

When I inspected here in December 1938 I found the Manual Training quite good. Since that time very little has been done. Some steps have been made which are of use as the children have to use the Manual Training benches as desks, but the work sent in for exhibition in Vancouver was not of much value, being mainly some small boxes.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6387, File 807-1, part 2)
I spoke to Mr Conway about the many debts he appears to have contracted in different parts of Alberta and B.C. He explained that the local debts had been paid, and that sums supposed to be owing in other places were in fact money put into his invention, a new kind of pen which he has not been able to put on the market. In particular a woman in Alberta, with whom there has been some correspondence considers that she is owed money for board, but Mr Conway says that this was in fact the payment for sharing his "work." I explained that the Department did not like teachers in Indian schools to owe money like this. This subject was included in a previous report, March 1938.

When informed that in all probability on the opening of the new Cowichan Consolidated School in January this present school would be absorbed, Mr Conway told me that he expected to be the Principal of the new school and that he had been promised a good position by Mr. Joey.

I suggested that it was highly unlikely that he would be Principal, and that it was possible that a community of Sisters would take charge of the teaching. Mr Conway was advised that while I had nothing to do with the selection of a staff, the matter being one for the Department of Education, I might well consider writing to one or more of the Catholic Bishops, particularly to His Excellency Bishop Bunog O.M.I., to seek nomination should a vacancy occur in a northern Indian day school.

Mr Conway was not a success at Kamloops Indian Residential School where he taught the older boys for one year. He did not get on well with the Sisters of St. Ann.

I would recommend that he be informed that the position he now holds will be done away with at the end of December, and that his services will therefore no longer be needed as from December 31st 1939. He should be given a full month's notice if this is in any way possible. I simply could not recommend that he be employed at the new school, for this year's work at the present Cowichan Indian Day School has not been satisfactory.

As my previous reports on this teacher have been satisfactory, may I suggest that you obtain a report from the Indian Agent before forwarding your own recommendations to Ottawa.

This whole matter has been discussed with Mr Moore and I understand that he is even more dissatisfied with Mr Conway's work than I am. There has been a great falling off in the work accomplished at the school during the past year, and the teacher's control is now so weak that I can do little for him. These facts in themselves would be sufficient to justify the termination of his services. However the matter might be better dealt with by the abolition of the position he now holds.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Sir:

On several occasions I have interviewed Mr. Moore about the draining and levelling of the grounds of the Cowichan Consolidated Indian School, and he informed me that, due to lack of funds, authorization to proceed with this very necessary work has been withheld. It seems impossible that this can actually be the case, as it is absolutely necessary for the health of the children to have the grounds seen to as soon as possible.

Perhaps the Department is not aware of the fact that only about 10% of our schoolchildren have the means to buy rubbers, and as all accommodations are outside, they are obliged to wade ankle deep through the mud, with the result that children, already delicate in health from undernourishment, must sit for several hours in the classroom with wet shoes and stockings. This, as you will readily understand, is very detrimental to their health and may cause lasting trouble.

Our school, so beautiful and spotless at the outset, has been damaged considerably by mud brought in unavoidably from the grounds which are really in a deplorable condition. This, though regrettable, is, however, merely of secondary importance. The children's health comes first, and as this was brought to the attention of Mr. Moore, he advised me to write to you myself.

Regarding Domestic Science supplies I also conferred with our Indian Agent, who seems to be of the opinion that the Department can make no provision. Knitting needles, thimbles, needles and thread, etc., have been supplied, but no provision has been made for the purchase of raw wool and other material necessary for the knitting of Indian sweaters and the teaching of cooking. May we suggest a monthly allowance of ten dollars ($10) from March 1st until the end of June? Our Domestic Science teacher is most eager to do her best to promote the Cowichan sweater industry. If material is provided for the first few months, the knitted articles might be sold later and with the proceeds other raw material could be purchased without added expense to the Department.

Eager to assist us in every possible way to make this new undertaking a great success, our Mother Provincial sent our Prefect of Studies on an official visitation of the classes to ascertain the number of pupils actually taught in this school. Forty six (46) were registered on the first day of school, and on the first of February this number had increased to 90, a very satisfactory enrollment, indeed. We both agree that, as Principal, it is impossible for me to do justice to five grades, teach an hour and a half daily in the Primary Grades in order that the Domestic Science teacher may devote this time to her branch of training, interview...
visit, and supervise the run of the school in general. Something must necessarily be neglected. To remedy this deficiency, and to make of this school, the only one of its kind in the Dominion, a real credit to the Department, we would strongly advise a fourth teacher, at least at the beginning of the new Scholastic Year in September. Classes could then be more evenly divided, vocational training could be placed on a more practical basis, and, though an added expense, the Department would be better satisfied.

I am happy to have this opportunity of expressing the sincere thanks of the Sisters and of our Indian children and their parents for this beautiful school and costly equipments. We trust that the improvements pleaded for will meet with your approval, and in return you may safely count on the wholehearted co-operation of the Sisters of St. Ann.

Very sincerely yours,

Sister Mary Armella, S.S.A.
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 2nd instant and also certain correspondence relating to the display of films at the Ste. Catherine's Indian day school, attached thereto.

You are aware of the action taken by the Department with respect to the operation of a cinematographic machine at the Alert Bay Indian residential school. After very careful and sympathetic consideration, it was felt that in view of the fire hazard involved and a number of other factors it was inadvisable in times such as these to display films at the Alert Bay school. It is not the intention of the principal in charge of the Ste. Catherine's school, as I understand it, to have the general public admitted to these displays. I feel, nevertheless, that a great many of the objections that apply to Alert Bay apply in this case also. No one at this date doubts the value of visual instruction. I have advocated its adoption and extension in public schools for a number of years. As a matter of fact, however, I do not know at the moment of a single white school where visual instruction is systematically provided. It would appear that for the time being at least the cost of this instruction is something the taxpayers are not able to meet. In view of this fact, it is of the utmost importance that those in charge of our Indian schools maintain, if they can, a sense of proportion. We shall be very fortunate indeed if we can provide regular instruction for Indian pupils during the war period, without extending this instruction to include visual education. It seems exceedingly difficult to bring home to our school teachers and missionaries on Indian reserves the fact that these are very extraordinary times in which we are living and times that demand substantial sacrifices on the part of all of us.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter with reference to the showing of educational films at the new St. Catherine's School by Father Lauzon, also letter attached from Inspector Barry on the same subject.

Personally, I cannot find any fault with the showing of the films as suggested, providing they are of General Educational value and not confined to Religious matters; in fact I feel that the Religious side should be left out of it entirely. Then, of course, there are the other questions which come to my mind such as:

(1). Father Lauzon states that the average cost of the show would be $1.50 but he asks that the Dept. pay him $2.00 to cover service and operating cost. I don't know what he means by service but the operating cost would be automatically borne by the Dept. in the Electric light bill.

(2). What assurance are we to have that only safety films will be shown? And how long is the time to be taken up from other other school subjects on these shows? To my mind 1 hour twice a month should be sufficient, especially during the fine weather.

(3). I am certainly very much against the performance being put on except during the regular school hours and then only to the Indian pupils. Night shows, in my opinion, should not be permitted under any consideration.

(4). I would strongly recommend that unless "Safety Films" are available that permission be not granted, because I saw a large Community Hall burned down when I was in the north by the films getting on fire from no apparent reason. As I have no idea how much electric energy a machine of this kind would take, I just mention it in passing in case that there happens to be a rise in the monthly light and power account.

Yours obediently,

Dear Major MacKay:

As requested I have given some consideration to the suggestion of the Rev. Father Lauzon, C.M.M., that he be paid some $3.00 per month to show educational films at the new St. Catherine's School, Cowichan Agency.

The Principal of the school, Sister M. Armella, appears to be in favour of this form of education, and I know from experience that Indian children do learn much from good films.

The Rev. Father Lauzon was supplied with information as to the location of certain firms etc., from which films could be borrowed. This was done at his request. I have no objection to such films being shown provided no charge is made and the general public excluded.

I should however point out that there are no shades to the windows at the school and though the large classrooms, when the doors are folded back, could accommodate the school, I do not see how the light could be sufficiently excluded to make such a picture show with safety films possible. Again if shown at night there is the question of transportation of the children by bus to be considered. These points should perhaps be cleared up by reference to the Indian Agent, and while the matter may be educational I for one should value his observations and recommendations, particularly on the points raised here.

Without the Indian Agent's full approval I do not see how this matter can be taken up with the Department. It involves the expenditure of some $30.00 per annum at the least, and with possible transportation charges might be very much more.

Only safety film should in any case be shown in a classroom, and this would no doubt be made a condition when permission was being considered by the Department.

Yours very truly,

The Prime Minister's Secretary (Mr. Henry) has referred to the Minister an exchange of correspondence with Mr. D.M.J. Rt.Hon. dear Sir,

Some two and one half years ago I was privileged to have you take a gracious interest in my securing a post as teacher with the Department of Indian Affairs. I was then appointed to Cowichan Indian Day School, on Vancouver Island.

I have held the post until Dec. 31st, '39, when my school was absorbed into a larger school-unit and I received a blunt notice of termination of my services.

I wrote to Ottawa, asking for information and was informed that Inspector Barry had given me an adverse report.

I took the matter up with Commissioner Major McBay, who was most courteous and sympathetic.

As I have not received any definite consideration I am placing the facts of my case in brief before yourself, Sir.

1. The Inspector rushed into my school, spent 35 minutes there and sent to Ottawa an adverse report on work he did not test. He was safe in doing so as he instructs the Agent not to allow teachers see their reports.

2. The work in Indian Schools in B.C. is a hit and miss affair, as it seems to be work outlined by a very variable inspector. A definite curriculum should be laid down and the teacher's work appraised on that standard.

... I immediately obtained another position as Mathematics and Science master in Duncan Grammar school.

I apologize for intruding on your valuable time but I cannot afford to let Inspector Barry get away with ruining my reputation as a teacher by giving me a report such as he gave. It was the first poor report I have received in all my teaching experience.

...............

I am honoured to remain, Hon. Sir, Yours very sincerely,

signed) D.M.J. Conway

Dear Major MacKay:

Mr. Hoey's letter 152-8-1 of the 16th instant has been read with care as requested and I wish to make the following observations for your information.

With regard to the Manual Training Instructor I may say that I understand that the Department has by this received Mr. Marchant's resignation to take effect April 30th No doubt His Excellency Bishop Cody will be requested to nominate the best qualified candidate he may have available to take Mr. Marchant's place as from May 1st 1940.

It has been explained previously that while Mr. Marchant may not have been sufficiently qualified as a tradesman he was the best available man for the combined position at St. Catherine's School at the time he was nominated.

The necessary school supplies and desks have I understand reached the school so that the ordinary academic work of the classrooms is being carried on as in other schools.

With regard to the grounds, a report of which was included in my letter of February 15th, 1940 and Mr. Hoey's observation that the teachers might have kept the children indoors for a week or two till conditions improved, I would point out that when the school was last visited by me on February 14th, some six weeks after the opening of the school, the grounds were in this hopelessly condition, and that as far as I am aware a similar condition has existed for at least a further month. In any case the children had to walk through thick mud to reach the school from the school bus and every time they went to the toilets. The pieces of wood that Mr. Hoey considers might be picked up by the older children were no doubt the pieces put down to cover patches of thick mud to allow the children to get to the school building. They will of course be removed when the ground has dried up a little.

While it is possible for one teacher to take up to forty or so children when these are in one or two Grades I have never known a teacher successful with 50 to 55 in a number of Grades. In British Columbia the limit for one teacher was six years ago at 40 and later reduced to 35 I believe. The classrooms at St. Catherine's School are intended and arranged for some 35 to 40 pupils each, as has been explained in previous reports and letters.

It was explained at great length to the Department that four Sisters would be required to look after the academic and girls' vocational work. The school was opened with three Sisters and very soon the Vocational Teacher, Sister M. Alphonse...
became ill through overwork. I was unable to arrange for pupils from the Primary Division to be promoted to this Sister's Division as she could not take on more work with the Vocational Training.

The Sister Superior or Principal, Sister M. Armella, next became ill and had to go to Victoria to hospital for a short time.

While these teachers are now back at work I have received in the last few days a letter from the Sister Prefect of Studies, St. Ann's Academy, Victoria, Provincial Administration Office. In the course of a letter dated March 14th 1940 Sister M. Dorothea S.S.A. says:

"I have had occasion, recently, to visit the new Indian School at Duncan, and I am happy to report that Sister Mary Armella has been able to resume her teaching and principalship there since early last week, - On March 6th, to be exact."

"The pupil attendance at the time of my visit was only about 60% as many of the children were suffering from colds and illnesses of one kind or another. I was most interested, however, in noting the advancement of the classes.

"We regret that it has been necessary, for a time at least, to relieve Sister Mary Alphonse, the Home Economics teacher of the 100-1015 period of academic teaching. Mother Provincial has provided a substitute for the stated period, Miss Somerville, whom the Sisters have carefully initiated into the needs of the class. As Miss Somerville seems to like the Indian children and to enjoy teaching them, I think her work will be successful. I hope the arrangement will prove satisfactory to you."

"Sister Mary Alphonse will now be free to devote her time to Home Economics and she will adjust her programme to take care of Religion and of singing as well."

"Sister Mary Armella has received official notification that the name, "St. Catherine's Indian School" has been approved by the Department at Ottawa. The Sisters are very pleased, as is also our Reverend Mother Provincial, who first proposed the name."

I am still of opinion that four Sisters are needed at this school if Home Economics is to be taught to the girls by one of the teachers with special qualifications for this work. You will see from the letter from the new Sister Prefect of Studies that a Miss Somerville has joined the school staff at least for the time. I wish the Department to be aware of this fact even if it is decided not to allow her any salary as above the sum being now given to the three Sisters of St Ann at the school.

I am certainly glad to learn that some at least of the vocational and physical training equipment recommended in my letter of February 16th last is to be provided.

Such matters as the proper fencing of the whole of the school grounds, levelling and seeding of the part around the building and the provision of suitable depth of gravel on part of the ground and the ploughing of a school garden, are not being further reported on as such matters have no doubt received the attention of the Indian Agent and yourself.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Sir,

I wish to thank you for your letter, date and file number above noted, with reference to the movement or transfer of children from either the Nokmakah or St. Catherine's schools to the other, unless there are special reasons to the contrary, and that after a child is enrolled in one school or the other that such child must remain there at least until the end of that academic year. This ruling of the Department is just as I expected it would be.

There is another angle in connection with our Day schools which I would like to have clarified, and a definite ruling from the Department on, and it refers to Sec. 10, s.s. 2 of the Indian Act. My interpretation of the above s.s. is that R.C. children when attending Residential Schools must be sent to Residential schools operated under the auspices of the R.C. Church, and Protestant children attend schools operated under Protestant Church denominations. In the case of Day Schools does that regulation also apply? For instance at the moment we have three R.C. children attending the Nanaimo Indian Day School which is operated under the auspices of the United Church, owing to the fact that the mother of these children is living as the C.Wife of an Nanaimo Indian and residing for the time being in Nanaimo I.R. Then at the Songhees Indian Day School we have a United Church child attending the Songhees Day School which is being operated under the auspices of the R.C. Church, for the reason that the guardian of the child is working at the Shipyard adjoining the Reserve and living on the Reserve at Songhees while he is working there.

In the case of the former 3 R.C. children I wrote their mother asking that she send them to Rupert Island Residential School, she replied saying that they were attending the day school at Nanaimo and that is where she wanted them to go and so far as their religious views concerned it didn't make any difference anyway as there was only one God and both faiths were going in the same direction but by different routes. In the case of the Protestant child attending the Songhees School the same argument applies, and as all of these children are receiving their education in day schools I hesitate to move them forcibly into Residential Schools of the faith to which they belong, largely on account of Sec. 10, s.s. 2 of the Indian Act which I endeavour to interpret in a broad way. For instance I believe that the s.s. referred to applies to Residential Schools and not to Day Schools. Of course I may be wrong but in my humble opinion I find it strange if the Department has one school on each reserve which is operated under one particular Church denomination and if there are children of another Denomination living on that Reserve that they should have to go to a Residential School of the Denomination to which they belong, instead of attending the day school on the Reserve. I quite appreciate the fact that the Department realise the added cost of a child's education in a Res. School, and I also appreciate the fact that the Department in its wisdom know what is best from all the various angles, and for that reason I would like to have a ruling on the matter and particularly with reference to the cases cited above. I would also like your on my interpretation of Sec. 10, s.s. 2 of the I.A.

I regret having to bother you in this way as I feel that I have been with the Department long enough to know what action I should take in matters of this kind, but it is only since coming to this Agency that I have been confronted with two religious denominations. I have maintained that where a child is attending a day school that may belong to a different religious faith, that we should allow that child to stay there instead of going to the expense of sending such child to a Res. school of its particular denomination, and that further in spite of arguments put up to the contrary by various people I was of the opinion that the section of the I.A. referred to in this letter was not intended to apply to day schools unless there were two schools of different faiths on the same reserve.

I quite realise that I may be entirely wrong and it is with the view of getting put right that I am writing this lengthy letter, in which I have tried to explain matters just as they exist.

Yours obediently;

Sir:

I would respectfully request to have a ruling from the Department on the following questions which have to do with educational matters:

(1). Does s.s. 2 of Section 10 of the Indian Act apply to any school for Indian Children, or just for children attending Indian Residential Schools?

(2). Would you please advise the exact status of the Koksilah Indian Day school? Is it an un-denominational School or recognised by the Department as being operated under the auspices of the United Church? If the former, will my first question about Sec. 10 have any bearing on R.C. children attending that school?

As you are quite aware there are certain R.C. children attending the Koksilah School who, if Sec. 10, s.s. 2 of the I.A. applies to Day Schools, should be attending St. Catherine's School, if not then who is the rightful person to determine just what school these children should attend?

There seems to be some confusion about this whole matter and I would like to be informed definitely just where we stand. For instance an R.C. child is enrolled at the Koksilah School for a couple of years and then it is decided that this child should go to the St. Catherine's School and the transfer is made without reference to me until after it has actually taken place. I believe that it might be well if the Department would be good enough to give a ruling on the subject. Should the wishes of the parents of the children have any bearing in deciding to which school a child should go or in case a parent asks that his or her child be allowed to go to another than the one the child has been attending for a year or more be sufficient reason to make the transfer?

3. Cowichan Agency:

St. Catherine's Indian Day School

This school was opened on January 8th 1940 as a consolidated school. It absorbed the old Cowichan Indian Day School.

The school was inspected by me on January 11th when there were 62 children on the school roll. I visited the school several times since the above date. There were 91 on the roll on the occasion of my visit on February 14th but since that date the attendance has increased till there are in excess of 110 pupils on the roll.

The school building is quite new. It is not necessary to report on this now. Children are brought to school and taken home by a school bus operated by a transportation company. This bus takes children to and from the Koksilah Indian Day School, reported on in my survey of United Church Indian Day Schools.

There are three Sisters of St Ann teaching at St Catherine's. A Manual Training Instructor and a part time janitor are also employed.

The attendance this last June has been very small indeed. The Rev. Sister Principal informed me that most of the children would be away in June and that it would not be worth my while making an inspection during this month.

Children from this district leave the local Indian reserves for seasonal employment towards the end of May. I do not believe that the school should be kept open in June. It seems very foolish to me to employ a large staff and operate a school bus for a very few pupils.

Under present regulations St Catherine's School will reopen on October 1st 1940. The academic year should in my opinion be one of eight months from October 1st to May 31st yearly.

Whatever course is decided on here should be followed in the Koksilah Indian Day School also, for the reason given above, that the same school bus is operated for the two schools, picking up and depositing children throughout its complete itinerary on the two morning trips and two afternoon trips.
