Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Dismissal of Mr. D.M.J. CONWAY,
Ste. Catherine's (Cowichan) School.

May I refer to a memorandum relating to the dismissal of the above noted teacher, dated March 12, 1940, and signed by Mr. W. C. Bethune? It is noted that the letter drafted by this Branch for the signature of the Private Secretary was not sent forward to Mr. Conway.

The records here indicate that a letter somewhat similar to the communication received by the Prime Minister from Mr. Conway was sent forward to Major MacKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, on January 3, 1940. Major MacKay has not replied to this letter and it would appear that there is little to add to the reports already on file in the Department with respect to the dismissal of this teacher.

I am sending forward, for your information, a letter received by the Department from Major MacKay dated November 12, 1939, and also excerpts from a report dated November 8, 1939, received by the Department from Inspector Barry.

I wish to point out that the one-room Indian day school at Cowichan, to which Mr. Conway was appointed, was displaced by a four-room consolidated school about three months ago. The new school, on the recommendation -
recommendation of the Inspector and the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, was placed in charge of the Sisters of St. Ann, who agreed to supply four teachers to undertake the academic work. Mr. Conway was fully aware of this fact. In addition to the four Sisters, a director of vocational instruction (male) was appointed. Consideration was given to Mr. Conway's claims for this position, but his work as teacher of the one-room school had been so unsatisfactory that he was not acceptable either to the church authorities or to the Department and consequently was given notice of dismissal. It is difficult to see how any good purpose can be served by referring the matter again to the officials in British Columbia.

Director.

The above girl did not return to the above school when it opened on the lst ultimo and on asking the reason of her father, Tommy Modeste Cowichan Band, he informed me that she had run away from home and gone to her uncle who was living at Nanaimo, where he was employed. The father asked me if I would allow her to go to the Ruper Island school as he could not handle her and she simply would not pay any attention to what he told her. I explained to the parent that this state of affairs was his responsibility and that I would not advise her transfer to a Residential school for such a reason. As the girl did not return within a reasonable time I gave her name, along with many others, to the R.C.M.P. as truants and they in turn advised the parent that she would have to attend school or he would be charged in Court for failing to have her do so.

Yesterday, we (the Police and I) found out that the girl has been employed in domestic service in Nanaimo, B.C., being employed in a very fine household. Her employer asked me if she could continue in his service as she was very happy and contented. After consideration I decided that she might do so until I referred the matter to you for a ruling. Since then the question has been discussed with the Principal of the school who informs me that Majorie is quite a big girl for her age, and has a will of her own, and if she is suitably employed in a good home the education she would receive there might be just as beneficial as if she was at school, particularly as there is a strong possibility that even we did bring her back she would only run away again at the first opportunity and her next job could quite easily be the very opposite to what her present one is. Personally, I quite agree with this reasoning and feel that under the circumstances it is definitely in the interests of the girl to remain where she is. I happen to know the people for whom she is working and they will see that the girl behaves and is not permitted to go out at nights. I would therefore recommend that this girl be excused from school so long as she stays in her present position.

Yours obediently,

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM.

To: Commissioner of Indian Affairs for B.C.
From: Inspector of Indian Schools.

Re - St. Catherine's Indian Day School.

The provision of full time Manual Training and Domestic Science Teacher at this school will not relieve to any appreciable extent the overcrowding in the Junior and Intermediate rooms unless a platoon system is employed, which is not altogether satisfactory for the Primary and Intermediate grades. The organization sheets show that approximately 1/3 of the pupils' time from Grades 4 to 8 was devoted to Vocational Instruction. This limits considerably the time devoted to academic fundamentals and should not be increased.

I recommend that an additional full time classroom teacher be employed and that the room at present used for sewing be converted into a classroom. This involves moving the equipment to the cooking room in the basement, and equipping the classroom with desks.

An alternative plan is to employ the specialists on a full time basis and to decrease the size of the groups in these classes. The various grades would then have to be organized on a platoon system. This alternative is recommended only if it is impossible to secure a classroom teacher. Apparently this was the plan the Reverend Principal had in mind in asking for the full time employment of the Vocational Training Teachers.

R.F. Davy,
Inspector of Indian Schools.

Dear Major Davey,

RE: 1947-1948 enrollment

We anticipated an enrollment of 112 not taking into account pupils who may come to the day school instead of returning to residential schools, two families of the district, one with three children attending the Agulmalt school last year, the other with four children who have been nomadic during the past year, back and forth to U.S.A. I may add that there are four beginners that may be added to our list if parents return to Duncan.

The Domestic Science teacher has four classes daily. If classes have to be readjusted, as we think they will, for there will be 41 pupils in Gr. I alone, 45 in the intermediate room (Gr. II, III, IV) and 27 in the senior class comprising Grs. V, VI, VII, VIII, then there will have to be five classes of domestic science. There are 30 girls in the senior group and most that can be handled in one senior class is 12 pupils, as there are only 3 machines and all the senior girls are capable of cutting and making dresses. One hr. is required for the supervision of preparation of cups and hot cocoa drink for the noon hour. Sister therefore teaches 5 hours a day totalling 25 hours per week. I may add that Sister does any First Aid work plus dressing of sores between the visits of the nurse.

The Manual training instructor who is now working on 3½ day basis will have to be subject to the same regime if things are to work harmoniously. Otherwise the girls of a grade will be out of the classroom and the boys in, leaving a divided grade, the girls being handicapped academically.

Ten pupils are the most that can be accommodated in the woodwork room at one period, but twelve make up the largest class.

Under the above plan children unable to progress academically can be given extra vocational training enabling them to return to their environment better equipped to raise their standards of living.
I hope, Major Davey, this information will be what you require.

Sincerely yours,

"Sister Mary Sheila"

I am enclosing with the returns a letter which I hope will make clear the situation I hurriedly tried to explain when in your office last week. I am sending two copies, asking you to please forward the second one to Ottawa, that they too may study the matter.

The attendance question of St. Catherine's School has been a "bone of contention" since its inauguration on January 8, 1940. Since every question concerning the school seems to be based upon the "Average Attendance" of the quarterly returns it seems to me that this method does not do us justice considering the question from different angles.

As an example to prove the above statement:
Room "Two" or Grades 3, 4 and 5 had 15 pupils registered at the opening of school, against 22 at the end of the month.

The average attendance for 15 pupils was 14.7
" " " " 22 " " " 17.5
lowering the average 4.5 against .3.
The per cent attendance for 15 pupils was 98.2
" " " " 22 " " " 71.3
leaving a drop of 26.9

Pupil No. 3 has 6 days to his credit out of 19
" " 6 " 2 " " " " " 19
" " 5 " 2 " " " " " 19
" " 10 " 3 " " " " " 19
" " 22 " 6 " " " " " 19

Dividing the aggregate attendance by the number of days school was open means that there are 74 out of the 95 days that cannot possibly be accounted for because how can a child be in school when he is not even in the country? Then again, how is it fair
to judge the attendance by the above method when the late comers depreciate the average to such an extent.

Another point is the changing back and forth from schools. Pupils 5 and 6 registered September 27th, remained 6 days—4 of which will tally in on the next quarterly. The family has gone to Esquimalt to work in the canneries. They expect to be gone for three months, returning for the dance season. Hence their 4 days present will bring down the average for the next quarter and their absence is unavoidable.

Again, when a pupil reaches 16 he leaves school regardless of the time of year.

Take the April, May and June returns for the same room, (Sister Mary Eugenia, teacher) the number of pupils registered was 40, the average 22. Twenty of these pupils left for the U.S.A. between the dates of May 23 to June 3. Two left for Nanaimo April 12. Nine pupils were in for the first week of June. Two pupils were present when school closed. All had left the country or the district.

According to the above, a better way of tabulating the aggregate attendance would be found if all circumstances would enter into consideration.

I have just been notified that Mr. Frank S. Morrison, instructor at St. Catherine's Indian Day School, Duncan, B.C., is sending in his resignation. The reason, I am told, is exclusively a salary question.

He apparently applied several times through the regular channels and directly to Ottawa for an increase in salary. True he is now drawing higher monthly checks but this is due mostly to the cost of living bonus and not to any substantial increase in his basic salary.

Mr. F. S. Morrison, as your files will show is fully qualified for the position he now holds. Moreover, the standard of his work with the Indians in general, and particularly in manual arts, has been of a very high quality, practically unequaled, as any person able to judge in the matter will readily admit. When he came to St. Catherine's, no work shop, nor work program were properly organized. The so-called instructors who preceded him were mere handy men, doing everything and anything. Under his guidance, the Boys learnt how to handle tools and in a short time they were able to put into practical use their training, as a visit around the school will conclusively show. He himself without any extra financial remuneration for this work built for the school several pieces of necessary furniture. This work alone in many instances would have cost the Department more than the salary he received. He gladly did it in the interest of the school and because he has the welfare of the Indians at heart. This last point is in my opinion of major importance, if we want to get results with the Indians.

All in all, I feel that Mr. Morrison has been an ideal man in his position and the Department would be ill advised to leave him go for the mere question of salary. I know it is the ambition of the Department to have and keep on staff good and qualified teachers and instructors. Consequently, I felt it was my duty to call your attention to his case, and ask you to reconsider it for a substantial increase in his basic salary. If you have time to refer yourself to the periodical reports which must have been sent to your office, you will find that they bear my claims, this I say in spite of the fact that I have not seen any of them at any time.

A copy of this letter is being sent to Mr. R.H. Moore, our local agent and to the Comm. Major D.M. MacKay with the request to support this case and give their viewpoint.

Sorry to trouble you about this matter, but I consider it as serious and important for the school and would ask you to give it serious consideration.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Neary:

Since the receipt of your letter of August 31, we have been further studying the situation at St. Catherine's Indian Day School, Duncan, B.C., and can at this date, only reiterate the points that have already been brought before your department through letters from Sister Mary Sheila, Principal, from Reverend Mother General, and from this office - also in person and in writing by Reverend L. D. Leclair, S.M.M.

These points are, briefly: (1) The Extra Teacher

In spite of the admittedly low AVERAGE pupil-attendance at St. Catherine's over the ENTIRE school year, (Such condition being attributable to circumstances peculiar to the Duncan reserves, and well-known to your office) and of the consequent shortening of the school year for pupils who register late and withdraw early - this coupled with the loss in teaching-time in every class on account of irregularity in student personnel from day to day, St. Catherine's is grading its pupils according to the B.C. Programme of Studies and has succeeded in bringing some of them to High School Entrance standing.

At the same time, St. Catherine's is endeavouring to carry out the much-to-be-desired Home Economics Programme for girls and the Manual Training for boys, as required for Indian schools.

Therefore, when the question is considered from the point of view of grade-programmes to be covered or of classes to be taught, rather than from the viewpoint of average attendance, the need for an extra teacher seems quite apparent - for:

In Grade I, . . Primary Class . . Sister Mary Walter . . there is the problem of teaching the children to speak English and then of bringing them to the scholastic standard required for promotion.

In Grade II & III, . . Intermediate Class . . Sister Mary Eugenia . . the teacher has to schedule her time so as to carry out the Home Economics programme for Grades III to VIII, as well as see to her own class.

In Grades IV, V, VI, VII and VIII . . Senior Class . . Sister Mary Sheila the teacher has charge of several grades besides attending to the duties of principal of the school.

It is conceivable, though, that a part-time teacher, relieving in Sister Mary Eugenia's class daily, for whatever period, or periods, is necessary to provide for the proper functioning of the Home Economics courses, would satisfy present needs.

We therefore repeat our request that we be allowed to present for the approval of your department a teacher who will be available for such daily periods, at least, as most seriously require the services of an extra teacher.

(2) Salary Increase

As requested in your letter of August 31, we are enclosing a statement of qualifications for each of the teachers now engaged at St. Catherine's. These are supported by extracts from Inspector's reports - copies of which you must have on
file - I trust you will find them satisfactory and that they will justify the increase in salary for which request has been made.

At the same time, may I draw to your attention the fact that the $10.00 addition to the salary was solicited by our Reverend Mother General as remuneration to St. Ann's School for Boys for housing the teachers of St. Catherine's School, rather than as a salary increase for teachers' service. In any case, we would be grateful for your kind attention to this matter.

(3) The installation of an indoor Toilet

The third point that requires attention for the personal convenience of the Sisters is the installation of an indoor toilet. I believe, however, that Reverend Father LeClair has made application for this.

We have watched with satisfaction the steady advance made by St. Catherine's School in recent years, and we wish, on this occasion, to assure you of our deepest interest in its future development. We deplore, with you, the one thing that hinders its progress, that is, the irregular attendance of the pupils, and we are hoping for an improvement this year. Some months of last year were very good. The zealous devotedness of the four teachers now trying to advance the interests of the school and at the same time cope with difficulties as presented above, has been truly admirable. The three Sisters and Mr. Morrison have accomplished marvels in the few years of the school's existence.

Sincerely yours,

Sister Mary Mildred,

In reference to your above noted letter, I wish to advise that the quotation given in your letter as taken from my report, cannot be supported except, as already stated, by our opinion. And by our I mean, Miss Robertson, Miss Hayward and myself, also Corporal J. Henry to a lesser degree. I said that I had no direct evidence to support our opinion other than the fact that we thought the teachers were not just the right type for that school, actually one or two of them might be alright, but it might avoid trouble and fuss if a complete change could be made at the suggestion of the Department to the proper authorities.

It is not my intention to make any trouble, but rather do I feel it my duty to suggest some means of getting better results at that school and as we have tried everything else, it would appear to be time to change the teachers to see if that would improve matters. If that does not have the desired effect then the question of changing the status of the school entirely might be considered. The children, or rather some of them, have told their parents that they did not like the teachers, but then there is nothing unusual about that and would be difficult to prove that the child was right and the teacher wrong. However, there must be something wrong when the existing spirit in the school is not better and the opinion expressed in my report and the suggestion offered is -to my mind-the easiest way to find out just where the trouble does lie. The reason I suggested a complete change would be, I thought, obvious, and simply means that with a new staff there a new and better feeling between teachers and pupils might be built up. I am not recommending a change, but rather suggesting that one be made to see if it will improve conditions at this school.

Schools were quite well attended during the period, with the exception of St. Catherine's which seem to have great difficulty in holding the interest of the children and getting the support of the parents. Some of us are inclined to think that a complete change of teaching staff is needed in that school, for although we have no direct evidence to substantiate our opinion, the fact remains that the children do not like their present teachers who might be alright in a Residential School but quite unsuited in a Day School. There is certainly a marked difference in the spirit existing in the Tsartlip School, where we have Rev. Sisters teaching also, than there is in St. Catherine's although the facilities and conveniences at the latter school are very much greater. I am of the opinion that if a change could be made in this school, that all the teachers should go there at present, for certainly we are not getting results now, even with the Truant Officer.

As reported last month a meeting was held with the Chiefs of the Cowichan Band in regard to the then irregular attendance at St. Catherine's school, the outcome being that a meeting of the Teacher's of the School and the Councils was arranged when the matter was fully discussed and all phases of the school and the program of studies gone into and explained by the Teachers. This meeting apparently had a very beneficial effect on all concerned and no further complaints have been received from the Council members. It was felt that the Teachers were doing a good job but the Indians some of them are of the opinion that more time should be devoted to classroom teaching and not so much to Domestic Science and Manual training, in other words more after the time table of the Provincial Public schools.

Attendance at all Indians schools during the period was quite satisfactory, with the exception of St. Catherine's. It would appear as if there is a definite objection by the Indians to have their children attend this school. A meeting to try and get to the bottom of the trouble was held with the Chiefs' and Councillors of the Cowichan Band during the month, along with the Truant Officer, but as there was not a quorum present no definite action could be taken. It was agreed however, by all those present that they would interview the parents of each child attending this school and get their objections to the school and report back at a regular Council meeting as soon as possible. There is certainly a very definite passive resistance on the part of the parents to their children being forced to attend this school and it is hoped that the situation can be clarified and a complete report submitted very soon.

January 21st, 1943.

D.M. MacKay, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver,

This is to inform you that Mrs Miller, Teacher of the Koksilah Indian Day School, telephoned me this morning at 7 o'clock to let me know that she was unable to attend school today on account of illness, having contracted a chill during the first two days of this week which has settled in her arms and legs.

I have just now received a telephone call from St. Catherine's School informing me that there are only 30 pupils present today, on account of the weather conditions, and I took the liberty to instruct the Principal to keep the school closed tomorrow as there does not appear to be any sign of the weather breaking; so if the Koksilah School will not be open it will just be a waste of money to have the bus run—and also a waste of fuel—for such a small attendance.

It is hoped that the weather will be back to normal again by Monday next and travel by bus will not be as hazardous as at present. Trusting that my action will be approved.

(R.H. Moore)

Sir:

I am in receipt of your telegram of the 1st instant in which you advise that Joseph Chubna is not prepared to accept the appointment as teacher of the Cowichan Indian Day School.

In view of the information contained in your telegram, the Department approved the appointment of D. M. J. Conway, B.A., as teacher of this school. Salary will be allowed at the rate of $90.00 a teaching month.

You should have Mr. Conway complete and return as soon as possible the staff questionnaire forwarded to you in my letter of August 31st.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

H. Graham, Esq.,

March 31, 1939.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

The Acting Agent at Duncan has reported that Mr. Conway, teacher of the Cowichan Indian Day School, has had to discontinue his work at the school due to an infected hand and arm. The Doctor has advised that Mr. Conway will be unable to resume his duties for at least ten days.

On receipt of this information, I consulted Inspector Barry, who suggested the school be closed and remain so until after the Easter holidays. I concurred in this and so instructed Mr. Moore. It was considered that it would be better to follow this course than to arrange for a substitute teacher for the short period between now and the commencement of the Easter holidays on April 5th. I trust this action meets with your approval.

The Department will be advised should Mr. Conway not be able to resume his work after the Easter recess.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,

Your action in allowing the school to remain closed until after the Easter holidays is approved.

Mr. Indian Agent Moore included in the current year's estimates for the Cowichan Indian Agency an amount of $600.00 to re-shingle the roof of the old Cowichan Indian Day School, and carry out other necessary repairs and improvements to the building with a view to its eventual use for school purposes by the pupils now attending the Sokolish Indian Day School. The question of the transfer of the Sokolish school to the old Cowichan Indian school building is one that should, in my opinion, be held in abeyance until the Inspector of Schools is appointed and has an opportunity to pass on the proposal. In the meantime, however, I feel that we should re-shingle the roof of the Cowichan Day School building in order to prevent deterioration of the structure and would recommend that the necessary authority be issued for this purpose. The Department's decision at an early date would be appreciated.

Former Cowichan Indian Day School

I have for answer your letter - 3-11-1 - of September 27, which has necessitated a considerable review of old files in order to thoroughly investigate this whole matter.

In a letter of June 2, 1944, Mr. Moore stated that there was not available in his office a copy of the survey made of this site in 1937. Therefore I am enclosing an extra copy which I discovered on one of our old files. If you so desire this can be forwarded to him. It is understood that in 1938 the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada offered to transfer this property to the Department for school purposes. I enclose a copy of the letter dated July 18, 1938, which was received by the Department at that time. It was decided, in view of the recommendation of the then Indian Agent, Mr. Graham, that nothing should be done in this regard. Would you now wish that the United Church be approached regarding the transfer of this property to the Department?

It is felt that the old Cowichan School is unsatisfactory for use as a school for the following reasons:

(a) The lighting in this school is very poor and does not meet the required standards.

(b) The question of transporting the United Church children to this school will probably necessitate the contracting for additional bus service.

...... (c)
(c) As pointed out in a previous letter (our 152-34-1 of August 1, 1944), the Department is not enthusiastic about moving the Koksihlah Day School to within such a short distance of the St. Catherine's Day School.

It is not our desire to enter into a long correspondence over this matter and we concur in your recommendation that this whole question of the transfer be held in abeyance until your Inspector of Schools has an opportunity to pass on the proposal.

In view of the heavy expenditures of recent months, it is regretted that we are unable to provide the funds necessary to re-shingle the roof of this school, as requested.

Encl.

Bernard F. Neary,

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Ottawa, February 22nd, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, informing the Department that, on account of an outbreak of flu among the children, you ordered the Cowichan Indian Day School to be closed for one month. In this connection it is noted that there was no possibility of obtaining an attendance of more than one pupil during the above mentioned period. Your action in having the school closed is approved.

It is hoped, however, that the children will recover at an early date and that the school will not remain closed any longer than absolutely necessary. As you are aware, there has been difficulty from the commencement of this school in getting the children to attend, and owing to the poor results that have been achieved, it is hoped that the school will be reopened at an early date. I shall be pleased to hear later as to the date this school reopens.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. H. Lomas, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duncan, B.C.

Duncan, B. C.

January 14th, 1930

Sir:

In connection with Day School Teachers salaries in this Agency, I would most respectfully request that the good teachers not have to wait the whole quarter for their salaries, some of whom have relatives dependent on them, which under the present system necessitates them making loans at 6% interest to tide them over. I have taken the matter up with Mr. Ditchburn, Indian Commissioner for B. C., who informs me that in some parts of the Province, advances have been made towards the middle of the quarter, which would greatly assist.

The Department undoubtedly have their rules on this matter, but if I may, I would like to suggest that the teachers in the West draw their monthly salary. You will understand by the time the quarterly returns can be checked over and forwarded from this office, it would take approximately 6 days and allowing for a few days in your offices, and a fortnight in both ways mail dispatch, puts them far behind those who are closer to your headquarters.

I submit this merely as a suggestion, and I feel you will treat the same without prejudice, knowing as you do the great distance between Ottawa and our Coast.

Your obedient servant,

(Alfred H. Lomas)
Indian Agent.

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Superintendent of Indian Education

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have before me a letter from Rev. Father Lauzon, S.M.M., of the Catholic Indian Mission, Duncan, dealing with the transportation of Indian children in the Duncan School district of the Cowichan Agency. You will recall that an arrangement was made last year whereby the Department allowed Father Lauzon $175.00 per school year for the transportation of ten children in his own car to and from the School, but this only makes provision for the transportation of a small percentage of the children.

It would appear that 36 children now attending school should have transportation and, of these, 23 are pupils of the Cowichan Day School and the remaining 13 attend the Koksilah Day School. It has been suggested that a one-ton regulation school bus, as described in the attached letter from the International Harvester Co. of Canada Ltd., would suit our requirements. General Motors also supply a one-ton bus for $100.00 less, but for the difference in price the International would probably be more satisfactory. In addition to the capital outlay involved, an allowance of approximately $800.00 would have to be provided to meet the costs of operation and maintenance. Father Lauzon would be responsible for the transportation of the children and the care and maintenance of the motor vehicle supplied. The amount asked for operation and maintenance ($800.00) is based on a mileage cost of 13 cents per mile and is considered reasonable when compared with transportation costs as paid by the Municipality of Duncan for the transportation of white children in the same area.

It will be recalled that in the Duncan School survey dated July 23rd, 1937, Inspector Barry recommended a consolidated improved Indian Day School for to take care of the children attending the Cowichan Day School and children of school age not at present attending any school. If approved, such a School would not lessen the need of transportation for a large number of the children, indeed, more children would be attending school for which transportation would be necessary than at present.

If funds are available, I would recommend a one-ton school bus be supplied and that a grant on a mileage basis be allowed Father Lauzon for the operation and maintenance of the bus. Should funds not be available, I would suggest that the arrangement we now have with Father Lauzon be continued.

Yours faithfully,

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, ONT.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

I am delighted to say however that through the kindness of the local Inspector, under whom I once taught, I was shown the blue print plans of a splendid four room Provincial Day School built in a square as suggested by Mr. Hoey.

This school has teachers' rooms and a basement divided into four playrooms, one under each room. Toilets are outside and no doubt of the dry earth type, pits being dug.

Some local plumbing was done at a cost of $116.50 but the contract price of the splendid four room school was only $6,209.80.

I would ask that the contents of this letter be considered as strictly confidential as I am dealing with matters of a Provincial Department of Education of which I am not supposed to have any official knowledge.

Further I have no reason to believe that there would be any difficulty in obtaining the blue prints of this particular four room school, which I have examined or rather just seen. May I suggest that you as Indian Commissioner apply to the Department of Public Works or the Architects Branch of the Provincial Government for one or more blue prints of the new four room school just erected at Yarrow, though the plans were drawn for Sumas. The particular plan that Mr. Hoey would want is numbered 845 and dated Public Works 1936. Such plans would probably cost $1.00 each.

This plan with modifications to be suggested by Mr. Hoey would no doubt be perfectly satisfactory for the proposed Consolidated School near Duncan.

The fitting up and even the arrangement of the rooms could of course be changed in the Ottawa plans which would have to be drawn before tenders were called for by the Department. Such changes might add greatly to the cost of the school.

I must also point out that the extraordinary low contract price of $6,209.80 for this school was put in by a local firm, from Chilliwack I believe, who are said to have made only wages out of this job. It was stated to me by the Provincial Inspector that I might add 50% to the above contract price to obtain a duplicate building near Duncan. Even then the total price of the school building would be under $9,000 and the completed school might not cost in excess of $15,000.

My estimate of $50,000 would appear to be too great under present conditions, and I am confident that the type of school suggested by Mr. Hoey, without gymnasium, kitchen, living quarters etc., could be erected and equipped for under the $20,000 he mentions.

It is hoped that the above confidential information will be of assistance to the Department.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
I am sorry to say that I do not like the modified water system mentioned by Mr. Hoey.

Boat building is not very necessary here, and a few benches placed along the side of the boys' basement would probably provide all the accommodation necessary. There would have to be cupboards for tools etc., but in this letter I am not going into details.

My own view is that the present Indian Day School called the Cowichan School is not worth moving to the site proposed for the new school. As the distance is not great, about a mile I should say, such a move could of course be arranged. The distance between the present site of the Cowichan Indian Day School and the proposed site of the new school would make any supervision of vocational work by the Sisters impossible should such work be carried on in the old school, where it now stands.

May I say in confidence that Mr. Hoey's suggestion that there would be no need for a Principal other than the Sister Superior, if the Sisters of St. Anne took charge, would be objected to by the Catholic Church authorities, I have reason to think.

Father Lauzon intimated to me that he wanted a male teacher for the older boys. The Manual Training Instructor would be a man of course.

I am of the opinion that the Sisters of St Ann could very well supervise the whole school, including the older boys few if any of whom would be above 15 years of age.

With Sisters and men on the staff of the school I suggested that the Catholic Missionary, in the present case, Rev. Father Lauzon, would be the most suitable to place in nominal charge of the school.

With regard to the second last paragraph of Mr. Hoey's letter of October 4th and acting on your instructions I may say that I visited the office of one of the local Provincial School Inspector's this morning.

I took up the cost of erection of Provincial Schools in places near large towns such as Victoria and Vancouver and was pleased to find that the cost of one, two, and four room day schools has been greatly reduced since I had anything to do with such schools.

I would say for Mr. Hoey's information and more or less in confidence, that the sum of $5,000 per room suggested in paragraph two of page two of his letter, and my own estimate of around $4,000 per room in B.C. are well in excess of present costs, if schools near Vancouver are to be taken as standard.

A very fine two room school with teachers' room, and double basement, with toilet accommodation water being laid on and central heating, electric light etc., cost at Stillwater near Powell River not more than $4,500. I have seen a photograph of this school which compares favourably with the new Indian Day School at Port Simpson though with less accommodation.

I may say that the Provincial Inspector considers the Stillwater School a highly satisfactory one. The basement is above ground.

Dear Major MacKay:

At your request I have read Mr. Hoey's letter 152-22-1 of October 4th last with regard to certain suggested modifications in my recommendations for the construction of a Consolidated Indian Day School in the Cowichan Agency near Duncan.

I certainly agree with Mr. Hoey that many items might be eliminated from those suggested in my letter of July 16th 1938 if it is necessary to cut down the cost of the school.

My letter and previous Survey Report of July 8, 1937 were made with great care and are I believe sound from a professional point of view. This does not mean that modifications could not be made. I am inclined to think that the Reverend Father Lauzon is requesting rather more than is necessary.

A square four room school with full basement accommodation would supply all that is necessary for the present.

In B.C., we find that basements should be above ground and not two thirds underground as suggested by Mr. Hoey. There is too great a danger of flooding in our rather wet climate. Even in the dry belt they are as a rule erected above ground.

Kitchens can be eliminated if the noon meal is just a lunch that could be heated on an electric stove in the room used as a lunch room for the children. Even tables in the basement on the boys' side and on the girls' side would be quite suitable and eliminate even a lunch room.

Living accommodation for a member of the staff might be eliminated in the simple school proposed by Mr. Hoey.

Inside toilets are better than those outside and at the rear of a school. Water is necessary for inside toilets and a septic tank is necessary, and is recommended by me still. I believe that a good water supply could be obtained by sinking a well on the property suggested for the school and now owned by Mrs Sammy Bob, which is by far the best site for the proposed school.

Dear Sir:

Re Your File 152-22-1.

I have to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of October 4th, and subsequent correspondence, regarding the proposed consolidated Indian Day School near Duncan, Cowichan Agency, and in this connection beg to advise that two blueprints of the plan of the 4-room day school erected by the Provincial Government at Yarrow, referred to by Capt. Barry in his letter of October 31st, a copy of which was submitted with my letter of November 8th, file 15/3/6632, are being forwarded this day under separate cover. This plan, with whatever modifications are considered necessary by the Department would no doubt meet our requirements.

As stated by Capt. Barry, most of our school basements in this Province are built in line with, or above, the ground level, this being found more suitable owing to climatic conditions.

Before finally deciding on the site for the proposed school, the question of a good and sufficient water supply will have to be gone into carefully, and in this connection it may be necessary to have some investigation work made by our engineering Branch. Should our requirements in this connection be found on the present school site, there would hardly be any need to consider the other site suggested, provided extra land could be acquired from James Capeal. The present school building could then be utilized for vocational work, and so divided that a section of it could be used for the manufacture of Cowichan sweaters and other woolen articles under the supervision of a member of the school staff. Should circumstances be such, however, that it will be necessary to acquire the acreage owned by Mrs. Sammy Bob, as recommended by Capt. Barry, a small inexpensive separate building for vocational training, where the manufacture of Cowichan sweaters...
sweaters could, to an important extent, be centralized under proper supervision, would have to be provided, as the distance from this site to the present Cowichan Day School would preclude supervision by the school staff, which is considered desirable.

Well constructed outside toilets with the usual screens and proper ventilation vents would probably do for the present. This is what is usually provided by the Province where connection with established water and sewerage systems is costly. The necessary pipe fittings for inside toilets and wash basins could be placed in the building when it is being built, so that these additions could be installed at any time the Department wishes to do so, should an adequate water supply be available.

I trust the plan being forwarded will be helpful to the Department in preparing final plans for the proposed consolidated school.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Major MacKay:

As requested I have read through the Specifications for the proposed Consolidated Indian Day School, Cowichan Agency, and also examined with some care the Blue Prints.

In general I believe that the building suggested will be most satisfactory. There are however several matters which I wish to raise now. These will not hinder a start being made but should be brought to the attention of the Department.

Two toilets of simple outdoor type have been allowed for and it is possible the male members of the staff might use the toilet set aside for the boys. I believe that as Sisters of St Ann will be employed a separate toilet should be erected in a convenient place for their use. I regret that it was not found possible to arrange for inside toilets.

(2) No Luncheon Room appears to have been provided though perhaps it is intended to use the Cooking and Sewing Rooms for such a purpose. I think it would be possible for the boys to use one of these rooms and the girls the other.

The transportation of children to the Cowichan Indian Day School is now being looked after by one of the local Catholic Priests, but such an arrangement might not be possible after the Consolidated School is in working use. Transportation was mentioned on Pages 15 and 16 of my Duncan School Survey Report of July 8th 1937, and in my letter of July 16th 1938.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

In accordance with your instructions, a test well has been dug on the new school site, Section 17, Range 1, Cowichan District. This well is situated 235 feet west of the western boundary of the church property and 33 feet south of the power line along the south side of the Tzouhalem road, in approximately the same location as suggested by Mr. G.H. Whyte in a report dated April 27, 1939.

The well was excavated six feet square for the first ten feet and then reduced to four feet square from ten feet to twenty-five foot depth. The underlying strata being as follows:

- 0 ft. to 1 ft. - Top soil
- 1 ft. to 13 ft. - Hard Clay
- 13 ft. to 19 ft. - Hard Clay with very thin layer of fine sand.
- 19 ft. to 25 ft. - Medium grain sand and gravel.

The level of the ground water was found to be at a depth of 24 feet. At first the water was extremely rusty coloured but constant bailing removed much of this discoloration. The rusty colour was due to stirring up of the sand while excavating, for after bailing the well out so that the bottom was exposed, clear water flowed in from all sides of the well. Left overnight, the water in the well became almost clear. This would indicate that after using the well for a short period of time, the water will be perfectly clear. After

C.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water and Power Bureau,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
bailing for an hour, the rate of inflow was tested and found to be approximately 80 gallons per hour. Deeper excavation would increase the flow considerably, as at present, the bottom of the well is only one foot below ground water level.

The depth of the well should be increased by eight to ten feet, unless clay is struck sooner, making a total depth of thirty-three to thirty-five feet below the surface. This would allow for lowering of the ground water level in the dry season and also provide a small amount of storage.

The present rate of inflow would be sufficient for school needs, but there is no assurance of the adequacy of the supply in the dry season until the well has been in use for one season and the flow compared with other wells in the same locality.

An investigation of some other wells in the vicinity showed Mrs. Sammy Bob's well, a few hundred yards west of the school site, to be 23 feet deep and it is reported to have an ample supply of water for domestic use except in very dry years. Mr. Johnson's well, about 100 yards west and on the north side of the road, is 12 feet deep and has ample supply for gardening and house use all year. A well due north of the new school site is about 16 feet deep and has a shortage of water in November and December. Father Lemon's well, about one mile south-east, is 40 feet deep and has a sufficient supply of water. On the property adjoining Father Lemon's is another well, located in the swamp, which is 12 feet deep and has ample water all year. This inves-
tigation indicates that the test well on the new school site will probably yield sufficient water.

As suggested in Mr. G.H. Whyte's report, water could be supplied through a hydrant if a small electric pump were installed. The cost of connecting up to such a pump would be small as the transmission line of the Nanaimo Duncan Utilities Ltd. follows the main road on the north boundary of the property. The minimum power rate is $5.00 per month, which allows a consumption of 60 K.W. hrs. The cost of operating a small pumping unit should not exceed this minimum charge.

As there is no definite assurance of a sufficient supply of water in the driest portion of the year, until the well has been used for one season, it would be advisable to use wood cribbing for lining the well rather than a more permanent lining. At present the well is not cribbed but temporary wood cribbing could be installed at a comparatively small cost. As the well is to be about thirty-five feet deep, it will be necessary to place the pumping unit about fifteen feet below the ground level. The six-foot square excavation will make a satisfactory location for a pump house. It would be advisable to have openings in the cribbing from the 20-foot to 35-foot depth and to surround it with well graded gravel. This would insure a maximum rate of flow into the well.

The estimated cost of completing the test well and installing an electric pump ready for school use is given in Appendix "A".
The test well indicates that sufficient water is available but this can be assured only by using the well for one season. It will be necessary to excavate the present well eight to ten feet deeper, making a total depth of 33 to 35 feet. It would be advisable to line the well with wood cribbing which would have a life of at least fifteen years. Using wood cribbing an estimated expenditure of $742.00 would be necessary to complete the well. This amount would include the installation of an electric pump and an Eclipse hydrant.

Your obedient servant,

W.V. McDonald

PARTICULARS & DIMENSIONS OF SCHOOL BUSES (MAXIMUM SIZE) FOR THE GUIDANCE OF MECHANICAL SUPERVISORS AND BODY BUILDERS, IN CONNECTION WITH THE BUILDING OF SCHOOL BUSES.

(Buses having a smaller carrying capacity to be patterned in proportion to satisfaction of Mechanical Inspector.)

REGULATION #21, Motor-Vehicle Act. Revised Statutes of B.C. 1936, Chapter 195 as amended by Chapter 54 of the Statutes of B.C. 1937. Regulations made by Order-in-Council #660, approved May 19th, 1938.

The following extracts from the Regulations are quoted for your information and guidance:

Regulation #21 (a) - "Interpretation":
In this Regulation, unless the context otherwise requires:- "Mechanical Inspector" means any person authorized by the Commissioner in writing to inspect and pass upon the fitness of school buses;
"Permittee" means the person to whom a permit is issued by the Commissioner for the operation of a school bus;
"School Bus" means a motor-vehicle used for the conveyance of children to and from school, and operated by or under contract with the Board of School Trustees or other authority in charge of the school, but does not include a motor-vehicle duly licensed under Part V of the "Highway Act" as a public passenger vehicle.

Regulation #21 (b) - "Inspection and Permit":
No motor-vehicle shall be used as a school bus until it has been submitted to the Mechanical Inspector for inspection and a permit for its use pursuant to this regulation has been obtained from the Commissioner. The Mechanical Inspector may, after satisfactory inspection of the motor-vehicle as to mechanical fitness, construction, equipment and seating capacity, may subject it to any test which he considers necessary, and he shall report the result of his inspection to the Commissioner for consideration in dealing with the application for the permit.

The permittee and every person in charge of a school bus shall upon the request of any officer or constable of the Provincial Police, forthwith take the school bus to a place designated by the officer or constable, and shall submit the same for inspection and testing. Where in the opinion of any officer or constable of the Provincial Police a school bus is unfit for the carrying of school children, no person shall operate such school bus or cause it to be operated on any highway for the purpose of carrying school children until the defect causing such unfitness has been remedied to the satisfaction of the officer or constable.

Copies of the Regulations pursuant to the Motor-Vehicle Act (Regulation #21 dealing with construction, equipment and operation of School Buses) may be obtained from the King's Printer, Victoria, B.C., upon payment of the required fee.

1. Chassis: The gross vehicle weight of a fully loaded bus must not exceed the manufacturers' gross allowable weight as fixed by the official in charge of the engineering department of the manufacturer of the Chassis. This shall be interpreted as the advertised maximum gross vehicle weight as shown in the manufacturers' advertising literature describing such chassis. (Gross vehicle weight means the actual weight of the chassis plus the actual weight of the body plus the weight of driver at 175lb and weight of pupils at 100lb each.) The wheel base of any chassis as originally supplied by the manufacturer must not be altered in any manner.

Tractor or trailer type vehicles where driver is separated from passengers are not approved for use as school buses.
2. Seating and Aisles:

**Seating:**

No passenger shall be seated forward of entrance door of any school bus. All school buses with a seating capacity for over twelve pupils shall have forward facing seats except that, where necessary, short longitudinal seats will be permitted over rear wheel housings.

| Seat Type                        | Minimum Requirements |
|----------------------------------|----------------------|
| Longitudinal type seating        | 18" per pupil at seat base line |
| Rear Cross Seat (full width of body) | 15"                  |
| Forward facing seats (not more than three pupils each seat) | 18"                  |

Seat centers (forward facing type) to be not less than 24". Seat depth to be not less than 14" in all types of seating.

Height shall not be less than 36" from floor and not more than 18" to top of cushioned seat back line.

All school buses equipped with forward facing seats shall have a suitable type guard rail located forward of the right front seat to prevent children in such seat from being thrown into stop well in case of sudden stop. This guard rail to be secured to a stanchion to be located between driver's seat and center line. Minimum clearance between stanchion and driver's seat to be 24".

Aisles shall be provided to accommodate pupil school cases in overhead racks. All forward type seating overhead racks shall not extend toward the center of the bus past the center line of the seats. Any racks so constructed shall be arranged in such a manner that books and utensils cannot fall out on pupils' heads. In no case where overhead racks are installed shall they interfere with head clearance.

**Aisles:**

Center height (forward facing seats) 11" at seat base line. Aisle width shall be increased by tapering seat backs 2½" from seat base line.

Emergency Exit Aisle: An unobstructed aisle of at least 12½" in width to lead to emergency door. This measurement to be taken at seat base line.

3. Doors:

There shall be no door on left front of bus, provided that panel-type delivery vehicle converted for school bus purposes may retain the door, as provided by the manufacturer of the body, at the left front of the vehicle.

Entrance doors to be of folding type only and located at right front of the vehicle. Width: Minimum horizontal clearance 24".

Height: Maximum height in accordance with body construction as measured from top of lower entrance step to roof. Entrance doors shall be provided with glass window in upper and lower portions and these windows shall be of such size and location as to provide adequate vision by the driver to the right. Windows in lower panels shall be of such size and location as to give adequate vision of the road surface to the right of the entrance door by the driver.

Provided that vehicles of the panel-delivery type converted for school bus purposes may retain the sedan type one piece door as supplied by the manufacturer of the body.

All types of entrance doors shall be mechanically controlled by the driver unless located in the driver's seat. Doors operated by vehicle motor shall have a reserve tank or auxiliary mechanical control.

Door jams, etc., shall be provided with good quality rubberized fabric or equivalent at all points to protect children's fingers, etc., and eliminate draft and noise, etc., from entering those points.
Entrance Door Steps: All stops at entrance door shall be provided with slip proof stool or covered with equally effective slip proof material and must be constructed so that risers shall be proportioned over bowing between stops and floor level, and in no case shall be more than 15" in height. Top of first step shall not exceed 18" in height from ground surface, depth to be not less than 12". Stops must be enclosed to prevent accumulation of ice and snow and shall not protrude beyond the side body line.

A suitable grab rail shall be provided inside entrance door to assist pupils in getting on or off the bus.

4. Emergency Door:
Emergency door shall be located at left rear side of body only and hinged at the forward edge and shall provide an unobstructed opening of not less than 24" horizontal clearance and 48" vertical clearance. (Provided that vehicle of panel delivery type when converted for school bus purposes may be equipped with an emergency door at the rear. This door shall be the door as supplied by the manufacturer of the body and must be hinged on its vertical edge.)

Emergency door shall be provided with approved latch control. This control to be of such type as to allow opening of door from inside or outside.

Inside latch control to be provided with a safety device to prevent accidental release yet operation of same must be obvious to school children.

Outside latch control must not project beyond the body side.

5. Glass:
All glass in windows and doors, etc., shall be of safety type. No unpolished or unground edges shall be accessible to pupils. Glass of wire-mesh type shall not be used in any part of the body.

6. Windows:
All side windows, with the exception of the emergency door window, shall lower 18" only from the top except window to the left of the driver and this window shall lower fully into body side or be of sliding divided type. Lower sill of left front window must be on a level plane with the lower sill of the windshield.

The windshield shall be of laminated safety plate glass and shall be sloped slightly to prevent glare from other lights and large enough to permit the driver to have clear view of the road. The glass must be of sufficient quality to prevent distortion of view from any direction.

7. Ventilation: All school bus bodies shall be equipped with a suitably controlled ventilating system of sufficient capacity to maintain the proper quantity of air under operating conditions. No intake ventilators shall be placed in the front of the body above the windshield line. In hooded type of the ventilating type, one hooded intake ventilator for every ten pupils based on seating capacity of the school bus shall be provided, but static exhaust roof ventilators shall not be placed to the rear of center of body. Too boards, dashboards, and other parts of the body must be so constructed as to exclude all motor fumes and gases from the interior of the body.

8. Heating:
Hot water or approved type hot air if required. Exhaust type heaters not approved.

9. Color:
The body of every new school bus put into service after August 1st, 1949, and of every school bus repainted after said date shall be painted school bus yellow except that any body moulding thereon shall be black.

10. Gasoline Tank:
All gasoline tanks shall be installed below the body floor line and provided with a filler spout of not less than 10" in height as measured from the upper surface of the tank and must be vented and filled from outside the bus body. The filler cap must not project...
11. Interior Lights:
The interior of the bus shall be lighted with adequate lights so arranged as to light up the whole of the interior except that portion occupied by the driver.

12. Body and Chassis:
Maximum overall length of any school bus must not exceed 30'.
Maximum overall width 8'.
Bodies may be of steel or composite type (wood and metal). Bodies shall be strong enough to withstand great impact through accident or collision. Construction must provide a reasonably dust and water tight unit.
Interior clearance height shall be not less than 66" at all points as measured at longitudinal center line to center line of rear cross side. (This shall not apply to vehicles of the panel delivery type and converted for school bus purposes.)

13. Bumpers:
Substantial bumpers shall be mounted on the front and rear of the vehicle and must be securely anchored to the chassis.

14. Guard Rails:
Guard rails of ample strength (at least two each side) shall be provided to resist impact and to prevent the body side from being crushed in case of accident, and provide a rub-rail for protection in case of side-swiping. One of these rails to be located at the seat line for maximum protection of the passengers, and all rails should extend from the front to rear of the bus on both sides.

15. Exhaust:
The motor exhaust shall be carried to 3' beyond the rear of the body skirt in an airtight steel tube and muffler, and not beyond rear bumper.

16. Fire Extinguisher:
Each school bus shall be equipped with the pump or pressure non-freezing type of fire extinguisher of not less than one quart capacity, which shall be located in the forward end of the bus easily accessible to the driver and near the entrance door.

17. Signs:
All school buses shall display signs as stated hereunder:
Body: Front Above windshield and on outside of body displaying the words "School Bus".
Rear Above or below the rear windows displaying the words "School Bus".
Size of lettering of above must not be less than 6" in height. Lettering must be unshaded black and background of sign must be school bus yellow.

Emergency Door: All emergency doors shall be provided with signs as follows:
1. "Emergency Door" letters not less than 2½" high, located so as to be plainly visible, in black letters on school bus yellow. To be placed on inside and outside of door.
2. "Use of this door prohibited by Law, except in case of emergency." Letters 1¾" high on inside of door. Black letters on school bus yellow.

18. Mirrors:
Every school bus shall be equipped with one interior non-glare mirror at least 4" in height and 15" in width. Located so that a complete view of the interior of the bus as well as a view through the rear bus windows can be had by the driver.
An exterior rear non-glare mirror not less than 6" diameter, or if rectangular 4"x 6", shall be installed on the left front corner of the bus to afford the driver a view of the highway along the left side and to the rear of the bus.
19. Windshield Wipers:
Two units in order that driver may have a view to front and right as well as directly ahead. Electric, vacuum or pressure type, capable of manual operation in case of emergency.

20. Reflex Reflectors:
There shall be two reflex reflectors mounted on the right and left corners of the rear of the bus 36" from the road surface and so located as to reflect the rays of light from lights of approaching vehicles. These reflectors must be of a type approved by the Commissioner, B.C. Police, under Regulation 3 (d) of the Motor-Vehicle Act and shall not be less than 4" in diameter for buses over 12 pupil carrying capacity.

21. Clearance Lights:
Every school bus shall be equipped with clearance lights as defined in Regulation 3 (e) of the Motor-Vehicle Act Regulations.

22. Stop Signals:
Every school bus shall be equipped with a stop signal light. This light must display the word "Stop" and must be of at least 4" in diameter. Provided that on vehicles of a carrying capacity of 12 pupils or less regular stop light as supplied by the manufacturer of the vehicle will be satisfactory. Stop lights to be mounted to the left of the center line of the rear of the body.

23. Signal Devices:
In the case of a school bus which is so constructed that any part of the vehicle extends 24" or more to the left of the center of the steering wheel, such school bus shall be equipped with an approved signalling device to indicate the turning, stopping or changing course on the highway of such school bus.

24. Alteration to Body:
No person shall change, reconstruct, materially alter, modify or add to the body or seating capacity of any school bus without the written approval of the Commissioner or Mechanical Inspector.

25. Wheel Housings:
If wheel housings protrude within the body of the bus they shall be so constructed that pupils will have normal comfortable seating positions as approved by Mechanical Inspector.

NOTE:
No attempt has been made here to compile a complete list of specifications for a school bus. The legal requirements of proper brakes, headlights, tail-light, steering apparatus, tires, etc., must be complied with.

Any further information dealing with the construction of school buses, as required under the "Motor-Vehicle Act" and Regulations, may be obtained from the nearest Mechanical Inspector, B.C. Police, at Nelson, Kamloops, Vancouver or Victoria.

Geo. A. Hood,
Inspector O/C Motor Branch,
for Commr. B. C. Police

Attention of Mr Hoey:
Dear Sir:

Due to your very appreciated cooperation in the matter, our school attendance is ever increasing and by the beginning of next month, October, 1939, when most of all our Indian children will be back from the hop fields, at least fifty (50) and most probably more will need transportation to and from our Cowichan and Koksilah Day Schools.

In order to provide them all with the necessary transportation, I will have to multiply the trips and consequently the expenses. Would you kindly have approved by the proper authorities an increase in the allowance, at the actual per capita monthly rate of $1.75.

At present for thirty (30) children, I receive monthly, $52.50. Therefore $87.50 would allow me to give service to at least fifty (50), and this starting October 1st, 1939, until with the opening of the new school a more adequate means of transportation will be provided for.

As you know by experience that much time and energy have been spent to train our children to regular school attendance, it would be both deplorable for the children who are disposed to attend and also for ourselves after our efforts if we cannot meet this emergency. But on my part on account of the extra expense, unless an extra allowance is approved, I feel I could not serve more than thirty (30) children, as I am now doing.

As the above request for an increased grant is for an immediate emergency, I would be very obliged to you for immediate attention.

May I assure you of my eager desire to cooperate to the success of your work as a whole.

I am very truly yours,

Dear Sir,

I arrived here, a week, last Saturday. Since then, I have been busy studying the requirements of the new school. After conferring with Rev. Mother General of the Sisters of St. Ann, I have a number of alterations, that I would like to submit to the Department.

There is no room provided for an office, where the records could be kept, where officials would be received, and where doctors or nurses could examine the children. This same room would also be required for the good management of the school, so that the teacher will be at the head of the school could confer with members of the staff. Another reason why that room would be needed is that it is to speak to the children. It is a fact of experience, that Indian children, once they grow up, are not to be reprimanded in public.

Another such a room would also be required for the Sisters. If they have to spend the whole day at the school, they should have place to retire. I have spoken with the Superintendent of the builders, and he agrees that it would be easy to move the partitions between the wardrobes and the class-rooms, so as to change two wardrobes into rooms large enough for the purposes mentioned above. Any of the wardrobes upstairs, could be used for that purpose.

There would be left two wardrobes upstairs, which could be used by the girls while the store room could be turned in to wardrobes for boys.

Referring to Father Leclair's letter of Aug. 26th, I beg to inform you that no answer giving a decision on the matter of having an inside toilet for the staff, has been received. After going over the matter, with Mother General, I agreed to make a new application which we think is necessary for a group of sisters.

It was also suggested that for the sake of keeping that school clean in winter time, it would be very desirable to have two more toilets for the children, so that class hours, at least, the children would not have to run out in the mud. This matter should be settled very soon, because the sewer pipes will be put in soon and the cement floor put in.

During my first visit in Ottawa, I spoke to Mr. Phelan, about a room to be used for a dining-room. He told me that although the plans did not provide for such a room, yet with the space we would fit in the building, it would be easy to secure such a room. After looking at the plans, the only solution would be to take the actual sewing room for that purpose, and put the sewing room in one of the class rooms where there will more light.

Mother General suggested that between the kitchen and the proposed dining-room, no partition would be needed. Folding doors could also be used there. The actual partition, is only a light one which could be removed, as it does not support any of the superstructure. Whether the Department provides the lunch for the children, or they have to secure their own, it would be better to have a dining-room than to let them eat in the class-rooms. The purpose of leaving the two rooms in one is to have more room for a dining place.

R. A. Hoey, sq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training

AIR MAIL

Dear Father Lauzon:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo in connection with the new Cowichan school. I have carefully considered the contents of your letter and have also reviewed the plans.

Permit me to point out that it is our desire that the new school be conducted as a day school. Under these circumstances it is not possible nor feasible to provide rooms for every purpose. The plans show that the class rooms, sewing room, kitchen and vocational rooms are sufficiently large for the purposes for which they are intended. While it may be a slight inconvenience to the members of the staff to permit the pupils to eat their lunch in one or other of the class rooms I think you will agree that it would not be possible to supply a special room for this purpose as such a room would only be required for a short time each day.

It is our desire that the building be used in the manner in which it is being constructed. I have, however, arranged for provision to be made for the stove pipe from the stove in the kitchen to the chimney.

I am informed by the Surveys & Engineering Branch that a separate toilet is being provided for the members of the staff.

If hot water is required it can be heated on the stove. We cannot supply hot water connections because this would involve a great deal of additional expense and upkeep. The same applies when the matter of installing inside toilets.

Rev. Father Lauzon, S.M.M.,
Catholic Indian Mission,
Duncan, B.C.
is considered. Such an installation would necessitate additional piping and a septic tank. As a matter of fact arrangements are being made to have a sink installed in the kitchen with a waste pipe leading to the drain. A connection is also being made to the well so that water may be obtained at the sink.

I feel certain that when you have reconsidered the matter you will agree with me that the present layout of the building is all that can be expected in an Indian day school. Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 28th inst., regarding information for a School Bus which it is proposed to purchase for the use of the Cowichan Day School. Dear Sir:

During the recent visit of Mr. P. Phelan to this Agency and our conversation regarding the transportation of children to the new Cowichan Day School, now in course of construction, he asked me to get particulars of a suitable School Bus from one of the local dealers.

I did this getting the particulars from Wilson & Cabeldu Ltd., who in turn had to get the information from Vancouver, B. C. This is a 30 passenger bus, which it was felt would be more suitable than a 20 passenger.

Mr. Phelan asked me to send the particulars to him as soon as I could but felt that as it might be necessary to get further particulars from the General Motors Co. in Vancouver, and as you would probably wish to see the Bus, or one like it first; and will probably desire quotations from other firms, I am sending you in duplicate full particulars of the bus with specifications of body and motor as well as prices covering the whole job.

It would appear to be a better arrangement if the manufacturers in Vancouver would quote to you direct for the dealers here have got to get the information there before passing it on to me. As soon as you can deal with this I would respectfully request that you submit the enclosed quotations to the Department as soon as possible. Please understand that the new Chassis will be out in another few weeks, the prices for which may be a little different from those quoted.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter, date and file number above noted, with reference to matters generally in connection with the new Cowichan Day School, also for copies of letters from Mr Hoey and Inspector Barry for which I thank you.

I am supposing that no comments are required from me in connection with the teaching staff of the School, as that has been all settled at least for the first year; however, I am strictly in accord with the suggestion that a Priest be not appointed Principal. However, I am doubtful about the success generally if the Sisters of St. Ann are going to remain indefinitely in charge of the School, for the simple reason that the Indians as a whole are inclined to take more interest in what their boys learn at School than their girls. I am also fearful about the attitude of the bigger boys to the Sisters, and feel that while the Sisters will probably give as good, or better, academical instruction in the class room as anyone else, nevertheless I feel that a man with organizing ability for grounds and outside work of the boys (such as gardening) is necessary as well as to keep the necessary discipline among the boys, and I am satisfied that the present teacher Mr Conway is not suitable for that, nor in my opinion to have charge of any Indian School. If we could get a male teacher with Manual training as well as class room qualifications and interested in gardening, who could also look after the physical training periods for both boys and girls and blessed with organizing ability, then I think you have the ideal man for the job as Principal.

Regarding the transportation question, I beg to attach herewith letters received from two local firms, operating several busses locally for the Schools and also for some of the large mills. From these letters you will please note that the prices are exactly the same, viz: $56.00 for a school week, or approximately $2240.00 per year. These prices include all necessary Insurance as apply at present to the white schools. On a five day basis this would mean an expenditure of $11,000. If we supplied our own bus and had a qualified driver and make him act as caretaker as well and pay him $150.00 per month for both jobs, figure an average weekly mileage of 150 miles for 24 weeks at a cost of 1¼ per mile for the full six months you will have an expenditure of $1437.60., as against $1344.00 offered by the Transportation Companies and we would still have to pay for the services of a caretaker for the school which should not be less, I think, than $75.00 per month or a total of $450.00 for six months, when added to the cost of transportation would be $1794.00. I believe it would be much cheaper for us to operate our own bus.

The question of transportation arrangements for the Indian children who will attend the new Consolidated Indian School at Duncan has been given considerable thought. The following courses are open to us:

(1) Transportation by Departmental bus.

(2) Transportation by arrangement with one of the local motor transportation companies.

Comparative costs are briefly summarized as follows:

(1) By Departmental Bus

(Considering original cost of bus at $3000)
Annual depreciation, insurance, licence fees, etc. $900.00

Operator's salary at $125.00 per month for 10 months, for which he would also do the janitor's work at the school: - 1250.00

Total - $2750.00

(2) By Motor Transportation Co.

Based on 197 school days, less 7 holidays, 190 days with daily mileage of 32 miles or 6080 miles per school year:

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Cowichan Consolidated Indian Day School,
Cowichan Indian Agency, Electoral District
of Nanaimo, B.C.

Provision for the erection of this school was made in the current year's appropriation and it is expected that the building will be completed for the middle of December.

As the majority of the children attending the school live at a considerable distance from it arrangements will have to be made for their transportation.

Indian Commissioner MacKay has given the matter very careful consideration and has submitted two propositions, one for the purchase of a bus by the Department and its operation by a man engaged by us or transportation by one of the local motor transportation companies.

Commissioner MacKay, after carefully considering both the above alternatives, writes, in part, as follows:

"Even if it should finally be established that the cost of operating a Departmental bus would actually be less than herein shown there is still the very great responsibility involved in the transportation of a large group of children to be considered. Careful consideration of the various angles of the transportation problem confronting us based on the information gathered leads me to..."
conclude that it would be safer, more satisfactory and as economical for us to make arrangements with one of the transportation companies for the transportation of the children."

Commissioner MacKay has submitted quotations for this service from the following firms:

1. Cowichan Valley Bus & Taxi Service, Duncan, B.C.
2. Vancouver Island Coach Lines Ltd., Duncan, B.C.

Each of these companies quotes the same price; namely, 35¢ a mile for a bus that would contain 30 passengers. The bus would have to travel 16 miles in the morning to pick up the children and the same distance in the afternoon to return them to their homes.

Both companies offer the same terms as regards insurance protecting the passengers in the case of accident.

I should appreciate it if you would advise me as soon as possible with which company you would prefer our completing arrangements. I might add that it is our intention to arrange for the service for the period January 1, 1940, to June 30, 1941.

PP.
