Dear Major MacKay:

As arranged I called on Mr. Indian Agent Moore on my arrival in Duncan on the afternoon of the 11th, and later went with him to see the new school building which will house the Cowichan Consolidated School.

As it was rather dark I visited the same building by myself the following morning, December 12th.

Mr Moore informs me that he has brought to your attention in previous letters and in one dated the 11th instant a number of most important matters relating to the equipment etc. and opening of the new school.

In this letter it is my desire to deal with only those items not as far as I know mentioned by Mr Moore. I believe that you would wish me to report on certain matters even if these were not as a rule such as come within my supervision.

Three classrooms are I understand to be used for academic work and the fourth for vocational training of girls in sewing, art and crafts etc. The school kitchen, lunch room and manual training shop are on the floor below the classrooms. The three classrooms used for academic work are here called the Senior Division, Junior Division, and Primary Division rooms.

There are available at the present Cowichan Day School 27 single Crown school desks, 9 being size No 2, 9 being size No. 3, and 9 being size No 4.

In the Senior Division room we shall need
21 only single desks No. 3
14 only single desks No. 2

In the Junior Division room we shall need
21 only single desks No. 3
14 only single desks No. 2
In the Primary Room we shall need

8 only single school desks No. 3
16 only single school desks No. 4
16 only single school desks No. 5

All the desks should be mounted on strips of wood
some 1½ in. by 4 ln. double dressed fir.

The desks in the Senior and Junior Divisions
should be arranged in five rows of seven each, while
in the Primary Division there should be five rows of eight.

The total number of NEW single school desks needed
will be as follows:

28 single school desks No. 2 less the 9 of this
size now at the Cowichan Day School or 19 new No. 2 desks.

50 single school desks No. 3 less the 9 of this
size now at the Cowichan Day School or 41 new No. 3 desks.

16 single school desks No. 4 less the 9 of this
size now at the Cowichan Day School or 7 new No. 4 desks.

16 single school desks No. 5 there being none of
this size at the Cowichan Day School or 16 new No. 5 desks.

No front or rear sections should be purchased at
this time. The 85 new desk sections with the 27 old desk
sections available will furnish seating for 30 pupils in
each of the Senior and Junior Divisions and 35 pupils in
the Primary Division, or for 95 children.

Four substantial teacher's desks will be needed, as
well as four teacher's chairs and eight visitors chairs for
the four classrooms.

In the vocational room in place of school desks we
shall need:

2 ordinary and 2 tailor type Singer treadle sewing
machines and 15 chairs for girls.

A large cutting out table and a teacher's table
will also be needed in this vocational or sewing room.

4 classroom clocks and one kitchen clock will be needed.

A suitable kitchen stove to burn coal and two large
kitchen tables will be needed in the kitchen.

In the lunch room six large trestle tables and
twelve forms will be required.

One large school bell and six small desk bells will
be needed.
The following articles will be most necessary:

**Furnace Room**
- 1 only coal shovel
- 1 long iron hook poker

**Entrances**
- Front: two large (at least 25in by 36in but larger if possible) coco door mats.
- one metal scraper mat
- Children's: four largest size coco door mats
- two metal scraper mats.

One large garbage can.

The three carpenter's benches, five small forms, one small sand table, one low kindergarten table, and all texts and other equipment now at the Cowichan Day School will of course have to be moved to the new school, and this equipment includes a few tools.

A flag pole and medium size Union-Jack flag will be needed at the new school.

While the lighting fixtures are in place, the school wired, and the electric light and power meter in place, there are no electric light bulbs at the school.

I have gone into the matter of lighting with some care and consulted the experts of the B.C.Electric Co., this morning. As a result of what I have learned I would recommend the supply of the following lights:

|---------------------------|--------------------------|
| Senior Division           | 6                        |
| Junior Division           | 6                        |
| Primary Division          | 6                        |
| Vocational Room           | 6                        |

| Hall                      | Lights of 200 watts each |
|---------------------------|--------------------------|

Lumber will be needed for the Manual Training and the strips to which the desks are to be fixed. A large number of cupboards and shelves will need to be constructed, and no doubt other articles for use in the school.

May I suggest that at least the sum of $200.00 be made available for dressed lumber, fir and pine. A number of tools additional to the small quantity from the present Cowichan Day School will be needed. These will cost about $150.00. A list could no doubt be prepared by the Manual Training Instructor later.
On December 11th I visited the Cowichan Indian Day School and the Koksilah Indian Day School, not to inspect but to find out as well as I could how many pupils might be expected at the new Cowichan Consolidated School on opening.

On the roll of the Cowichan Day School there are now some 66 children, of which only 13 boys and 19 girls were present on the morning of the 11th.

At the Koksilah Indian Day School there were 18 boys and 16 girls present out of a total 37.

Of the above 37 pupils only 22 are described as Roman Catholics by the teacher, Miss Perry. I am aware that some of the Roman Catholics at the Koksilah School may not wish to change to the new Cowichan Consolidated School, and it is very doubtful if we have the right to force the parents to send their children to the new Catholic school. It should be remembered that the Koksilah School is more or less undenominational though taught by a United Church girl.

There are some children not going to either of the present schools who should come to the new school.

From 80 to 90 pupils should be expected at the opening of the new school, and while force should not be used, I do think that the Catholic children should be encouraged in every way to attend the new school.

The provision of bread and soup, which I hope the Department will provide, should attract the children.

While I asked for four teachers at the new school in my letter of September 8th 1939 only three Sisters have been authorized. The plan outlined in my letter of September 8th could not be worked with three teachers. It will now be necessary to have boys and girls in the same academic classes, and under this arrangement it will be just possible I hope to arrange the teachers' work so that vocational as well as academic work can be taught.

I am to see the Sister Superior and Prefect of Studies this afternoon and I shall do all I can to assist first these Sisters of St. Ann to make out their requisition for supplies and later to assist the actual Sisters going to Cowichan with the organization of the classroom work.

The original requisition forwarded to Mr. Moore by the Sisters of St. Ann included many of the articles mentioned in this letter. Other articles, some necessary and some unused in our schools, were included, and as the requisition was in a form almost impossible for you to deal with, I am spending some time assisting the Sisters to draw up a better list of necessary articles, which I hope the Department will supply.

While I believe the teachers, Manual Training Instructor and Janitor should be at the new school from January 3rd, the day set for opening, I do not see how the classrooms could possibly be ready then for the children. May I suggest that the children do not attend the new school after the Christmas vacation till at the earliest Monday, January 8th, but much better Monday January 15th.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Plan New School For Island Indians

(Special to The Daily Province)

VANCOUVER, Dec. 5 — Facing Troublesome, near Quamichan Indian village, two miles from Duncan, stands a new school for Island day school, first of its kind in the Dominion, ready for occupancy in January.

The school will be Catholic, and will draw its pupils from the present Comoxen Indian day school, which remains open for the Protestant remainder, and from the Kuper Island attending schools, which is overcrowded.

It has room for 120 pupils, and will have 60 between the ages of nine and twenty at first. There will be four teachers, manual training, domestic science—inside the knitting of the famous Cowichan sweaters—and elementary agriculture, will be part of the practical curriculum.

Dear Sir:

I had occasion recently to visit the Cowichan Agency and while at Duncan went out to look over the new Cowichan Consolidated Indian Day School. The building has every appearance of having been well constructed, and is of very pleasing design. One is favorably impressed almost immediately with the somewhat distinctive lines and general appearance of the school. The classrooms are large and bright, and the basement has been subdivided so as to provide for Manual Training and other requirements. The building, which will be completed shortly, will be an important addition to the facilities provided by the Department in this Province for the education and training of our Indian children.

It would appear that the contract only provided for three small outside toilets, as this is the number that has been erected. One of these is for the staff. The accommodation provided in this respect is by no means sufficient, and I would suggest that provision be made immediately for the construction of an outside screened-in boys' urinal and two extra toilets. This would meet the requirements and would provide two toilets for the girls and the same number plus an urinal for the boys. Board screens should be erected in front of the urinal and all toilets. Should funds not be available at the moment to provide all this additional accommodation, I consider it very important that the urinal be constructed, and I should appreciate covering authority in this respect.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant with reference to certain equipment required at the new Cowichan Consolidated Indian Day School. Memorandum:

The Deputy Minister.

The services of a Caretaker are required for the new Cowichan Consolidated Indian Day School, Cowichan Agency, B.C., which will be opened on January 3, 1940.

This building contains four classrooms and a basement for vocational training. The Caretaker will be required to operate the furnace, keep the building clean and assist with the school garden.

This is a case where it is considered that an Indian should be given preference in appointment. Owing to present economic conditions and the high cost of relief, the Department feels that when an opportunity arises where the employment of an Indian will meet the requirements, he should be given consideration.

Major MacKay has thoroughly discussed the matter of a Caretaker for this school with the Indian Agent, Mr. R. H. Moore, and has recommended the employment of Chris Camute, of the Cowichan Reserve, for the position. He is 38 years of age, good living and industrious, and is stated to be qualified to undertake the work.

It is thought that $600.00 per annum would be a fair and reasonable salary.

I have, therefore, prepared a submission to the Civil Service Commission and Treasury Board for the establishment of a position, and would ask that the matter receive early attention.

Director.

In accordance with your instructions I visited this school on December 8th in company with the Indian Agent, Mr. Moore, and after looking over the situation beg to report that to carry out full improvements as outlined in detail hereafter will cost approximately $1035.00.

During time of visit the grounds were very wet from exceptionally heavy rain falling at the time and the previous day. Conditions were therefore as severe as are likely to be encountered unless after melting snow.

The several items which it is suggested might be improved are as follows. These are given in order of importance:

TOILETS:- The present toilets with capacity two for boys and two for girls are rather small for a four-room school (with domestic science and manual training rooms additional) which might easily have a school population of from 160 to 200 pupils. It is suggested the pupils toilets be doubled in size by affixing directly to present toilet one of same size as that at present in place with fence in front and end as shown on plan. Doors on the boys' toilets to be left off. The cost of these improvements is estimated at $114.00 made up as follows:
2 toilets @ $40.00 = $80.00
Fence, 6-feet high = $18.64
Trough = $5.00
Plus 10% = $10.26 = $114.00

WALKS: A wooden walk should be provided from the road to the front of the school and also from the terrace about the rear door to the toilets. The front walk to be of 1-inch slatted material 4-feet wide and the others to be 2½-feet wide except inside fence of toilets where 4-foot walks are needed. It is assumed the main entrance for pupils will be at rear door and a 10 ft. by 10 ft. platform should be built in front of this door. This platform to be slatted of 2-inch material.

The cost of these improvements would be approximately $114.50, and work required is as follows:

- 102 ft. of 4-foot walk laid and painted.
- 220 ft. of 2½-foot walk laid and painted.
- 1 - 10 ft. x 10 ft. platform laid and painted.

GRADING AND CLEARING: Between the school and the road there is a small area of brush, also a similar area just to the southeast of the school. These should be removed and the area about the school properly graded up as shown on the plan. The area in front of the school contains three stumps which will have to be removed. One of these is of good size and appears quite solid. The others are partly rotted. Provision for flag pole with pulley and rope and its erection should also be made. The cost of grading and clearing is estimated at $82.90. It is estimated this work could be done with one team and driver, and four men in approximately four days, plus one man day for flag pole.

Total 4 team days and 17 man days.
GRAVELLING ROAD ETC. As the fuel room and entrance is on south side of the building, it will be necessary to provide access to it by wagon or truck, therefore a road will be necessary from the highway to rear of building. It is estimated that roadway with six inches of gravel and about 10 feet wide would be satisfactory. A culvert must also be placed as shown on plan. To provide room for trucks to manoeuvre at fuel entrance and also to provide a parage ground for pupils it is considered 6" gravelling should be continued as shown on plan. Gravel should also be provided around the hydrant in the yard and from there to the road. It is also desired that a 10 foot strip of 4-inch gravel be placed on sides and front of building. The estimated cost of this work is $80.70 made up as follows:

6" gravel on road and parage, 4700 square feet
4" gravel around three sides of school, 1900 square feet.

Estimated 110 yards of gravel required.

DITCHES

The drainage of the grounds is very necessary if they are to be used for playing fields, as due to its general flatness and clay surface soil the heavy rains usual during the winter in this district do not run off and undoubtedly the grass which now covers a good portion of the grounds would soon be destroyed if drainage is not provided. It is also necessary the swamp in the bush lying to southeast of school should also be again drained and some provision made for removal of ground water now spilled on to land to west of school. As it may not be considered necessary to put in tile drains at present,
this estimate is divided into two parts. Under ditches is included the clearing of the highway ditch which is now causing a considerable amount of water trouble at the site, clearing of old ditch from the swamp and clearing of ditch from pond on land to west. The cost of this work should not cost over $28.20. Work to be done is as follows:

Clearing highway ditch, 2 men 1 day
" old ditch from swamp, 2 men 1 day
" old ditch from pond on land to west, 2 men 2 days
Total 8 man days

DRAINS

To further improve the condition of grounds it would be advisable to install certain tile drains as shown on the plan. The estimated cost of this work would be $172.30.

Work proposed is laying of following:
260 feet 4" agricultural tile drain
450 feet 3"

FENCE

As it is desired to teach a certain amount of farming at the school and as a garden is proposed, it is very necessary the property or at least a portion, be fenced. This fence will also keep stock out and thus protect the buildings etc. It has been suggested by the Indian Agent that a four foot stock fence be erected around the whole property with two 10-foot gates and two 4-foot gates as shown on plan. On the highway side of property and on west side where fence would be across open land a 2 x 6 rail be placed on top and one of same size about half way up the post. These rails would pro-
tect fence from children climbing it. Where fence is through woodland it is suggested that wooden rails be left off and a line of barbed wire be placed on top. The estimated cost of the fence around the whole property is $407.40.

Work etc., to be included is as follows:

- 2000 feet of clearing for fence
- 2000 feet #936 Mc & Mc Heavy Stock fence
- 1250 feet 4 point cattle barbed wire
- 2 - 10 foot gates 48" high
- 2 - 4 foot gates 48" high
- 1500 lineal feet 2 x 6 cedar rails painted
- Necessary 4 x 4 cedar posts dipped and painted.

SUPERVISION

It is believed supervision of this work if carried out by Indian labour is necessary and an item of $35.00 to cover living expenses etc. during progress of work is included. This is based on sufficient men being available to complete work in about one week. All buildings, fence, walks etc. are to be painted with brown creosote stain and bottom of fence posts tarred. Estimates cover cost of this work.

Attached hereto is detailed estimate and plan showing proposed improvements.

Sir:

Re: Cowichan Indian School,
Cowichan Reserve, Duncan, B.C.

In accordance with a request of the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia an examination was made of the school grounds at the new Cowichan Indian School with the idea of ascertaining what improvements are desirable.

The investigation was made by Mr. G.H. Whyte and I am pleased to enclose herewith, in triplicate, his report dated December 22, 1939. From this report you will note Mr. Whyte has covered the situation quite fully and has outlined what improvements may be carried out at the school. These include construction of additional toilets, boardwalk, grading and clearing, graveling of road and the installation of drainage ditches, as well as the fencing of the school property. Total cost of this work is estimated to be $1055.00.

Mr. Whyte has discussed the items in the order of their preference as they appear to him, and the extent to which the improvements are carried out will, of course, have to be governed by funds available.

Costs given in this report are based on the use of Indian labour, under supervision of an engineer of this organization.

Copies of this report are being furnished Mr. Indian Commissioner MacKay who will no doubt be making some recommendations to his branch in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

(sgd) C.E. Webb
District Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 5th ultimo, regarding transportation of pupils to the new Cowichan Consolidated Indian Day School and acceptance of the offer of the Cowichan Valley Bus and Taxi Services, for the ensuing six-month period, which you stated you would prefer to cover a longer period unless there were reasons to the contrary, I would advise that I had the Inspector of Indian Agencies go into this matter when he was in Duncan recently, and he found that the Duncan School Board was employing this firm on a five-year contract, and securing their copy of the agreement, he drafted a similar agreement modified to meet our conditions, also inserting a clause (Section 17) enabling the Department to cancel the contract on ninety days' notice. While it is considered that the Department's interests are fully protected, it would be appreciated if the proposed contract receives careful consideration. Meanwhile, the transportation of the children is fully arranged for until the end of this term, in June, in accordance with your instructions of the 5th ultimo.

The proposed contract would expire on 30th June, 1945, and would, therefore, be effective for five and one-half years, including the present term. The signature of the contractors was secured, as it was anticipated that any changes in costs would tend to be on the increase than otherwise, under conditions that are likely to prevail for some time.

Yours faithfully,
